webTitle: Property slowdown hits estate agency chain

fields.headline: Property slowdown hits estate agency chain
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The housing market slowdown is starting to bite, with Britain's largest estate agency yesterday reporting a 27% drop in first-half profits.
fields.body:
The housing market slowdown is starting to bite, with Britain's largest estate agency yesterday reporting a 27% drop in first-half profits.

Countrywide Assured, the life insurer and estate agency, said that with little likelihood of interest rate cuts in the near future "we believe the market slowdown will continue".

The comments from the company, whose estate agency networks include Bairstow Eves, Mann & Co and John D Wood, come 24 hours after a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors survey declared that across the country, house price growth has "all but come to an end".

Countrywide Assured's interim profits declaration sent its shares to a new low for the year. It said a second-quarter slowdown in what was previously a very buoyant housing market, combined with "negative consumer reaction" to traditional mortgage endowment policies in recent months, outweighed the good start to the year that the company previously reported.

Christopher Sporborg, CA's chairman, said: "Sales arranged in June and July have fallen sharply. As a consequence our pipeline of business in the hands of lawyers at the end of June was some £3m down on last year and is likely to continue to deteriorate."

The results provide further evidence that the housing boom is over. House-buyers have been taking a "summer break" but the market could pick up in September and October, according to the National Association of Estate Agents.

Countrywide Assured saw its shares fall 14.6% to 102.5p after it announced first-half pre-tax profits of £20.9m, down from £28.6m a year previously.

fields.headline: The ill-behaviour
fields.standfirst: Send your problem to Dr Work
fields.trailText: 24 August: I took a day off sick recently for hospital checks. My company then said they would not pay for sick leave and knocked a day's pay off my salary.
fields.body:
The problem

I recently took a day off sick and had to go to hospital for checks. We then got an office memo stating that the company was retrospectively implementing statutory sick pay and that they would not pay us for the first three consecutive days off sick. When I got my salary, they had deducted a day's pay.

Emma

The solution

This may not be legal. There is legislation to protect workers from having unauthorised deductions made from their wages and in this case, you have clearly not consented. I am assuming too, that there is no authorisation within your contract for such deductions.

You will have to take legal advice about this. If there has been an unlawful deduction, you could seek redress by making a complaint to an employment tribunal. However, you would be expected to have tried to sort it out with your employer first - quite often, a simple letter pointing out an employees legal rights, often does the trick without the need to take it further. Contact your union, Citizen's Advice or local ACAS public advisory point for further advice.

Even if your company is acting illegally, you will have to decide whether it is worth going to the trouble of trying to recoup the lost day's pay (of course, if you are ill again, it might not just be one day's lost pay). Some people might not feel it is worth the hassle, especially if they are job-hunting and anxious about references . I think your priority should obviously be getting out as soon as you can and finding a reputable company to take your talents to.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Gaea Girls
fields.standfirst:
Cameo
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000

54th Edinburgh International Film Festival
fields.trailText: Documentarist Kim Longinotto has, over the years, launched a number of investigations into the social habits of Japanese women. This latest, following the activities of a training gym for female wrestlers, is a concerted attempt to understand those who would go against Japan's apparent preference for all things demure, restrained and prettified where women are concerned.
fields.body:
Documentarist Kim Longinotto has, over the years, launched a number of investigations into the social habits of Japanese women. This latest, following the activities of a training gym for female wrestlers, is a concerted attempt to understand those who would go against Japan's apparent preference for all things demure, restrained and prettified where women are concerned.

The Gaea circuit, it would seem, is a homegrown version of the WWF, and its costumes and theatrical grappling are a low-budget fascimile of Western wrestling - no fancy martial-arts and sumo moves here. Introduced first is Nagoya Chigusa, the shock-haired, pugnacious fighter in charge of the training camp, who is also a well-established wrestler. In fact, the first proper bout we get to see is Nagoya, fighting for her team's place in the division, against a grappler who goes under the name of "Lioness Aska", and who appears equipped with a large ironing board. Nagoya, however, is too quick for the Lioness, and sneakily overpowers her with an unexpected mouthful of lighter fuel blown through a naked flame.

Though the drift of the film appears at first to be a not unexpected vision of tough-girl empowerment, Gaea Girls begins to edge into more fruitful areas. Like all good documentaries, the real narrative emerges slowly, and here it reveals itself to be the story of Takeuchi, one of the recruits who has to pass a stringent multi-bout test to prove herself worthy of making her professional debut.

Outside the ring, Takeuchi is a shy, sweet-tempered giggler; inside, she becomes a ball of screaming energy, desperate to impress her coach and promoter. As she is routinely humiliated and reduced to a snivelling, bloodied wreck, Takeuchi's odyssey becomes genuinely heart-rending; but it's all too evident that, in sparring bout after sparring bout, she lacks the sheer bodyweight and strength to make a natural wrestler.

Longinotto and her co-film-maker Jano Williams don't inquire too deeply into the choreographed nature of what they are witnessing; their detached style makes a virtue of letting the fighters speak and act for themselves. But that's a minor quibble into what becomes a moving portrait of a bizarre sub-culture.

Screening tonight. Box office: 0131-623 8030.

fields.headline: Sean Lock
fields.standfirst:
Assembly Rooms
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Sean Lock is far from being the only stand-up purveying his sort of low-key free-associative humour, owing as much to wordplay as to the far-fetched "imagine if" conceit. But he is one of the best (hence being nominated for this year's Perrier), particularly because he doesn't appear to try too hard.
fields.body:
Sean Lock is far from being the only stand-up purveying his sort of low-key free-associative humour, owing as much to wordplay as to the far-fetched "imagine if" conceit. But he is one of the best (hence being nominated for this year's Perrier), particularly because he doesn't appear to try too hard.

He comes on clutching his hand to his head, making his fingers into a dapper fringe, his patented device for concealing baldness. Then he gives a tiny puff - just so - and his finger-fringe rises up a half-inch, so languidly that you have the gist of his comic style right there.

Lock is a curious mixture of brazenly confident and sheepishly apologetic, and such a relaxed presence that he barely bothers to project any conventional showbiz front, just breezing a sort of muted glee. Lock is pitching it slightly more gently than he has in the past, which makes his current set engaging rather than hysterical. But he really comes into his own when the rambling fantasies suddenly coalesce in a crisp little formula that sounds perfect almost regardless of the gag. One riff involves an endless chain of explanations for an audience that doesn't know any nouns: "Barn - building where farmers keep their porn." And never mind what it would mean to be caught in a "dwarf shame spiral", just the euphonious ring of it shows why Lock is an act to relish.

Till Monday. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

webTitle: Egg helps foil first virtual bank robbery

fields.headline: Egg helps foil first virtual bank robbery
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: Internet bank Egg worked with police to develop software that helped trace a gang behind what is thought to be Britain's first alleged attemped online bank robbery, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Internet bank Egg worked with police to develop software that helped trace a gang behind what is thought to be Britain's first alleged attemped online bank robbery, it emerged yesterday.

Three people arrested following a six-month investigation into internet banking fraud involving the Prudential banking subsidiary have been released on bail pending further inquiries, the national crime squad said yesterday.

It also confirmed that other online banks may have been targeted by the alleged fraudsters. The arrests prompted experts to claim it was only a matter of time before criminals successfully carry out a "virtual bank raid".

Egg said its security systems were not breached and that there had been "absolutely no risk to customers' money whatsoever". But it confirmed that the alleged fraudsters "may have got away with a minimal amount". The fraud is said to have involved multiple bogus applications for loans and savings accounts.

Three people were detained after officers swooped on addresses in Buckinghamshire, Bedfordshire and Northamptonshire. Officers seized computer equipment as well as a quantity of cash and drugs in the raids on Tuesday.

Staff at the bank have worked with police over the past six months to help with the investigation. Tony Williams, Egg communications director, said: "This is not about hacking but multiple applications."

During the investigation Egg developed software that "rings an alarm bell" when a number of applications are made from the same address or PC.

The national crime squad said the possibility of attacks on other online banks came to light after studying the alleged fraudsters' computers.

Anthony Riem, partner at the "cyber law" specialist Philippsohn Crawfords Berwald, predicted that many more crime syndicates will attack internet banks, putting them at risk of losing millions of pounds.

webTitle: Edinburgh review:  Americana Absurdum: Wolverine Dream

fields.headline: Americana Absurdum: Wolverine Dream
fields.standfirst:
Assembly Rooms
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: The American dream doesn't just die, it is blown to smithereens in this joyously dysfunctional account of corporate and family greed, set in an America where clowns and a talking wolverine hang around with dubious airline tycoons and even more doubtful compensation lawyers.
fields.body:
The American dream doesn't just die, it is blown to smithereens in this joyously dysfunctional account of corporate and family greed, set in an America where clowns and a talking wolverine hang around with dubious airline tycoons and even more doubtful compensation lawyers.

Taking place in the aftermath of a plane crash, which only the wolverine survives, Brian Parks's play takes the form of a series of snappy comic monologues or brief interchanges that throw a spotlight on the dark lives that are only bearable if you are shooting up, of people who are all out to make a fast-buck, for whom self-belief is the only religion.

Stylistically, it has the energetic buzz of theatre designed for an audience with the attention span of a flea. The snappiness of the production adds to the disorientating effect and the whole thing seems like a particularly sick episode of The Simpsons played at double speed. Spotlighting the great sickness that is the US has never been quite such fun, although the play - if that's what you can call it - doesn't shirk at finding the tragic in the freakish. God bless America, she really needs it.

Till Monday. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

fields.headline: More for the head than the heart
fields.standfirst:
Arcadia
Chichester Festival Theatre
***
fields.trailText: How do you play Tom Stoppard? For the passion or the ideas? Chichester has had the bright idea of inviting Peter Wood, for many years Stoppard's most faithful interpreter, to stage the first major revival of Arcadia. The result is cool, witty, elegant and intellectually much clearer than the National Theatre original; but in muting the play's element of suppressed romanticism, Wood's staging unwittingly exposes its flaws.
fields.body:
How do you play Tom Stoppard? For the passion or the ideas? Chichester has had the bright idea of inviting Peter Wood, for many years Stoppard's most faithful interpreter, to stage the first major revival of Arcadia. The result is cool, witty, elegant and intellectually much clearer than the National Theatre original; but in muting the play's element of suppressed romanticism, Wood's staging unwittingly exposes its flaws.

Marilyn Butler, in a perceptive programme note, compares Stoppard's plays to the conversational novels of Thomas Love Peacock; and there is much of Headlong Hall, with its disputatious gathering of writers, scientists, painters and landscape artists, in Arcadia. The key difference is that Stoppard interweaves life in a Derbyshire country house from 1809 to 1812 with the present day. In the earlier era we see the precocious Thomasina Coverley not only falling in love with her Byronic tutor but anticipating modern ideas about chaos theory and irregular "fractal" geometry. In the present we see a vainglorious academic twit hopelessly misreading the past while the silent love of a mute teenager for a female scholar decisively echoes it.

Stoppard's play is many things: part satire, part detective-story (who was the hermit who died in the grounds of Sidley Park?), part debate about determinism and free will, part celebration of ungovernable human curiosity in the face of the running-down of the universe. The play is a fantastically ingenious construct, but it lacks a strong internal dynamic, and Wood's production, explanatory rather than emotional, makes you aware of the lack of narrative propulsion. The one genuinely moving moment comes when Thomasina's tutor, responding to her lament over Caesar's burning of the Alexandrian library, argues that whatever is historically lost is recovered in the long march of humanity.

Wood's production looks handsome and is well-cast. The outstanding performance comes from Eleanor David, who lends Hannah, the modern scholar and hermit-seeker, a mocking, ironic, laid-back intelligence that effortlessly exposes Jay Villiers's blustering vanity as her academic rival. Laura Howard and Robert Hands are also quietly impressive as Thomasina and her tutor without ever quite conveying the contours of burgeoning passion. But the production plays more to the head than the heart, and if Stoppard keeps the audience on the edge of its seat, here it is more out of a desire to unravel the play's meaning than to discover what will happen next.

Until October 7. Box office: 01243 781312.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: European fillip will fail to quell worries

fields.headline: European fillip will fail to quell worries
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: At a time when manufacturing is squealing loudly about the damage inflicted by the pound's strength against the euro, the European Union goods deficit narrowed to £131m in June from £576m in May.
fields.body:
At a time when manufacturing is squealing loudly about the damage inflicted by the pound's strength against the euro, the European Union goods deficit narrowed to £131m in June from £576m in May.

This was the smallest shortfall for more than three years and reflected a 5.1% pick-up in exports, chiefly of cars, intermediate and capital goods.

The strength of Britain's exports appears to take the wind out of the pro-EMU camp's sails. But that surge, a reflection of the strength of demand in the continental European economy, looks less impressive when longer-term trends are examined.

For example, over the latest three months compared to the previous three, the value of exports to the EU rose by just 0.4% while those to non-EU countries increased by 5.9% over the same period. Compared to the same three months a year ago, the increase was 10.3% versus 19.1% to non-EU countries.

In volume terms, the office for national statistics estimates that exports to the EU, excluding oil and erratic items such as ships and aircraft, are barely growing at all; a year ago they were growing by about 1% a month.

The figures are not compelling evidence that manufacturing is prospering, but do suggest the situation is not as dire as some pro-EMU lobbyists pretend.

The good news in June's EU deficit is offset by the bad news in the widening non-EU balance, itself possibly a reflection of the pound's strength. Anecdotal evidence suggests sterling's strength is forcing many UK-based companies to source components from abroad instead of buying British.

The result can be seen in a surge of imports from non-EU countries, up 5.9% in June compared to May and a whopping 24.4% in the latest three months compared to the same period a year ago. Irrespective of the relative movements of the EU and non-EU deficits, the overall trade gap is on a widening trend, according to the ONS, and on course to hit a record high of around £3bn next month.

webTitle: US-style bonus schemes are on way

fields.headline: US-style bonus schemes are on way
fields.trailText: An explosion of US-style pay deals was predicted yesterday with Britain's top companies planning to double the number of share options they grant to senior executives, according to research by a consultancy firm.
fields.body:
An explosion of US-style pay deals was predicted yesterday with Britain's top companies planning to double the number of share options they grant to senior executives, according to research by a consultancy firm.

The move would see even faster rates of wage rises in Britain's boardrooms. The Guardian-Inbucon survey of directors' pay revealed a 16.5% rise last year.

But research by William M Mercer, a consultancy firm, showed annual grants of options are running at more than twice a top executive's salary, with awards ranging from the equivalent of salary to more than 20 times basic pay.

Share options are the basis of the new multi-million pound pay packets. The two executives at the top of the Guardian's pay survey, Arun Sarin and Mohan Gyani, both from Vodafone, were propelled to the top of the table because of gains - worth about £15m - on cheap options last year.

The prediction that British companies plan to award more options to their executives is expected to add weight to the call by the Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting guidelines, for options to be registered on a company's profit and loss account.

Michael McKersie of the Association of British Insurers, whose members control about a quarter of the stock market, said investors wanted to know the value of the options being awarded to executives. "Investors do want to see that the options are recognised."

However, the debate over whether awards of options to executives should appear in company accounts is expected to rage for at least two years.

The proposal, published by the ASB last month, has met fierce resistance from some companies.They have raised concerns that the plans could hurt basic save-as-you-earn employee schemes.

The industry has been expecting a wave of more generous reward schemes since the ABI relaxed its guidelines on options awards, which used to restrict annual grants to one times salary.

Mr McKersie said last night that investors were generally supportive of an increase in the proportion of share-based awards to directors because they allowed a closer link of directors' pay to their companies' performance.

This was described by Marcus Peaker, a founding member of remuneration consultancy Meis, as one the main differences between the rewards to directors in Britain and those in the US, where many schemes are not linked to specific performance targets.

While some companies, such as Barclays and Glaxo Wellcome, have introduced schemes which have elements modelled on US lines, remuneration experts do not believe they are yet to become commonplace.

webTitle: Edinburgh review:  Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight

fields.headline: Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Below
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: So here we are in Edinburgh, that hell hole of the North, and we have been ushered into an audience with Garth Marenghi, dream weaver, shaman, one hell of a man and the author of 24 classic horror novels including Black Fang (rats learn to drive) and The Ooze (can water die?).
fields.body:
So here we are in Edinburgh, that hell hole of the North, and we have been ushered into an audience with Garth Marenghi, dream weaver, shaman, one hell of a man and the author of 24 classic horror novels including Black Fang (rats learn to drive) and The Ooze (can water die?).

Such is my unfamiliarity with the horror genre and such is the detailed pastiche of this show, right down to its brilliant flyers with their two-for-one Goth offer, that I have to confess there were a couple of minutes at the start when I thought our Garth might be for real.

But it soon becomes clear - as Garth squares up to face the Fright Knight who has kidnapped his muse, does battle with the hag who makes ice-cream from her own breast milk and subdues the forces of evil - that this is a very slick and very funny spoof on the whole tacky genre. It's just been nominated for the Perrier, so leave your incredulity and good taste behind, and prepare to be truly terrified by the fact that one man can single-handedly inflict such devastating damage on the English language.

Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Review:  European Union Youth Orchestra/Ashkenazy/ Henschel

fields.headline: Embodying an ideal
fields.standfirst:
European Union Youth Orchestra/Ashkenazy/ Henschel
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: The women of the European Union Youth Orchestra advertise the ensemble's mission by draping themselves in swathes of chiffon bearing the blue and gold-starred emblem of the EU flag. Some might see this as overstating the case, but the EUYO has a high political status, and is held up by many as the artistic embodiment of the EU ideal.
fields.body:
The women of the European Union Youth Orchestra advertise the ensemble's mission by draping themselves in swathes of chiffon bearing the blue and gold-starred emblem of the EU flag. Some might see this as overstating the case, but the EUYO has a high political status, and is held up by many as the artistic embodiment of the EU ideal. Under its current music director Vladimir Ashkenazy, it draws players from major academies Europe-wide, provides them with intensive training and undertakes major concerts each year.

Another sartorial surprise came when the evening's soloist, the baritone Dietrich Henschel, arrived on the platform. Tall and lanky, he was kitted out in tight brown leather and his appearance caused the audience to gasp. Perhaps he felt he needed to make an immediate impression, for he was a last-minute substitute for the popular but indisposed Matthias Goerne.

Henschel, however, didn't need to worry: in a stunning performance of Mahler's Early Songs, orchestrated by Berio, he soon had the audience in the palm of his hand. His voice is lighter than Goerne's - a flash of silver as opposed to Goerne's bronze gleam. He floats pianissimo high notes with a tender ease rare in baritones. Elsewhere, his experience as a singing actor spoke volumes as phrase after phrase of the dark, charnel-house texts was brilliantly laced with irony. The EUYO wove tendrils of elegant sound around him. Ashkenazy impressively emphasised both the orchestral sections that sound like genuine Mahler and those moments of sparse strangeness that are very much Berio's own.

This was the high point, for the works that flanked it came over unevenly. Strauss's Don Juan wasn't quite the show-stopper it could have been. Ashkenazy sees the piece as being about love rather than sex, presenting a portrait of a man whose emotions, though transitory, are genuine. It is a valid interpretation, but ultimately one misses the visceral excitement, the hints of obscenity and the orgiastic atmosphere that should hang over the piece.

Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony was done at high neurotic voltage, occasionally tipping into overblown melodrama in the process. The EUYO playing is exemplary, with some glorious instrumental solos in both works. On occasion, however, the balance lacks cogency, with the brass tending to drown out the rest of the orchestra.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Calling for calm
fields.standfirst:
Wilby
Ronnie Scott's, London
***
fields.trailText: "I don't write many happy songs do I?" ponders Rosie Wilby, singer, songwriter and pint-sized star of Wilby. "Sorry about that. It just comes out that way." But though her songs are melancholy musings on love, they're delicately wrapped in the sound of sunny pop. Joined by four instrumentalists, including Chris Bachmann on guitar, and two backing singers, Rosie Wilby treats her bright blue guitar as an extension of herself in a manner that puts the likes of Sheryl Crow to shame. Once she begins This Time, from debut album Precious Moments, all heads turn.
fields.body:
"I don't write many happy songs do I?" ponders Rosie Wilby, singer, songwriter and pint-sized star of Wilby. "Sorry about that. It just comes out that way." But though her songs are melancholy musings on love, they're delicately wrapped in the sound of sunny pop. Joined by four instrumentalists, including Chris Bachmann on guitar, and two backing singers, Rosie Wilby treats her bright blue guitar as an extension of herself in a manner that puts the likes of Sheryl Crow to shame. Once she begins This Time, from debut album Precious Moments, all heads turn.

Her voice is glorious, ranging from the trembly heights of Kate Bush to a wistful, candy-floss lightness, warm and welcoming. Each note played and word uttered is as finely tuned as Wilby's guitar, but without any air of elitism or jazz cool. The singer's performance is heartfelt but her attitude is as breezy as her songs. After a seductive I Want You, so slinky it should be wearing a backless black dress, she brings us back to earth with a bump. "I still never pulled with that song," she says, with a shrug, half-amused, half-dismayed.

Maybe the men she targets just don't appreciate the detail she puts into her lyrics. "The way your hair falls/ You will see/ That does something to me," she purrs, coquettish but with a little-girl charm. When one of those notes aiming to hit the ceiling proves too elusive, she mutters a quick "oops" and carries on regardless.

It's a pity that some of the audience don't take the time to notice. While Ronnie Scott's is a low-lit, comfy venue - perfect for Wilby to strut their stuff - its laid-back atmosphere allows the chatter from the crowd to compete with what is happening on stage; tender moments are too easily spoilt by people fretting about catching the last train home. But Wilby are lost in their own world. While the likes of This Love offer slow-burning gentleness, and Lifeline sees Rosie Wilby alone in the spotlight, terrified but triumphant, Take My Hand sees her rock out, as much as an acoustic guitar allows, gritting her teeth and bobbing her head as she moves around the stage, carried away by her music. But then reality returns. "I've got to calm down a bit," she explains, a little embarrassed. "I got over excited at the end there."

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Crane World
fields.standfirst:
Cameo
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000

54th Edinburgh International Film Festival
fields.trailText: A study of an out-of-work Argentinian ex-musician may not sound the most promising material for a feature film, but first-time director Pablo Trapero has crafted an impressive debut - one that emphasises the dignity of his subject without lapsing into agit-prop.
fields.body:
A study of an out-of-work Argentinian ex-musician may not sound the most promising material for a feature film, but first-time director Pablo Trapero has crafted an impressive debut - one that emphasises the dignity of his subject without lapsing into agit-prop.

The central figure here is one Rulo (Luis Margani), nearing 50 and running to considerable fat. His wife is long gone, and he has lapsed into the unprepossessing lifestyle of the set-in-his-ways mid-lifer: washing up when he feels like it, clothes where he drops them, that sort of thing. Rulo is also saddled with an adolescent son, a none-too-trim specimen himself, fond of Sepultura and other metal outfits so popular in Latin America.

Much of Rulo's time is spent attempting to find a job: he has a friend who works for a construction company, and so Rulo is given a crash course in how to operate one of those gigantic 300-foot cranes that tower over the city building sites. Reinforcing the irony of Rulo's hand-to-mouth predicament is the fact that his band ("The Seventh Regiment") briefly achieved stardom in the 70s - added to which, his son Claudio (Federico Esquerro) is knocking out a racket with a pick-up garage band of his own.

Trapero's treatment of this blue-collar milieu is pleasantly straightforward and low-key: neither does he cast Rulo as an incarnation of working-class nobility (this guy is a serious slob, and kicks his son out when he gets too noisy), nor as a repository of society's ills - much of his misfortune, you sense, is due to his inability to focus properly, or pay attention to reasonably obvious warning signs. Trapero concentrates on Rulo's stolid bravery: when he loses out to a younger, fitter competitor for the crane job, his only option is to travel thousands of miles south to a building project in Patagonia - sacrificing a flourishing love affair as he does so - on a vague friend-of-a-friend promise. That he encounters genuine comradeship in a trying environment is almost incidental; the job comes to an end, and the work cycle grinds on remorselessly.

Much has been made of Trapero's debt to neo-realism, and while the monochromatic visuals and thematic common ground with Bicycle Thieves are undoubtedly powerful, Crane World belongs to a much more stripped-down school of realism that is present in some strength at Edinburgh.

Tonight and Saturday. Box office: 0131-623 8030.

fields.headline: A tip to the regulator: don't treat us like fools
fields.standfirst:
FSA clampdown on websites

Net news
Special report: e-financeMoney Unlimited
fields.trailText: Just 20 years ago, when the architects of Britain's framework of financial regulation set about scraping away some of the City's filth, a sensible guiding principle was adopted. The regulator's job, it was decreed, was not to protect a fool from losing his or her money but to protect an ordinary investor from being made to look a fool.
fields.body:
Just 20 years ago, when the architects of Britain's framework of financial regulation set about scraping away some of the City's filth, a sensible guiding principle was adopted. The regulator's job, it was decreed, was not to protect a fool from losing his or her money but to protect an ordinary investor from being made to look a fool.

It sometimes seems that over the years this principle has been edited down to the point where the newly empowered financial services authority just treats everyone as an idiot.

That may sound harsh but it is difficult to conclude otherwise after this week's news that two financial websites have had to stop reprinting share tips from newspapers. Or they would have to be registered as financial advisers (and regulated as such), even though newspapers and many investment periodicals are exempt from the rule.

While the FSA pleads that it is not trying to stifle the internet but simply applying established law, the argument that collating newspaper tips on a website amounts to financial advice is clearly nonsense.

The affair highlights, once again, the particular muddle over where financial regulation should start and where it should stop. Ten years ago, the FSA's forerunner, the securities & investments board, thought it worth its bureaucratic while to crack down on a bookie in Bournemouth who started offering odds on pairs of shares with daily "price races". A decade on and the FSA is arguing that the likes of Sharepages.com and Digitallook.com are not "periodicals" and are therefore not eligible for the regulatory exception enjoyed, for example, by this newspaper.

These web services are "continuous" publications, you see, and therefore ripe for regulatory picking.

Talks are under way between the FSA and the Treasury about getting some clarity on the matter into the next tranche of City legislation. But the crass way the rules are being implemented does note bode well.

Fraud frustrated

Egg has hit the headlines as victim of the first internet bank heist, yet this is not the great train robbery replayed in cyberspace. There was no latter-day Ronnie Biggs; the important fact, somewhat forgotten amid the excitement, is that the cyber-crooks did not get away with it.

In truth, the attempted robbery was rather old-fashioned. It was not masterminded by a remote hacker whizzing millions of pounds across the net with a few clever clicks. Instead it was a relatively simple (in their case, too simple) matter of applying for loans under fictitious names and addresses in the hope that Egg would send the loot.

Banks have always been open to such fraud and the internet does not make it easier to carry out; it probably makes it harder. It is now much easier to verify data electronically on names and addresses, while money laundering regulations introduced in the past 10 years make opening a bank account impossible without extensive checking of an individual's identity.

The real risk to the public's confidence in e-commerce is the explosive growth in "card not present" fraud. This is where someone - perhaps a waiter or petrol attendant - copies your credit card details and passes them on to counterfeit gangs which then use the number to make substantial purchases over the net. The banks hope to short-circuit this little wheeze by making retailers ask for the three-digit number on the back of a card, which will not be available to someone who has made a copy of the front. Over the net, security will be further strengthened by new systems to check billing addresses.

The French are ahead of the British; card users there have to type secret four-digit Pin numbers on keypads instead of signing till receipts, eliminating easily copied card imprints. There are plans to introduce the system in the UK, but not before 2004. This sloppy timescale benefits only the crooks, and the Home Office needs to act now to hurry it along.

webTitle: Royle trusts City flops to seize Maine chance

fields.headline: Royle trusts City flops to seize Maine chance
fields.trailText: Joe Royle is giving his humiliated Manchester City team the chance to redeem themselves when Sunderland visit Maine Road tonight.
fields.body:
Joe Royle is giving his humiliated Manchester City team the chance to redeem themselves before their own fans when Premiership football comes to Maine Road tonight for the first time in four years.

City gave a dismal performance in the opening-day 4-0 defeat at Charlton but Royle has already announced the same side for the visit of Sunderland, which sees the former Maine Road manager Peter Reid and the one-time City striker Niall Quinn returning.

Royle's new £500,000 signing Paul Ritchie will be on the bench. Reid has Don Hutchison available after the midfielder missed the win over Arsenal because of suspension, but the goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen is struggling with a knee problem and the midfielder Eric Roy is almost certainly out with an ankle injury.

Peter Taylor aims to break a depressing sequence when he takes Leicester to Upton Park tonight. They have not beaten West Ham there since 1966. But Taylor said: "I will not be going for a draw. One of two of our players really impressed against Aston Villa but the other players can do a lot more."

Taylor watched Steve Guppy, linked with Celtic after being left out against Villa, and Frank Sinclair play in a reserve match last night and may include them in tonight's squad.

The early leaders Charlton go to Everton tonight and Arsenal on Saturday knowing those games will be a far stronger examination of their calibre than last Saturday's.

Everton have several injury problems but Alan Curbishley is expecting a hot reception from Walter Smith's side.

webTitle: Vieira may quit before ban ends

fields.headline: Vieira may quit before ban ends
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira will be banned for five matches for his red cards against Sunderland and Liverpool, though Emmanuel Petit suggested yesterday that his former Arsenal team-mate might not stay in England to see that out.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira will be banned for five matches for his red cards against Sunderland and Liverpool, though Emmanuel Petit suggested yesterday that his former Arsenal team-mate might not stay in England to see that out.

Vieira is reported to have said when he came off on Monday that he did "not want to play [in England] any more" and Petit said he feared the 24-year-old might leave because he felt targeted by opponents and not protected by referees.

"I'm afraid he might feel he must quit," said Petit, explaining that his own move to Barcelona was influenced by such problems. "I am sure he loves the fans and he loves the club but he is really fed up with the treatment he is getting.

"When you are a quiet player it is easy to play in England. The referees and other players leave you alone. But when you are famous the problems come. The violence is growing in English football, and players with a high profile like Patrick, Beckham, Wise, Bergkamp and Leboeuf are suffering."

Meanwhile the Football Association insisted its new disciplinary procedures had no bearing on the three red cards issued by Graham Poll at Highbury. "They were his responsibility and his alone," it said.

The new procedures, it explained, concerned "bringing clarity and consistency once disciplinary action is under way and punishments have to be assessed and handed out."

Vieira cannot appeal against his ban, which includes an extra match because he has been sent off twice this season. Liverpool's Gary McAllister and Didi Hamann get three- and one-match bans respectively.

webTitle: Worthington Cup: Ellis late strike puts leash on Rovers

fields.headline: Ellis late strike puts leash on Rovers
fields.trailText:
It may not have lived up to the greatest day in Rochdale's history, but a 90th-minute header by Tony Ellis ensured current fans will long remember this night.
Rochdale 1 - 0 Blackburn
fields.body:
It may not have lived up to the greatest day in Rochdale's history - the 3-1 League Cup semi-final win over the same opponents here 38 years ago - but a 90th-minute header by Tony Ellis ensured the present generation of home fans will long remember this night.

The Third Division side emerged with great credit as they fought back from a 59th-minute goal by Nathan Blake.

The financial resources of the respective Lancashire clubs may put them on different planets but at least Graeme Souness tried to level the playing field by resting several regular starters. It meant a rare appearance for Keith Gillespie, one of a number of players now surplus to requirements.

Gillespie looked eager to take advantage of the opportunity. His 29th-minute cross created the first real opening as Blake rose and forced Neil Edwards into a fine one-handed tip over the crossbar.

Edwards, from close range, then denied Blake from the resulting corner but just as Rovers looked to be exerting a stranglehold, Rochdale responded in determined fashion.

The source of their more encouraging moments was the irrepressible midfielder Tony Ford, 41 years old and making his 1,014th first-team appearance. Twice, in quick succession, his deep right-wing crosses hung tantalisingly in the air for Ellis. First, however, the much-travelled striker snatched at his shot before placing a header narrowly beyond the far post.

Blake threatened again just before the interval, turning sharply and shooting just off target. But with the French striker Kaba Diawara, at Rovers for the rest of the season on loan from Paris St-Germain, watching from the stand, it was not an encouraging first-half for the visiting strikers.

The second half briefly promised to follow a similar pattern as Ellis was presented with two chances, the first a shot he put wide, the second requiring a well-judged interception by Marlon Broomes from a Michael Oliver cross.

Gillespie then saw an effort headed off the line by Wayne Evans before a moment of genuine quality finally broke the deadlock. Matthew Jansen threaded a pass to put in Blake for a routine finish.

fields.headline: Arsenal eye Dyer and Croatian
fields.trailText: Arsenal want to buy another midfielder and have been linked with Kieron Dyer, Newcastle's England international, and Igor Biscan, a 22-year-old international with the Croatian champions Dinamo Zagreb.
fields.body:
Arsenal want to buy another midfielder and have been linked with Kieron Dyer, Newcastle's England international, and Igor Biscan, a 22-year-old international with the Croatian champions Dinamo Zagreb.

Biscan, a tall, powerful former defender, is valued at about £4m. Milan and Ajax are also showing interest.

Charlton, with four senior strikers injured, have inquired about Jean-Claude Darcheville, a 25-year-old who was with Nottingham Forest two seasons ago. He plays for the French second division club Lorient, for whom he was top scorer last season. They are willing to sell for about £600,000.

"Charlton have contacted us about Jean-Claude," said their president Marcel Le Mentec. "We are short of money as a result of club restructuring and we need to sell him."

Alan Buckley yesterday became the first English managerial casualty of the season when he was sacked by Grimsby only two games into the new term.

Buckley, 49, was in his second spell at Grimsby having rejoined them in 1997 after an unsuccessful spell at West Brom. His team were close to relegation from the First Division last season and they opened this campaign by losing at home to Preston before drawing at Portsmouth on Saturday. The club's vice-chairman Bryan Huxford said: "Results have not improved and we felt it was time for a change."

Wolves will pay about £1.3m for the Saudi international striker Sami Al Jaber after he impressed in a trial. The 27-year-old is to sign a four-year contract and the deal involves Wolves playing two exhibition games in Riyadh.

webTitle: The best Christopher Eccleston scene: Gone in 60 seconds

fields.headline: The best Christopher Eccleston scene: Gone in 60 seconds
fields.trailText: Retired car thief Memphis Raines (Nicolas Cage) has been summoned to the
fields.body:
Retired car thief Memphis Raines (Nicolas Cage) has been summoned to the

office of bigtime villain Raymond Calitri (Christopher Eccleston). Calitri has threatened to kill Memphis's brother Kip, who owes him money. Sitting at his desk, he explains, "On this list you'll find 50 cars - five zero. I need all 50 delivered to Long Beach Harbour, Pier 14, by 8am four days from now. I'll pay you $200,000."

"I'm not interested, I'm just here for my brother."

"Young Kip came to me, he had street cred - the brother of the notorious Memphis Red. So two weeks ago I hired him, and advanced him $10,000."

"Yeah, he told me. If it's about the advance, I can understand your anger. The debt has to be settled." Memphis takes out a wad of notes and places them on the desk. "Ten grand. From me to you."

Calitri looks scornful. "I wish it was that easy."

"I don't see the complication."

Calitri gets up and begins to pace. "I have four days to deliver 50 cars and I have no cars. It's about me delivering 50 top-end cars because I said I would. Because if I don't, my South American friend goes elsewhere from now on. It's a humiliation. Because I'm the arsehole who said he could deliver. Am I an arsehole? Do I look like an arsehole?"

Memphis looks him up and down. "Yeah."

Calitri throws the $10,000 in his face.

See also: Shallow Grave, Elizabeth, Let Him Have It, Jude

Don't see also: eXistenZ

Pointless Trivia: Before landing a film role, Christopher Eccleston had small parts in episodes of Boon, Poirot and Inspector Morse.

fields.headline: 'Victim' Vieira urged to stay
fields.standfirst: The combative midfielder was made for the Premiership, not its referees
fields.trailText: The combative midfielder was made for the Premiership, not its referees, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
As Patrick Vieira considers taking his most dramatic early exit yet, this time out of English football altogether, he may be heartened to hear that rivals, as well as team-mates, are insisting he should stay.

This even includes Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann, the victim of the tackle that led to Vieira's second red card in three days at Highbury on Monday, who said: "It would be bad for English football if he left. He is a fantastic player and not a dirty one. He plays the game in a fair-minded way."

In any case, even if Vieira left Arsenal it is difficult to imagine where he could go in search of greater understanding, short of signing for the Priory Clinic XI. In Europe's main leagues a man of his combative instincts would be unlikely to complete 90 minutes of any game, and in Italy he would be lucky to survive the pre-match warm-up.

Vieira understands that, which is central to his frustration, feeling forced out of his natural environment by referees he believes are singling him out. But though he has at times invited punishment, unnecessarily and even recklessly, he finds himself playing in England at a time when beleaguered referees are trying to second-guess the assessors and rule-tweakers who govern them.

The English game is the fastest and most physical in the world, which used to invite a matching level of tolerance and discretion from officials who tried their best to distinguish between malevolent fouls and mistimed ones. Now those qualities have been reclassified as vices for referees who have been instructed, as they were at the beginning of last season, to take a zero-tolerance attitude to foul play.

Vieira, who was sent off only once in each of the previous two seasons, made a serious attempt to temper his game after his red card against West Ham last October, when he received a six-match ban not for his tackle but for spitting at Neil Ruddock.

To a degree he has even managed to temper his temper. And he was so confident that he could offer further proof that he was reformed this season that he struck a bet with his best friend Olivier Dacourt that he would have the better disciplinary record of the two of them.

Dacourt, in Germany preparing for Leeds's Champions League qualifier against Munich 1860 tonight, says: "I phoned Pat after the Sunderland game to tell him that he would never win the bet. He managed to joke then but he must be very upset now.

"When you watch the incident against Liverpool, can you tell me that he was not unlucky? I have not been able to speak to him yet but when he came off the pitch he told the people in French that he does not want to play in England any more. If he does stop playing, the Premiership will lose a great player."

Though Dacourt could be expected to defend his friend, Vieira's case is significantly helped by the more independent support of Sunderland's manager Peter Reid and Liverpool's Gérard Houllier, who both insisted he was desperately unlucky. And though Hamann insists that the tackle on him deserved a yellow card, he rightly points out that Vieira should never have received his first booking, when he shaped to retaliate after a Jamie Carragher foul but was held back by team-mates.

Vieira apologised to Arsenal colleagues after losing his head at Sunderland on Saturday when pulled back by Darren Williams. But though flailing an arm invited a red card, he clearly did so not with the intention of injuring an opponent but to free himself to continue an attack as his side chased a last-minute equaliser.

This is not to build a case for Vieira's canonisation. In both games he lost emotional control, and history suggests there is almost no measurable unit of time between the lighting of the blue touchpaper by an opponent and the Vieira explosion.

His expectorating performance against Ruddock, an unacceptable practice in British football, was an example of that. And as well as a sending-off against Charlton two years ago for elbowing an opponent, an unacceptable practice anywhere, he has been fined for making a V-sign to Sheffield Wednesday fans and he escaped punishment and, remarkably, retribution after appearing to butt Roy Keane last season.

After six red cards, Vieira is one sending-off away from joining Vinnie Jones at the head of the Premiership dishonours list. Given the respective talent of the two players this seems a ludicrous prospect, though Vieira has already equalled Eric Cantona's record of red cards in successive games. Cantona's were against Swindon and, no surprise here, Arsenal in 1993-94.

Despite a denial by Philip Don, the Premier League's head of refereeing, that there is a clampdown on foul play, a pattern has developed in English football in which a flurry of red cards in the opening weeks of the season becomes barely a trickle later on. By Christmas, the sort of tackle with which Vieira caught Hamann may not even bring a harsh look from a referee. Arsenal are just hoping he is still around to reap the benefit.

fields.headline: Summerbell rings to deny Spurs
fields.trailText: Hope still springs eternal in North London and on Teesside, if only because last night's closely fought draw provided little indication as to what either side can truly expect this season.
fields.body:
Hope still springs eternal in North London and on Teesside, if only because last night's closely fought draw provided little indication as to what either side can truly expect this season.

Bryan Robson can take heart from his side's early attacking and their second-half revival which saw Mark Summerbell head them level while Tottenham could have won had Steffen Iversen's late Exocet not been straight at Mark Schwarzer. In the end a point apiece seemed appropriate.

There is a sense of genuine expectation at both clubs after a summer of mouth-watering transfer activity, an enthusiasm hardly dampened by convincing opening-day victories against opponents who are expected to struggle.

For the visit of George Graham's apparently hot Spurs Teesside hoped to be granted its first sight of Alen Boksic. But, to the locals' dismay, the two-goal hero of Boro's win at Coventry was forced to rest his sore ankle.

Instead it was Joseph-Desire Job, the right-sided prong of Middlesbrough's trident attack, who posed the early threat. Within a minute of his home debut he had Neil Sullivan gratefully clutching a low shot from just inside the area.

In the absence of Boksic the sole big-name East European on view was the visitors' £11m recruit Sergei Rebrov. After a quiet start, with his side defending in numbers, the pocket-sized Ukrainian steadily imposed his influence.

There was skill - Tim Sherwood's lob was neatly controlled on his instep to gasps from the crowd - and vision as he wriggled himself into space before sending Ben Thatcher away down the left. The defender's cross was headed firmly over the bar by Steffen Iversen.

Then, after Steve Carr had seen his lob cleared off the line by Paul Okon and Sherwood had shot wide, Rebrov was instrumental in the visitors gaining a deserved lead. The striker, all twists and turns with mesmeric feet to baffle his marker, broke free of the congested midfield to measure a delicious cross into the Middlesbrough area. Arriving at speed was Oyvind Leonhardsen, who flicked a header past the diving Schwarzer and inside the far post.

Boro re-discovered some of their earlier drive after the break. Keith O'Neill's surge down the left exemplified the urgency, with Brian Deane spearing his pull-back just wide from the edge of the area.

Christian Karembeu's 50th-minute cross-shot caused similar anxiety in the Tottenham defence before the pressure told nine minutes later.

Karembeu fed Curtis Fleming down the right and the full-back's cross found two Boro players free at the back post. Summerbell, in for the injured Paul Ince, rose highest to power his first league goal beyond Sullivan.

Parity restored, both sides attacked with vigour if little poise, relying instead on the pace of their front lines to cause problems. At such frenetic pace there was no place for Rebrov and he disappeared into the dug-out looking somewhat bemused by it all.

webTitle: Mad Dog and Irishmen: a profile of Johnny Adair

fields.headline: Mad Dog and Irishmen
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown profiles Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, the Ulster Freedom Fighter set free under the Good Friday peace agreement's early release scheme, who was behind bars again today, accused of igniting a loyalist feud in Belfast
fields.trailText: Derek Brown profiles Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, the Ulster Freedom Fighter set free under the Good Friday peace agreement's early release scheme, who was behind bars again today, accused of igniting a loyalist feud in Belfast
fields.body:
Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair must have loved the drama of his arrest last night. Ordered out of his car, spread-eagled on the road, manacled and whisked off under escort to a military barracks, and then taken via helicopter to Maghaberry Jail: all very satisfying for a man consumed by his own ego.

Adair has now paid a second time for his insatiable lust for attention. His first arrest, in 1993, came after he bragged to RUC officers about his paramilitary prowess. What he didn't know, was that they were taping him. In recent days, any prudent paramilitarist would have kept his head down. Not so Adair: he was in the thick of the action, exhorting and directing his own followers, abusing the police, and generally doing his best to get his picture taken.

He is indeed photogenic, though nobody would accuse him of being handsome. He is squat, shaven-headed, and bulging with muscle which others suggest owes more to steroids than to weight-training. As an added curiosity, he has had his nipples pierced.

Aged 36, Adair lives in some comfort with his wife Gina and three young children. He enjoys dressing up in loyalist chic: T-shirts emblazoned with the red hand of Ulster, the dark glasses and baseball cap which are the hallmark of street power. And he loves being interviewed, often talking of himself in the third person. He is clearly flattered by his nickname, and recently introduced his two-year-old son to reporters as 'Mad Pup'.

Adair belongs to the streets; in particular to the Shankill Road in west Belfast. It was there, after an adolescence of petty crime and dabbling in fascism - he was pictured at a National Front rally in 1983 - that he made his name as a hard man of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, the stormtroopers and assassins of the Ulster Defence Association.

In the early 1990s there was an outbreak of sectarian killings, many attributed to the west Belfast UDA/UFF. No fewer than 22 murders of Roman Catholics were linked with Adair, though when he was finally brought to trial, he was charged not with killing, but with directing others to do so.

He was sentenced to 16 years and once in the notorious Maze prison, quickly established himself as a hardmen's hero. It was there that he developed his body-building fetish.

Adair was freed last September under the Good Friday peace deal arrangements for the early release of prisoners. He had served just five and a half years.

Under the bizarre Maze regime, he had already been let out on weekend leaves. On one such break, in May last year, he was shot and slightly wounded in the head, almost certainly by a Republican gunman.

There have been several attempts on Adair's life, and he is genuinely hated and feared by nationalists. But there is some evidence, at least once the danger is passed, that he enjoys the added notoriety such attacks bring. Only last week he claimed the IRA had tried to kill him with a home-made grenade, though no evidence was made available to the police. Since his release, Adair has claimed to be a 'community worker' but appears to have an affluent lifestyle. Recently he took his family on holiday to Jamaica and, when not wearing his trademark T-shirt, he is fond of designer clothes.

Seasoned Ulster watchers believe that the UFF/UDA is largely funding itself from the drug trade, and that its current feud with the Ulster Volunteer Force is more of a turf war than an ideological one.

Adair, however, vehemently denies involvement in drugs, and there is no evidence of any involvement on his part.

Whatever the root cause, the dispute is undeniably bloody and fraught with implications for the peace process. Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson has tried to portray Adair as an individual hoodlum without any political motivation. The truth, as ever, is much more complicated.

When Adair was first sent to prison the two loyalist factions had subsumed their long-standing rivalry in their running battles with the IRA, and their sectarian campaigns against innocent Catholics. In the latter years of the Troubles they had formed a grandiloquently titled Combined Loyalist Military Command.

In 1994, both groups followed the lead of the Provisional IRA in declaring a ceasefire. Ostensibly, the loyalist paramilitary groups threw their weight behind the new politics of the peace process. Both had political wings: the UDA/UFF was represented by the Ulster Democratic party, and the UVF by the Popular Unionist party.

But with the suspension of the immediate IRA threat, the two groups had more time to brood about their old rivalries. The tension between them was deepened by the success of the PUP in winning two seats in the Ulster Assembly. The UDP, though it has a sprinkling of local councillors, has made relatively little impact - though it has an office in Stormont and regularly takes part in round-table talks, courtesy of Mr Mandelson.

Since his release, Adair has publicly supported the peace process, and privately denounced it. He is known to despise his own UDP leader, Gary McMichael, and is reported to have had blazing rows with him. More ominously, he has made no secret of his admiration for, and links with, the hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force.

The LVF is a UVF breakaway faction which passionately opposes the Good Friday peace deal. Its first leader was Adair's personal hero, Billy 'King Rat' Wright, who was assassinated in the Maze by members of the Irish National Liberation Army.

The LVF breakaway has created a hugely volatile three-way division of hardline loyalism. As the sets of bombastic titles and initials proliferate, the oldest faction of all, the UVF, finds itself lined up against both the UDA/UFF and the LVF. Since the early release programme swung into full gear, the rival factions have been rejoined by a steady stream of prison-hardened recruits - including seasoned commanders like Adair.

Since last December, the feud has claimed half a dozen lives, and there have been scores of murderous attacks. The spark that ignited the latest wave of violence was the attack, last Saturday evening, on the home of the UVF veteran Gusty Spence. Retaliation was inevitable, and it duly came with the murder of UDA member Jackie Coulter and his friend (and former UVF supporter) Bobby Mahood.

There is no hint of a truce. The loyalist communities of Northern Ireland are fearfully awaiting the next round of attacks, and Johnnie Adair is safely behind bars.

webTitle: Gulf Air airliner crashes off Bahrain

fields.headline: Gulf Air airliner crashes off Bahrain
fields.standfirst:
Gulf Air
Bahrain Tribune newspaper
fields.trailText: A Gulf Air Airbus A320 on a scheduled flight from Bahrain to the Egyptian capital Cairo crashed in the Persian Gulf several minutes after taking off from Bahrain international airport, Bahrain information ministry officials said.
fields.body:
A Gulf Air Airbus A320 on a scheduled flight from Bahrain to the Egyptian capital Cairo crashed in the Persian Gulf several minutes after taking off from Bahrain international airport, Bahrain information ministry officials said.

Speaking on condition of anonymity, the officials did not know how many passengers were on board flight GF072, but the airline's Airbus A320s have been configured to seat up to 129 passengers, according to the Gulf Air website.

State Bahrain television said the crash was caused by a fire in one of the aircraft's engines. In the capital Manama, scores of ambulances were seen heading toward the airport. Helicopters were also seen flying in the same direction.

Gulf Air is owned by Bahrain, the Gulf states of Oman and Qatar and Abu Dhabi, the largest of seven sheikdoms making up the United Arab Emirates. Based in Bahrain, it flies to 53 international destinations.

The Gulf Air crash emergency number is 0845 604 0171.

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

200 -249 runs (1pt);

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4)

three-five wickets (1);

six-eight wickets (2);

nine-ten (3).

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Shane Warne's telephone manner may not be to everyone's liking but he cannot be faulted for effort on the field. Arriving back in England only yesterday morning after playing for Australia in their indoor series against South Africa in Melbourne, he took a wicket with his fifth ball as Hampshire restricted Kent to 268 for nine on the first day of their match in Canterbury.
fields.body:
Shane Warne's telephone manner may not be to everyone's liking but he cannot be faulted for effort on the field. Arriving back in England only yesterday morning after playing for Australia in their indoor series against South Africa in Melbourne, he took a wicket with his fifth ball as Hampshire restricted Kent to 268 for nine on the first day of their match in Canterbury.

Warne took two more wickets, held two catches and bowled 28 overs but an unbeaten 92 from the Kent wicketkeeper Paul Nixon denied him an early opportunity to put his feet up. Nixon has added 70 for the last wicket with David Masters.

"Many people thought he was just here for the fast buck, but Shane is a true team man and he wants to help his adopted county fight out of the relegation predicament we find ourselves in," said Hampshire's captain Robin Smith. "It would have been easy for Warnie to have opted out of this one."

It is a match Hampshire must win if they are to have realistic ambitions of staying in the First Division and, in excellent batting conditions, Alan Mullally also undermined Kent's progress. He took five for 67, including the key wicket of Rahul Dravid, who played on for 20. It was the fifth time this season the England bowler has taken five wickets in an innings.

Buskers and beggars might want to hitch a lift to Colwyn Bay this week. The Sussex captain Chris Adams is clearly in a charitable mood; after winning the toss against Glamorgan he put the Welsh county in to bat and watched them amass 457 for one.

Matthew Elliott and Steve James's partnership of 374 was a Glamorgan record for the first wicket. James, who ended the day seven short of a double century, has a clear preference for the Colwyn Bay pitch; he made 259 not out there last year against Nottinghamshire. Elliott's innings of 177 was his fourth championship hundred of the season and his highest score for the county.

"Do we have a spinner who is worth his place?" will doubtless be the main question raised when England's selectors discuss the side for next week's fifth Test at the Oval. Well, there is a left-armer at Middlesex who is still pretty useful. Phil Tufnell squeezed the life out of the Gloucestershire top order on the second day of the match in Bristol, returning figures of three for 16 from 28 overs. For those who have not been paying attention, Tufnell has now taken 57 wickets this season at 22 apiece.

Middlesex have a slight advantage at the halfway stage. Gloucestershire, facing the prospect of batting last, are 50 runs behind with three first-innings wickets left.

In the second Under-19 Test in Northampton, a century from Durham's Nick Peng threatened to put England in a strong position against Sri Lanka but they lost three wickets in the last hour to relinquish control.

webTitle: Habib gets his rebuke in first

fields.headline: Habib gets his rebuke in first
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 362-7 v Lancashire
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText: Resplendent in a sombrero and a shirt designed to rile the Noise Abatement Society, Lewis, self-styled cheerleader at Grace Road, had a lot to say for himself yesterday. So, too, did Chris Schofield.
fields.body:
Resplendent in a sombrero and a shirt designed to rile the Noise Abatement Society, Lewis, self-styled cheerleader at Grace Road, had a lot to say for himself yesterday. So, too, did Chris Schofield.

Whereas the Jamaican was typically longer on passion than intelligibility, The Lancastrian Who Would Be Shane was eloquence personified.

David Graveney is expected here today but his timing may be awry. The objects of his visit, Schofield and Andrew Flintoff, both had solid workouts with the ball, which the chairman of England's selectors will doubtless feel miffed to have missed.

However, having recently admitted that the selectors had been too hasty in discarding Aftab Habib, Graveney may not be greatly displeased to have been absent while the batsman was composing one of those sturdy symphonies that often save his side from ruination. There are more profitable ways of spending a day than having cock-ups rammed down one's throat.

Twenty points here and Lancashire will draw level with Surrey, though from a game more, so Peter Martin's latest mishap was doubly cruel. Having missed two months with a broken left thumb, he spilt a catch in practice and cracked the other.

Initially this was no great hardship. On a firm, bouncy pitch Glen Chapple filled the breach and swiftly trapped Iain Sutcliffe. Ben Smith, leading the hosts in place of the injured Vince Wells, parried Mike Smethurst to short leg and, when Flintoff steamed in to eject the Darrens, Maddy and Stevens, in the same over, the latter gobsmacked by Mark Chilton's grab at midwicket, Habib was again manning the burning deck.

Jon Dakin, who looks like a misplaced Viking and could probably row a longship on his own, drove ruggedly in a stand of 97 before misreading Schofield's googly.

As usual the leg-spinner had come on well after his fellow twirler Gary Keedy, which makes sense only to those easily seduced by averages. Though Keedy has taken twice as many wickets this term, he has also bowled twice as many overs in one match fewer. Schofield, moreover, boasts a superior strike rate. Do we detect a separate agenda here?

After 68 overs of stylish vigilance Habib hoicked Schofield to midwicket where Mike Atherton took a terrific running catch; and Neil Burns soon played on sweeping at Schofield.

By now, though, Phil DeFreitas was in full flow, a straight six off Keedy a reminder of the power of the original Man Who Would Be Botham. Lewis looked as if he was willing to give him the shirt off his back. But dear old Daffy is not that daft.

webTitle: Dean helps Durham go with the swing

fields.headline: Dean helps Durham go with the swing
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 167 & 0-0
Durham 144
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 167 & 0-0
Durham 144
fields.body:
Derbyshire have still not fully recovered from being docked eight points for the pitch on which they beat Surrey in June, so there must have been a few nervous glances in the direction of A C Smith, the pitch liaison officer, as 20 wickets fell yesterday.

But there really was nothing to worry about. It was a combination of good swing bowling, particularly from the left-armers Simon Brown and Kevin Dean, and rank bad batting by two counties for whom that is not a rare phenomenon. Smith left at tea.

Derbyshire were put in and failed to reach 200 in their first innings for the eighth time in 14 championship matches but still ended the day with a narrow advantage. Steve Stubbings, Michael Di Venuto - who after a successful season with Sussex is finding life at Derby more of a struggle - and Luke Sutton were undone by Brown's opening burst of 8-3-22-3.

Surprisingly the 31-year-old did not add another wicket, but he had already gone past 50 first-class victims for the seventh of Durham's nine seasons in the championship.

Melvyn Betts and Steve Harmison did the rest of the damage, although there was little sign of that as Dominic Cork savaged Harmison before lunch. Derbyshire's captain hit 45 from 53 balls with nine fours, and Harmison retreated from the attack having conceded 39 from six overs.

But soon after the interval Cork became the second of Betts's three victims, nibbling at a wide one, and Harmison returned to pick up two late wickets and end with three for 42, his best performance since May in a season that started with an England call-up but has been interrupted by shin problems.

Perhaps the best comment on the Derbyshire batting was provided by the veteran Rob Bailey, who by applying himself watchfully moved comfortably enough to a 105-ball half-century, then for some reason left a straight ball from Paul Collingwood.

That last affliction was catching: by the eighth over of Durham's reply Jon Lewis and Michael Gough had gone, shouldering arms to Dean's in-swing, and when Collingwood was trapped lbw first ball the visitors were 20 for three.

They recovered slightly as Simon Katich, an Australian who has had a much more productive summer than Di Venuto, followed Bailey's example. Katich played a couple of wristy midwicket whips but was otherwise tied down by Tim Munton, who eventually had him caught behind for 38 and also took a wonderful second-slip catch to dismiss Jimmy Daley.

Dean then returned to complete figures of six for 52 to follow his six for 51 at the Oval last week and eight for 52 at Canterbury two innings before that. Derbyshire may already be as good as relegated, but they could still drag Durham down with them.

webTitle: Liptrot tips up to take five

fields.headline: Liptrot tips up to take five
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 338
Warwickshire 140-8
County Championship Second Division points table
fields.trailText: Warwickshire must have imagined they had pulled off a double whammy when they reached the NatWest final. Not only had they a Lord's date to relish, but they had also neatly sidestepped a confrontation with the most dangerous fast bowler in the world.
fields.body:
Warwickshire must have imagined they had pulled off a double whammy when they reached the NatWest final. Not only had they a Lord's date to relish, but they had also neatly sidestepped a confrontation with the most dangerous fast bowler in the world.

The Lord's final dictated that this crucial promotion derby had to be brought forward 24 hours, so scuppering Worcestershire's intention that Glenn McGrath could fly back in time from Australia's indoor series against South Africa.

Spared the McGrath gallop, Warwickshire were undone instead by the Liptrot. Chris Liptrot, called up in McGrath's absence for his first championship match of the season, breached the top order with three new-ball wickets and may have irreparably damaged their promotion prospects as a consequence.

McGrath had popped in for a social call as Liptrot, a 19-year-old Lancastrian, took three afternoon wickets in 10 balls: Mark Wagh leg-before, Anurag Singh clutched by Graeme Hick at slip, and David Hemp falling at short leg.

When Trevor Penney, whose batting rarely approaches the brilliance of his fielding, fell leg-before to Alamgir Sheriyar, McGrath was able to go and doze away his jet lag without many fears that his absence would prove costly.

Only Michael Powell organised much resistance. With Nick Knight absent with knee trouble, his 75 was the sole source of substance in a vulnerable batting side.

Liptrot's final raid, in two overs before the close, when he had Powell caught at the wicket and then bowled Keith Piper, left him with five for 43 and virtually extinguished Warwickshire's hopes of scrambling a further 49 runs this morning to avoid a follow-on.

Things are obviously not going to plan when even the mid-pitch glove punch - which has long since superseded "good luck, old boy" - proves fallible. Dougie Brown cover-drove Stuart Lampitt, exchanged punches with Powell with equal conviction to pronounce that a recovery was under way, and then fended the next delivery weakly to Paul Pollard at second slip.

Worcestershire had showed more resolve with the bat. They added 107 to their overnight 231 for five, with Vikram Solanki advancing to 160 before Brown had him caught at mid-off.

Suddenly Solanki is within touching distance of 1,000 first-class runs, which this summer has been achieved only by Mark Ramprakash among English batsmen. To retain the mood would have a considerable impact upon Worcestershire's promotion challenge. Even if England are temporarily looking elsewhere, there is plenty to occupy him.

webTitle: Rough sleepers are only the tip of the iceberg

fields.headline: Rough sleepers are only the tip of the iceberg
fields.standfirst: While the reduction in rough sleeping is to be celebrated, it shouldn't be the only focus of the fight to eradicate homelessness, writes Val Chinn, chief executive of the Big Issue in the North trust
fields.trailText: While the reduction in rough sleeping is to be celebrated, it shouldn't be the only focus of the fight to eradicate homelessness, writes Val Chinn, chief executive of the Big Issue in the North trust
fields.body:
The announcement that rough sleeping has been cut by a third is, on the face of it, very good news and a clear demonstration that the government's approach is working. However, it's notoriously difficult to count rough sleepers, so while undoubtedly progress is being made, it's probably a mistake to rely too much on the figures that have been released.

In our experience in the north, rough sleepers are not a single group of people who sleep rough for months on end. Our research amongst vendors shows that while just 14% of them had slept rough the previous night they were questioned, 75% had slept rough at some point during the year.

Rough sleepers form part of the wider problem of homelessness, which covers people staying in temporary and unstable accommodation, such as squats, hostels, bed and breakfasts or sleeping on friend's floors. It's a mistake to believe that just focusing on rough sleeping will really end homelessness ­ it just deals with it's most visible aspect and means that politicians no longer need to step over homeless people on their way to the theatre.

All too often, individuals who are moved from the streets into temporary and even permanent accommodation are back on the streets a few months later. Temporary forms of accommodation, especially hostels, are often viewed as no better than sleeping rough. And without the necessary resources or skills, many long-term homeless people simply can't make a go of a permanent tenancy.

There's still a long way to go to solve the problem of homelessness. Moving people off the streets into hostels and short-term accommodation is not enough. At the Big Issue in the North, we work to move homeless people - including those who sleep rough - away from the streets and into good homes, good jobs, good health and a good life - permanently.

We do this by adopting a wide-ranging approach which looks at the needs of each vendor and provides them with practical advice, personal development opportunities, employment training and, crucially, ongoing support through the process of becoming rehoused.

Our approach works. During the last 12 months, across the north of England, we have helped one of our vendors every week back into permanent accommodation and one vendor every 9 days back into employment.

In the 12 months since it was established, the rough sleepers unit has demonstrated the government's commitment to a new approach to tackling homelessness. They are working with a wide range of organisations from the public and voluntary sectors, who have first-hand experience of the problems - and frontline inspiration for the solutions.

However, it's notoriously difficult to count rough sleepers, so while undoubtedly progress is being made, it's probably a mistake to rely too much on the figures that have been released. In our experience in the north, rough sleepers are not a single group of people who sleep rough for months on end. Our research amongst vendors shows that while just 14% of them had slept rough the previous night they were questioned, 75% had slept rough at some point during the year.
