fields.headline: A lack of trust
fields.standfirst:
Fear of paedophiles is at an all-time high and all men, however good they are with children, are being treated with some degree of suspicion, says James Talbot

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Fear of paedophiles is at an all-time high and all men, however good they are with children, are being treated with some degree of suspicion, says James Talbot.
fields.body:
As heroic deeds go, it didn't amount to much. My pre-school daughter and I were waiting for the playgroup to open when there was a disturbance at the front of the queue. A mother had been taken ill. Worse, it was her turn to do mother's duty that day. By the time it was realised that she needed to be taken home the other mothers had gone, and the staff were desperate for a volunteer. Why not me?

As a lecturer with no classes that day, I had time. I offered, and there was consternation. A man had never done mother's duty before. But they had no choice so, for an hour, a father helped out. That was as long as it took before a mother could be found to relieve me.

Anyway, the mould was broken. A man had done play-school duty and after that I did it regularly. So did others: Ben, a fireman on shifts. And 19-year-old Matthew, from Manchester, who had come down to stay with his uncle to escape unemployment. He quickly became the idol of the local girls with his big city ways. The mothers loved him too, for with no money he was always ready to do one of their volunteer duties for a couple of quid.

And the kids appreciated it. Against a fireman and the local Romeo, a young lecturer didn't count for much but we were all men in a previously female world.

But how many of us are there today? Would any of us do it again? And are we wanted? For the finger of suspicion is out. That playgroup has gone but the new one still needs volunteers. They are usually women.

The rules are strict. The Children's Act, they tell the volunteers, insists that only full-timers take the children to the loo. It doesn't, of course, but that is not the point. It's easier that way.

The discomfort I feel is real and I am not alone. Taking my son and his friends to a local water park we are drawn to the rapids where powerful jets throw you around in a jumble of bodies. It's all right to be there with your children but do you go in alone?

I look around. This is a macho place for men to bring their kids. The men are up there on the water slides, hanging from the swinging ropes, showing off to one another - their kids playing somewhere else. But in the rapids with its jumble of bodies there are no men on their own.

Jeffrey, a student of mine, is a pensioner whose wife died some time ago and now he is looking forward to the summer. His granddaughter is coming to stay for the first time. "It's OK," he says. "Her mother trusts her with me, I'm her grandfather." It seems best not to offend his dignity by asking what he means. The meaning is clear in that phrase, "I'm her grandfather."

Henry is not so savvy. He is in his early 80s and walks with difficulty. His delight is to sit outside his house on a warm day and tease the local primary school children on their way home, and offer them sweets. Not all of them like it but Henry is well known in the street. He is less well known in the centre of town to which he can sometimes struggle.

In the newsagent I see him teasing an adolescent girl from a nearby street. "Dirty old man," a young mother says under her breath as she pays for her newspaper. Then, to her horror, Henry turns and offers her young daughter a sweet. As the child's hand reaches out the mother pulls it away. "I've told you not to take anything from strangers," she yells. Henry stands there looking bewildered. The middle-aged shop assistant who knows him well calls out: "It's Henry, he won't hurt her." But it's too late. The child, now crying, is dragged out of the door.

My sister-in-law tells me about a young male trainee primary school teacher - a diminishing breed. He has to take a class to swimming lessons and is talking about getting in the pool with them. But she and the other women teachers are advising him against it. Don't put yourself in that position, she says. But just by wanting to work with primary school children he is vulnerable to gossip.

I have seen it with Paul. He teaches at the local primary school where he is one of two male staff. The other is the head. To be a man and a head is OK - it's what you are there for and, in any case, he is married. But Paul is not and he is middle-aged. He is not the greatest teacher but the kids love him. They are desperate to be in his class. Mine were. And most of the parents like him too.

But for some there is that question: why does a man want to spend his life working with very young children? I hope that he never hears their malicious gossip but he is experienced. He probably understands and he knows the situations to avoid.

Not so John, he has to learn. His wife is about to give birth and he is talking to Steve. They are both middle class, both in education. Steve is young, too, but already has three children aged 10, six and two. Does he feel any different about being a father today? He is, he says, much more conscious of the way he behaves with the youngest than he was with the eldest. "Do you do things like have a bath with them?" asks John. "I used to," says Steve.

Then there's the moment when you're on the beach and you see a small child running across it crying and obviously lost. No one else seems to notice but you do. What do you do? You know the stereotype. The child is crying and somewhere there is a frantic mother and perhaps an angry father panicking over whether the child is lost or been taken.

It would be so easy to take the child by the hand and guide it back to safety. But you are a man alone, half-undressed on a lonely beach. Do you get up and risk it or do you close your ears? Do you let someone else solve the problem? Would that be so wrong? As the moral panic grows, men are voting with their feet. It's not something that is often talked about. There is no need. It is there in the nuance of the conversation, in the inaction, in the distance you keep. It's simpler that way. No misunderstandings. Let the women do it - it's their work.

webTitle: No need for kiddy summer activities

fields.headline: Let them amuse themselves
fields.standfirst: Worn out by ferrying your children from one summer activity to another? Don't bother. They can make their own fun, says  Julie Myerson
fields.trailText: Worn out by ferrying your children from one summer activity to another? Don't bother. They can make their own fun, says Julie Myerson.
fields.body:
A long, wet Tuesday afternoon in August. My three children have been blissfully quiet for hours - so quiet that I've been able to think and work without a break.

Twenty minutes ago, Raphael, eight, crept downstairs and whispered to me that he wanted to cut up some cubes of cheddar and stick them on cocktail sticks. "Sure," I muttered without really looking up from my screen. "Careful with the knife." Now, music wails and judders from the crackly old Early Learning Centre cassette player up in the playroom - Abba, Chitty Chitty Bang Bang and Batman by Prince.

When I finally poke my head round the door, hot bordello darkness greets me. Toy boxes have been stacked to create a kind of dance floor, in the middle of which, beneath the harsh spotlight of an Anglepoise, a penguin and a gorilla hold hands stiffly as Prince rasps his pelvic lyrics. Behind them, an Alsatian with a bored expression sits on an upturned yellow plastic Lego bucket, three mini cans of Coca-Cola arranged in front of him. Bumford, his teddy bear sidekick, flops forlornly in front of the hacked-up cheese.

"Shh, it's a cuddly toy disco!" the children hiss, frowning at me from the greenish gloom. "Go away, mummy."

"Bumford's not going to get his eye poked out with a cocktail stick, is he?"

"No!" they shriek, intensely excited by the mere suggestion.

"I hope the animals aren't getting drunk."

More shrieks. "They are! They are! And they're sexing!"

I close the door. I don't need to hear any more. At least someone's having a wild time on this damp Tuesday afternoon. It seems to me that this is the best sort of game - unsupervised by adults, not bought or got from a box, unbreakable, highly charged, funny, slightly naughty, meticulously and deliciously imaginative.

This summer holiday is our first without any paid childcare whatsoever. We're lucky. Though my partner and I work hard, our work is flexible and we do it from home. Our children have finally reached ages - 11, nine and eight - when constant supervision isn't necessary. As long as someone is in the house - to feed, administer First Aid, sort out rows - we can let them get on with it.

My friend Katie was unnerved when I told her the plan: "But what ... no outings?"

"We've been on holiday," I said, "Now they can play."

She looked at me as if "play" meant burying your kids up to the neck in sand. "What will they do all day?"

"Play," I said again. "Hang out."

"But what about stimulation? Exercise?"

"We walk the dog on the common," I told her, but you could see that she didn't like it. You could see that she thought we were failing our children in some vital, terrible way. Her four (even the youngest, who is barely five) all do courses. Violin, judo, pottery, tap-dancing, pond-dipping. The rest of the time, they're strapped into the Peugeot (French song tape playing, of course), since the courses are all some distance from each other and finish at different times. Last week when she called in for tea having collected all but the last child, she admitted she was exhausted. "I'll be glad when the holidays are over," she sighed, "Still, at least they're not bored."

I don't get it. I love the holidays precisely because there's nothing to do. As my three chuck their ratty grey uniforms in the laundry basket at the end of term, you can almost see their little bodies sigh and relax. No more schedules or structure. What are today's parents so scared of? Why do they feel that they are failing their kids if they don't provide them with a minute-by-minute, fun-packed itinerary? What's wrong with not knowing what's going to happen next? Don't the best fun and games come about when you just let time go baggy on you?

Come to that, what's wrong with doing nothing? How, if you have a kit for this and a course for that, will you ever have an original idea of your own? Would the Brontës have been so creative if they'd been strapped into a Volvo for half the day going to music and movement classes?

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Every month in the US you hear about a new and improved fad that parents foist upon their children, hoping to turn them into Einstein meets Bill Gates.
fields.body:
Every month in the US you hear about a new and improved fad that parents foist upon their children, hoping to turn them into Einstein meets Bill Gates: reading them Ronald Reagan's biography instead of fairy-tales; teaching them Latin; creating a website for a three-year-old so he can develop himself as a "brand". But that is nothing compared to the latest manifestation of parental ambition - American children with British manners. That is, kids who say how-do-you-do?, not howya doin'?, please and thank you, and curl their pinkies as they sip tea (pot, not bag).

In California, land of sun, sand and instant gratification, British expatriate Ruth Davies-Brady, 32, is ready and willing to help. Davies-Brady, who lives in Orange County outside Los Angeles, holds combination tea party and etiquette classes for children, with an emphasis on English table manners and tea-taking.

At a cost of $10.95 per child for finger sandwiches, chocolate chip scones and miniature cakes, all served on English bone china, and $100 for the etiquette lesson, Davies-Brady (who also hosts tea parties for adults) is taking potential American brats and turning them into little English lords and ladies. As her business has doubled in size since last year, it seems Americans, who believe upward mobility cannot be complete without good manners, can't get enough of it.

At each tea party, either Davies-Brady, who is from Surrey, or her mother Elizabeth dress up as "the duchess", while the children, usually girls aged five to 12, learn proper table manners. "We take them through every step. We show them how to shake out a napkin and put it on their laps and explain that they should not reach across the table but ask their neighbour, politely, to pass the sugar. We make them sit up straight and tell them not to chew with their mouths open. And we explain why. It's a very relaxed atmosphere and the kids love it. They really get into it."

American children do not have terrible manners - they are just more casual socially than their British counterparts.

Davies-Brady admits that some parents simply like the novelty value of what she has to offer but most are desperate to instil little Brittany or Billy Bob with a touch of class, hoping it will give them the social edge in later life.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Are single-sex classes in schools a good idea?
fields.trailText: The Question: Are single-sex classes in schools a good idea?
fields.body:
John Fairhurst Headmaster, Shenfield High School, Essex

We introduced single-sex classes in 1994 and our exam results have improved at a higher rate than the national average. The initiative was introduced to combat the negative effects of laddish culture, but we're finding that the girls, being more mature, are exploiting the opportunity more. We divide pupils in every academic subject in years seven, eight and nine, and what we've found is that our teachers naturally adapt the lessons to suit the different classes. It's hard to do a study, but we know it's working. I'm not saying it's a panacea, but it does make sense.
Verdict: Yes

David Hart General Secretary, National Association of Headteachers

Most heads I speak to are not convinced by single-sex classes. We shouldn't rush into thinking they're the answer to the problems of "laddish culture". It's true that it has undoubtedly affected academic results in the 10 to 14 age range, but it's not confined to school, it develops in the home, in the community and within peer groups outside school. We are taking steps to deal with it in schools - things like the primary literacy strategy and homework clubs for boys, but it's not the whole answer, it's much more deeply rooted than that.
Verdict: No

Terri Apter Social psychologist, University of Cambridge

Anxiety over performance makes children do less well than when concentrating solely on the task. When there are no boys in class, girls may still feel that their appearance is being monitored, but they don't tend to feel concerned about looking dumb - like they do with boys. Research shows that girls benefit most from single-sex classes, but we're finding now that boys also benefit. There is less of a "laddish" culture in boys-only schools. One school reported this week that they've introduced single-sex classes and the boys are doing better.
Verdict: Yes

Christopher Hesse An 18-year-old who has just finished A-levels

Being in single-sex classes would not be conducive to better learning. At A-level and GCSE we're mature enough to mix, and it gives us a wider range of opinions. Laddish culture is partly to blame for boys not doing so well, but it's mostly laziness. People who do well tend to have big plans and just go for it - it's not really a boy/girl issue. Perhaps girls are more motivated because of the glass ceiling, feeling that they have to do better to prove themselves. On the whole, though, I think pupils should be seen as individuals rather than boys or girls.
Verdict: No

Wendy Elms Mother of four children aged nine, 12, 14 and 16

Both my teenage girls are at a single-sex grammar school, which I definitely think is best. Boys hamper girls' progress. I was at a mixed comprehensive myself - if I'd been at an all-girls' school I'd have done better, because I paid attention to the boys. If you're really focused and academic then you can do well in a bad school, and if you're really not interested then you can still do badly in a good school, but those of us in the middle, we can easily be swayed and influenced. Boys on their own will still mess around, but it cuts out the showing off in front of the girls.
Verdict: Yes

Alan Smithers Education research centre, Liverpool University

There's no strong academic evidence to show that children do better in mixed or separate classes. When single-sex education was the norm, people started pressing for coeducation and claimed it had all sorts of hard-to-prove advantages - now it's the other way around. I think that when single-sex classes are first introduced there's an initial boost in learning because students feel they're getting special teaching, but the novelty wears off. What parents think is crucial - if they feel their children will do best in single-sex classes, they should choose a school accordingly.
Verdict: No

fields.headline: All's right with the world. Well, nearly
fields.standfirst: Home and away:  The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: Home and away: The diary of a part-time father.
fields.body:
I have become extremely calm. I am a sea of serenity. I am pacific on an oceanic scale. Gloria, Jed and Billy have come back from their extravagant continental holiday with their mother Dilys and, of course, Chris the Pillock, the man with the meaningless IT consultancy, the Ernest Hemingway bush shorts and the mystic soul connection with his own internal depths (the bowel movement as poetry: discuss).

They have tumbled through the front door to be kissed and climbed upon by their half-sister Estelle, embraced by their stepmother, Angie, and quietly waited for by their part-time father - me.

Yes: waited for, quietly, in the wings. It is now nearly five years since Dilys's departure. In that time I have learned how best to cope with my three eldest children's return after three summer weeks, the longest stretch they are ever away from me.

When they depart I am raw with resentment. But gradually I get a grip. I cease being ambushed by bleak reveries about burning aircraft wreckage, or terrible speculation about sudden maternal death. By the time the children reappear I have raised myself above the emotional fray.

I cultivate this frame of mind because the children need it. Like divers surfacing after a long spell in the deep, a period of decompression is required. They don't need too many questions, too much close investigation by me. The story of their time away will seep out soon enough: the improving activities devised for them by Chris, the swooning approval lavished on these by Dilys.

I know better than to hope that they will tell me that they've missed me. Instead, I have learned to be ready for the moments when they give themselves away: a wry aside from Gloria; Jed and Billy imperceptibly edging closer on the sofa until their heads rest on my ribs.

As always, it was Angie who extracted the first nuggets of information and Gloria who let them slip. Later, in our bedroom, Angie and I inspected these fragments of intelligence for signs of burgeoning skulduggery by the "other parents" or shifts in the dynamics of the children's "other home".

This year, the insights are especially intriguing. "They had a row," Angie whispered. "Dilys got fed up with him not helping in the kitchen and Chris flounced off. He was gone all afternoon!" Silently, I war-danced with delight.

"But the best thing," said Angie, "is that on the last evening a Spanish boy asked Gloria out!"

I burst directly into song: "Shoo-bee-doo-bee-doo, shoo-ba-ba-dee-dah . . ."

"That's enough Sinatra," Angie hissed.

"Quite right," I conceded. "But who was this spotty stranger in the night?"

"Juan," Angie replied. "He's 14. He bought her a Coke in a cafe, and he kissed her on the cheek."

"Blimey. She's only 12."

"Looks older, though."

And so she does. Bodily at least, she seems to be taking adolescence in her stride. Her skin is fresh, her smile bright, her shape already more that of a young woman than a girl. Meanwhile, Angie has seen to it that her bottom drawer contains what Gloria will need when her first period starts.

W atching her, talking to her, I find I am in the presence of an adult-in-the-making. With this metamorphosis, glimpses of our old empathy return.

I write this from our own holiday location: a raggedy bit of Little England-on-Sea. We work hard on these vacations to cement the bonds of our blended family. Jed had his ninth birthday while he was away, Angie her 37th just the day before. Their belated joint celebration under an unfamiliar roof is now an annual event: separate presents, but a shared cake, all deeply symbolic.

An evening or two later, Gloria and I went walking on the beach under the moonlight. I made no mention of Juan's advances or Chris the Pillock's tantrum. But I did ask some advice about her mum. "Should I write her a nice letter? Maybe try to find a way of getting on a little better?"

Gloria nodded: "It might be worth a try."

"Should I tell her I still love her and can no longer live without her?"

Risky. But I was on a roll. "Why don't you just suggest running away together?"

Such sarcasm! I like Gloria best when she reminds me of me.

"OK," I agreed. "I'll write to her as soon as we get home."

webTitle: Branson must wait for lottery prize

fields.headline: Branson must wait for lottery prize
fields.standfirst:
Commissioners withhold new lottery licence for now but holds out hope for People's Lottery bid
Lottery Commission: Full statement
NetNotes: the lottery
fields.trailText: The Lottery commission today stunned observers by saying it could not award the national lottery to either Camelot, the current organiser, or Sir Richard Branson's rival bid, the People's Lottery.
fields.body:
The Lottery commission today stunned observers by saying it could not award the national lottery to either Camelot, the current organiser, or Sir Richard Branson's rival bid, the People's Lottery.

However, the commission chair, Dame Helena Shovelton, said the licence would be given to the People's Lottery if within a month it came up with a system that would protect "all players, all the time". As for Camelot, Dame Helena said the commission's confidence had been shaken by software problems and "propriety issues" related to lottery equipment supplied by Gtech.

MPs have questioned GTech's fitness to be involved in running the lottery amid allegations about the way the firm obtained lottery licences in the US.

The People's Lottery has pledged to create 2,500 new millionaires and raise more than £15bn - the entire profits - for good causes. The game under Virgin tycoon Sir Richard would require participants to select six balls out of 53 instead of the present 49, meaning there would be fewer winners but bigger prizes.

Sir Richard has fought hard for Camelot's prize. Despite being newly knighted for "services to entrepreneurship" and worth an estimated £2.4bn, running the lottery has remained his overriding ambition. Today's announcement makes it likely that he will claim the lottery licence, provided his team can meet the commission's concerns.

Camelot had pledged to cut the salaries and bonuses paid to directors and give a greater share of its profits to good causes amid criticism of its "fat-cat" payments to top executives. Had it secured a second term as National Lottery operator, it said it would have given more than £15bn to good causes.

Camelot's failed bid also included at least four new online games, investigation of the possibility of an international lottery, and a £1bn investment in technology to allow people to play via the internet, mobile phones and interactive television by 2002.

Before today's announcement, the Right Rev Richard Harris, Bishop of Oxford and chairman of the church's board of social responsibility, criticised the lottery for creating a fantasy world of escape for many of Britain's poorest people.

"The very fact that we have a lottery, I think, is a sign of social malaise - the fact that things in our society are not as they ought to be," he said. I think it distracts us from facing up to the kind of society we have now and the kind of society we ought to have."

In a year when pay for Britain's top executives went up by 16% while the number of people living in poverty grew, society needed to take stock and re-evaluate its priorities, Bishop Harris went on.

The bishop added that he would like the lottery to be scrapped, but if that was not possible the operators should give more prizes of a lower value rather than huge single-win rollover jackpots.

As for Camelot, Dame Helena said the commission's confidence had been shaken by software problems and "propriety issues" related to lottery equipment supplied by Gtech. MPs have questioned GTech's fitness to be involved in running the lottery amid allegations about the way the firm obtained lottery licences in the US. The People's Lottery has pledged to create 2,500 new millionaires and raise more than £15bn - the entire profits - for good causes. The game under Virgin tycoon Sir Richard would require participants to select six balls out of 53 instead of the present 49, meaning there would be fewer winners but bigger prizes. Sir Richard has fought hard for Camelot's prize. Despite being newly knighted for "services to entrepreneurship" and worth an estimated £2.4bn, running the lottery has remained his overriding ambition. Today's announcement makes it likely that he will claim the lottery licence, provided his team can meet the commission's concerns. Camelot had pledged to cut the salaries and bonuses paid to directors and give a greater share of its profits to good causes amid criticism of its "fat-cat" payments to top executives. Had it secured a second term as National Lottery operator, it said it would have given more than £15bn to good causes. Camelot's failed bid also included at least four new online games, investigation of the possibility of an international lottery, and a £1bn investment in technology to allow people to play via the internet, mobile phones and interactive television by 2002. Before today's announcement, the Right Rev Richard Harris, Bishop of Oxford and chairman of the church's board of social responsibility, criticised the lottery for creating a fantasy world of escape for many of Britain's poorest people. "The very fact that we have a lottery, I think, is a sign of social malaise - the fact that things in our society are not as they ought to be," he said. I think it distracts us from facing up to the kind of society we have now and the kind of society we ought to have." In a year when pay for Britain's top executives went up by 16% while the number of people living in poverty grew, society needed to take stock and re-evaluate its priorities, Bishop Harris went on. The bishop added that he would like the lottery to be scrapped, but if that was not possible the operators should give more prizes of a lower value rather than huge single-win rollover jackpots. fields.headline: Branson's day of reckoning
fields.standfirst:
Virgin boss won't go quietly if he loses second fight to run lottery
Bidding for the big prize
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson was the first man to fly across the Atlantic in a hot air balloon and held the Blue Riband for the fastest crossing in a boat, but last night he was struggling to get one of his own jumbo jets off the ground and make it to the most important business meeting of his life.
fields.byline: John Cassy, David Teather and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson was the first man to fly across the Atlantic in a hot air balloon and held the Blue Riband for the fastest crossing in a boat, but last night he was struggling to get one of his own jumbo jets off the ground and make it to the most important business meeting of his life.

Britain's best-known businessman was on his private Caribbean island of Necker, battling to avoid hurricane Debby and catch his Virgin Atlantic flight back to England in time for the award of the licence to operate the national lottery for the next seven years.

Today's announcement at 1pm will end six months of secret deliberations by the Lottery Commission and is likely to be greeted by another storm, this time of the publicity kind.

Sir Richard has fought bitterly for Camelot's crown. Despite being newly knighted for "services to entrepreneurship" and worth an estimated £2.4bn, running the lottery has remained his most passionate ambition. Last time round his bid ended in acrimony with accusations of bribery, and if defeat hits him a second time, he is unlikely to take it well.

Passionate

Six years ago Sir Richard emerged heartbroken from his Holland Park home after pulling a note off his office fax machine announcing that he'd failed. "I've lost the chance to do the most important thing in my lifetime," he complained.

This time the worst he will be is runner-up. Then the rushed bid was judged fourth out of eight by the National Audit Office; this time Camelot is the only rival.

If he loses today, Sir Richard will be desperately disappointed. "Richard wants to win the lottery more than anything else in the world," said one Virgin insider. "He was devastated when his last bid failed and passionately wants to run an organisation which could give so much to so many good causes and have a huge impact on people's lives."

Some say he also sees it as opportunity to settle an old score. Shortly after losing in 1994 he alleged he was offered a bribe to withdraw his rival bid by Guy Snowden, chairman of GTech, which was part of the Camelot consortium.

Sir Richard won the libel action that resulted from the allegation and had the decision upheld in the court of appeal. Only British Airways' infamous "dirty tricks" campaign against Virgin Atlantic has riled him more.

Sir Richard has promised not to make a penny from the lottery and says it will operate entirely independently of the Virgin Group. He wants to create a millionaire a day and raise billions for good causes.

Critics, including Camelot, say that some of the firms involved in the consortium will make money by providing services to the non-profit making venture. Sir Richard's people reply that they must offer "best value", charging low prices to avoid fat cattery charges.

Sir Richard and his aides are sensitive to suggestions that Virgin will benefit from the lottery and the enormous publicity it will bring him.

The billionaire has already fired off a writ to author Tom Bower after the journalist claimed "that sceptics will inevitably whisper that Branson's motive is self-glorification". It is an allegation that Sir Richard strenuously denies.

Advisers stress that it is not a Virgin company and he is only one of seven directors that include Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, and Caroline Marland, the outgoing managing director of Guardian Newspapers.

Yet Sir Richard is the People's Lottery Holding Company's sole shareholder, driving force and very public face. When the bid was launched to the press earlier in the year, he greeted every journalist personally, shaking them warmly by the hand.

Yet the bid to run the lottery comes at a time when Sir Richard's sprawling business empire is under more scrutiny than ever. Virgin Atlantic, his flagship, is likely to see its profits halve this year, while ventures into clothing, soft drinks and cosmetics have hardly been conspicuous successes.

Half of the airline was recently sold to raise cash for his loss-making record business and fund his new mobile phone and internet business.

Despite these setbacks, Sir Richard has called in some of biggest names in business names to back his bid. Microsoft's Bill Gates, an occasional neighbour in Holland Park, flew to the UK earlier in the year to tell Sir David Frost and a nationwide television audience why he was joining the People's campaign. Giant US internet services company Cisco has given its support.

They go head to head with a Camelot team with six years experience of running a UK national lottery.

Camelot has not been without its critics. Questions have been asked about excess profits of as much as £70m a year, directors' bonuses and the way money was distributed to good causes. Then lottery regulator Peter David walked into a storm of criticism for accepting hospitality and free trips in a private jet owned by GTech.

MPs have also questioned GTech's fitness to be involved in running the lottery amid allegations about the way the firm obtained lottery licences in the US. Earlier in the summer two top executives at GTech resigned following a sharp fall in the US firm's share price.

Camelot directors have had to fight "fat-cat" allegations of after bonus payments raised their salaries by 40%.

Despite this, Camelot insists it runs the most successful lottery in the world. It has sold tickets worth more than £28bn and given £8.8bn to good causes.

In many ways the People's Lottery is typical Branson. He has pitched himself as the consumer champion taking on the incumbent operator that has grown rich without strong competition. It is much the same approach he used when launching Virgin Atlantic, Virgin Cola, Virgin Mobile and any number of other Virgin companies.

Opinions on who will emerge victorious today are split. Some in government are thought to want to see a change and that the three month delay to the announcement is partly to do with giving the voter-friendly Sir Richard every chance to get his bid in order.

Others believe that the criticism heaped upon Camelot has persuaded it to clean up its act and for the commission it could be a case of better the devil they know.

fields.headline: Unmetered net access
fields.standfirst: Following the announcement by the Californian firm AltaVista that it is  indefinitely postponing its pledge to provide free internet access in the UK, Chris Alden looks at the demise of the 'free' net revolution
fields.trailText:
Following the announcement by the Californian firm AltaVista that it is
indefinitely postponing its pledge to provide free internet access in the UK, we look at the demise of the "free" net revolution.
fields.body:
What is AltaVista?
AltaVista is one of the best-known internet search engines, which allows users to find information on any topic in a page on the web, either worldwide or in the UK. Like other engines, AltaVista has branched out by turning itself into a portal, with a web directory and content of its own. Becoming an internet service provider (ISP) is a key extension of this strategy.

What did AltaVista promise its users regarding internet access?
In March, AltaVista offered free and unlimited access to the web in the UK, for an initial annual fee of £60. Once the fee was paid, AltaVista was to give users a connection to a freephone number for internet use. The scheme attracted widespread coverage - not least because the US has had unmetered internet access for some years, and consequently a far higher rate of internet use. Some 274,000 customers, attracted by the savings they could make compared to their local call charges, pre-registered - and the excitement generated even prompted Tony Blair to hail the uptake as the advent of the "internet for the people".

What happened next?
Delays are commonplace in the wired world, so it surprised few people that it took until July for AltaVista to claim that the service was "up and running" in a "controlled roll-out". Even when other free deals reported difficulties, AltaVista kept quiet. But, after an appeal by online magazine The Register which turned up no customers at all, the company announced it was suspending its offer - and Andy Mitchell, managing director of AltaVista UK, has been forced to admit that it had in fact been put on hold "a few weeks ago".

So what went wrong?
That depends on whom you ask. AltaVista is blaming BT. The background to this is that the telecoms regulator, Oftel, directed BT in May to make wholesale unmetered internet access (or "Friaco") available to ISPs such as AltaVista. This would allow AltaVista to buy circuits both between the exchange and the end user, and between itself and the wider internet, at a capped, unmetered rate. But a deal for such an unmetered rate has not yet been hammered out - and until then, ISPs would effectively be paying users' phone bills themselves. But AltaVista has been rightly berated by industry commentators for making promises it couldn't keep; BT was likely to be sluggish, they say. In addition, Oftel has criticised AltaVista because the ISP had announced the launch of its new service in March, two months before wholesale unmetered access by BT was to be made available.

What is happening to those who pre-registered?
AltaVista is advising them to opt for one of its other offers - which either restrict how long users can stay online, or ask them to pay their telephone charges.

So what is the future for free net access in the UK?
Until a deal has been hammered out between BT and the ISPs, there will continue to be problems. Of 20 players in the market, four - CallNet 0800, Virgin, LineOne and AltaVista - have cancelled or suspended their service, while Breathe has banned 500 of its highest-use customers. Meanwhile, there is always BT Surftime, which offers unlimited access for £20 a month or £6 for evenings and weekends. But this offer has been taken up by only four ISPs - Freeserve, BT Internet, BT Click and PlusNet - and BT has already been ordered by Oftel to provide a satisfactory alternative. Watch this space...

The AltaVista statement issued last night
AltaVista's original announcement
Campaign for Unmetered Telecommunications
ZDNet UK's unmetered access guide
Heavy surfers pay the price
Leader comment: Absolutely remiss

fields.headline: Loved to death
fields.standfirst: John Park has co-written a play about how the pressures on parents of autistic children can push them to extremes
fields.trailText: John Park has co-written a play about how the pressures on parents of autistic children can push them to extremes.
fields.body:
A million parents in Britain have a lifelong responsibility for autistic people. What happens when the strain gets too much? The National Autistic Association (NAS) estimates that 518,000 people in Britain may be affected by autistic spectrum disorders. Many, perhaps most, of the 403,000 with IQs over 70, will become semi- or fully independent as adults, but need understanding and help as children, according to the NAS. Almost all of the remaining 115,000 will require a high level of support throughout their lives. Figures globally are in the region of 91 people in 10,000.

The autistic community of parents and affected people throughout the world keeps closely in touch, using the internet extensively to exchange information and provide encouragement. Janine Albury Thomson in New Zealand was one parent who lacked this support. She strangled her daughter in 1997 after the pressure became too much for her to bear. The killing of 17-year-old Casey Albury is regarded as a crucial case by the autistic community because the evidence clearly articulated the mother's state of mind. It was not reported in the British press.

Casey was on holiday from her special boarding school. On the day she died, her mother recalled how she wouldn't stop repeating: "The sun is rising". Weary from stress and lack of sleep, Albury Thomson cracked. She told the jury that she took Casey to a bridge. She "foolishly expected her to climb up and throw herself off" [the parapet]. Casey, with the reduced ability to communicate of a low-functioning autistic, refused saying: "cold". Albury Thomson drove Casey to a quiet street and used the girl's dressing-gown belt as a ligature. "I wrapped it round her neck and pulled. Then I wrapped it around and pulled again and then again, all in different directions and kept thinking this isn't happening quickly enough.

"She was a misfit. People were scared of her because she was different... I wish it could have been quicker. I'd wanted to kill her for a long time. She didn't die quickly, and I held on tight . . . saying 'Let go, for God's sake, let go'... and telling her that I loved her. I wanted her to be happy in another life, because she certainly wasn't happy here."

Judge McGechan said that Casey was entitled to a life, and the court could not allow "some sort of open season" on the disabled. Albury Thomson was tried for murder, convicted of manslaughter, and sentenced to four years' jail.

Following a public outcry, the New Zealand Court of Appeal reduced her sentence to 18 months. She was released in December 1998 after serving five months of her sentence, and returned home to her two remaining children, Hannah, four, and Shannon, three.

Lester Mundell, chief advisor on disability to the New Zealand ministry of health, told me: "The disability sector in New Zealand has generally been critical of the public sympathy shown to Janine Albury Thomson, pointing out the sanctity of human life and the need to not discount that because of disability.

"Understandably, there has also been comment from many parents of children with autism, that they have also come close to causing harm because of the lack of support."

The case resulted in a New Zealand government inquiry into the provision of services for autism conducted by Professor John Werry. A number of initiatives resulted, including the piloting of the British EarlyBird intervention programme. EarlyBird was launched nationally in the UK in January and was devised by the NAS with funding from British Telecom. The aim is to help parents with pre-school autistic children. Parents attend weekly support groups over a period of three months with experts visiting them at home in between.

The British Association for the Study and Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect (BASPCAN) is to hold Congress 2000 at York University on September 18. Professor Richard Sobsey, who is director of the JP Das Developmental Disabilities Centre at Alberta University in Canada, and head of the International Coalition on Abuse and Disability, will be giving a keynote speech entitled Abuse and Children with Disabilities. He is robustly opposed to so-called "mercy killing" against disabled people.

"Killing children who have disabilities is basically no different from killing other children," he says. "Society has constructed a myth that says it's OK, or at least not really too bad, to kill these children."

As the parent of a son with a severe disability, Sobsey knows what he's talking about. "I know that sometimes it is demanding and sometimes it is heartbreaking, but also as the parent of a daughter without a disability I know that any parent can feel that way about any child at times." Alberta University is researching 1,130 homicides of disabled people over recent years. Sobsey said of the Albury Thomson case: "The (initial) four-year sentence handed down by Justice McGechan is about average for killing a child with a disability and much shorter than the sentences typically given for killing a child without a disability.

"Two-thirds of all murdered children are killed by their own parents. Virtually all parents who kill their children are under great stress for one reason or another. If stress, lack of support, or concern over the child's future is an excuse for killing Casey, we'd better be prepared to excuse every other parent who kills his or her child. If not, we're just putting less value on the lives of children with disabilities."

Sobsey emphasises that most parents of autistic children don't harm them. "Some (parents) are great writers or artists or musicians. Most are just ordinary people, but in the middle of the night, trying to soothe a sleepless child, they are all pretty much the same. Deep inside they love their children... because of their special relationship with a child who needs a lot from them."

Frank Johnson, my playwriting partner, has a mildly autistic son. Zachary is a gentle and affectionate boy who is able to respond to his parents, so their experience of autism has been positive. By contrast, a severely autistic child, like the 10-year-old Charley in our new play, can make life hell. The parents have a life-long responsibility for someone with profound difficulty in relating to the world. The young person's inability to show love in the same way as a "normal" child can be a daily heartbreak. Parents often feel guilt, and worry about the child's future when they die.

The inspiration for our radio play Charley From Outside came from reading an article in a national newspaper about the parent of an autistic child who confessed to terrible feelings of wishing their child were dead.

Charley is about a caring mother pushed to the limit. We consulted experts on autism, including specialist teachers who meet parents of autistic children daily, and parents themselves. We always told people that we were writing about a mother who murders her child, in case they were horrified at the idea. They never were. Though few of them would act in the same way as Albury Thomson.

 Charley From Outside by Frank Johnson and John Park will be broadcast on LBC 1152 AM on 28 August at 2 pm, and webcast internationally from www.lbc.co.uk. Feedback can be emailed to charleyfromoutside@hotmail.com.

Sobsey said of the Albury Thomson case: "The (initial) four-year sentence handed down by Justice McGechan is about average for killing a child with a disability and much shorter than the sentences typically given for killing a child without a disability. "Two-thirds of all murdered children are killed by their own parents. Virtually all parents who kill their children are under great stress for one reason or another. If stress, lack of support, or concern over the child's future is an excuse for killing Casey, we'd better be prepared to excuse every other parent who kills his or her child. If not, we're just putting less value on the lives of children with disabilities." Sobsey emphasises that most parents of autistic children don't harm them. "Some (parents) are great writers or artists or musicians. Most are just ordinary people, but in the middle of the night, trying to soothe a sleepless child, they are all pretty much the same. Deep inside they love their children... because of their special relationship with a child who needs a lot from them." Frank Johnson, my playwriting partner, has a mildly autistic son. Zachary is a gentle and affectionate boy who is able to respond to his parents, so their experience of autism has been positive. By contrast, a severely autistic child, like the 10-year-old Charley in our new play, can make life hell. The parents have a life-long responsibility for someone with profound difficulty in relating to the world. The young person's inability to show love in the same way as a "normal" child can be a daily heartbreak. Parents often feel guilt, and worry about the child's future when they die. The inspiration for our radio play Charley From Outside came from reading an article in a national newspaper about the parent of an autistic child who confessed to terrible feelings of wishing their child were dead. Charley is about a caring mother pushed to the limit. We consulted experts on autism, including specialist teachers who meet parents of autistic children daily, and parents themselves. We always told people that we were writing about a mother who murders her child, in case they were horrified at the idea. They never were. Though few of them would act in the same way as Albury Thomson.  Charley From Outside by Frank Johnson and John Park will be broadcast on LBC 1152 AM on 28 August at 2 pm, and webcast internationally from www.lbc.co.uk. fields.headline: Softer selling
fields.standfirst: Charities face a code of practice to regulate 'aggressive' fundraising techniques.  Nicola Hill  reports
fields.trailText: Charities face a code of practice to regulate 'aggressive' fundraising techniques. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
Charity fundraisers who stop you in the street may have to watch their step in future. The practice of "face-to-face" fundraising, asking passers by to set up a direct debit, has spread rapidly through Britain's high streets in the past two years. But a review of charity law in Scotland, together with a code of practice south of the border, look likely to begin to curb what some see as an over-aggressive technique.

The prospect of controls in Scotland has come with the launch of a consultation paper from the Scottish charity law review commission. The paper suggests that the legal definition of "public charitable collection" may be too narrow and notes that it excludes non-cash appeals.

Jean McFadden, who is chairing the commission, says: "I have heard that some people are worried about the increasing use of professional fundraisers who collect direct debit details from people in the street to ensure regular donations to charities."

The 14-member commission is undertaking a programme of fact-finding visits over the summer and has invited comments on its paper by September 29. McFadden says she wants to "hear directly from people what they really think about charities and what they think we should do to modernise the regulation of charities". The commission's final recommendations will be presented to the Scottish parliament next spring.

The Charity Commission says it has no plans for a corresponding review of the law in England and Wales. But a spokesperson warns: "Members of the public should not give in to pressure to donate against their better judgment. If individuals are asked to make long-term financial commitments, they should feel free to take the material home and look at it more closely."

To discourage aggressive forms of face-to-face fundraising, the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers (ICFM) has just issued a code of practice on what it calls "personal solicitation for committed gifts". Andrew Watt, who heads the ICFM's policy unit, says: "We as a sector see this work from the inside, from a practitioner's viewpoint. The danger is that the public can see the external manifestation of this as an alienating and inappropriate level of commercialism, rather than the professional approach that all responsible fundraisers must undertake."

The institute has also drawn up a draft donors' rights charter and an accompanying complaints procedure. This eight-point pledge is being circulated among fundraisers for consultation and will be issued to the public in early December. It states that donors have the right to expect fundraisers to observe the highest professional standards at all times.

Practitioners of face-to-face fundraising claim that they do maintain high standards. Personal Fundraising Partnership (PFP) is one of the leading agencies in the field and has an office in Glasgow. James Hale, its PR and marketing manager, says that its fundraisers only talk to passers-by who express an interest, and that there is no pressure to give to the charity.

"As with any new medium, we can understand people's concerns," says Hale. "The same was true of direct mail or telesales in the past, but these rarely attract comments now. Face-to-face fundraising has inevitably attracted a lot of attention due to its visibility on the streets, though some reports have been alarmist and over-exaggerated."

Greenpeace UK was one of the first organisations to introduce face-to-face fundraising, which it had pioneered in Germany. The charity's marketing director, Annie Moreton says she was surprised by McFadden's comments. "Face-to-face has one of the lowest complaint rates compared with other forms of fundraising."

Although it is seen as a new method, Moreton points out that talking to people to interest them in a charity is one of the oldest techniques in the world. Greenpeace has conducted research among those it has recruited and found an "extremely positive" response to the method. Moreton says that younger people, in particular, welcome the opportunity for dialogue. This seems to be borne out by research conducted by PFP. Of new donors recruited, 85% are under the age of 40 and some 60% to 75% are not supporting any other charity. Hale says: "This shows that we are tapping into a new pool of donors that are not being reached by other fundraising methods."

However, Richard Radcliffe, chair of legacy fundraising agency Smee and Ford, is concerned about the impact on existing donors. He says: "I heard someone on the street the other day complaining about face-to-face fundraising going on and saying they would take the charity out of their will." As well as gathering anecdotal evidence, Radcliffe has conducted almost 400 focus groups researching attitudes to fundraising. He found the most common complaints of respondents centred on poor direct marketing, telemarketing - and face-to-face fundraising on the streets. "What alarms me at the moment is how many members of the public think there is too much fundraising and that it is done in too direct a way," says Radcliffe. "The danger is that this may lead to less giving in the long-term."

 The Scottish charity law review commission's consultation paper is at www.charityreview.com

fields.headline: Just getting by
fields.standfirst: The rural poor have least access to services. So how do people cope? By developing self-help strategies, says  David Lovibond
fields.trailText: The rural poor have least access to services. So how do people cope? By developing self-help strategies, says David Lovibond
fields.body:
In his diary entry for July 30, 1990, Alan Clarke complains of someone's "fat wife" stealing firewood from his hedgerows. All over rural England the poor are taking cabbages from the fields at night time, tending sheep all day for a bag of groceries, tidying gardens for a lift into town on market day.

Jean, 38, a divorced mother of three children all under 10, lives in a council semi in a village near Chichester. After harvest this year, as every year, she trundles an old pram into the fields and gathers the ears of corn spilt by the combines. "We keep chickens at home, this way it costs me nothing to feed them and I sell most of the eggs at the gate. There's always a day or two before they plough the field, and between us we can fill the pram right up five or six times."

In winter, Jean, who once owed money to mail order catalogue companies and the utilities, takes her battered black pram and scours local woodlands for fallen timber. "I've a wood-burning stove, and we can heat water and keep the house warm from what we collect round and about. I'll take a rope and maybe a saw in the pram; sometimes a tree or branch needs a bit of help to fall over, but no one seems to mind."

Social services research shows that the rural poor have least access to services. The least well-off turn quietly to self-help in the form of barter and to the oldest system of all - hunting and gathering. Sometimes the activity borders on the criminal, other schemes involve elaborate cooperative ventures, but the common denominator is that people just do not earn enough or have enough social security to buy what they need.

In Nottinghamshire, the closure of more than two dozen pits in 20 years has economically debilitated the county's colliery villages and led to some unorthodox self-help strategies. "There's a whole amount of illegality in these type of communities," says Bob Middleton of Nottinghamshire rural development council. "Everything from car boots through to hare coursing - a bit like Robin Hood country - which is what we are of course."

Fred (not his real name), 36, a part-time cleaner from Warsopvale near Mansfield, is an unlikely candidate for Mr Hood's band of merry men. "Potatoes are best, or carrots. We'll go out at night round Newark and fill the car from the fields. Maybe do three or four runs to the same place. I bag up what I need for myself and sell the rest in the pubs at 20p a pound. On average we make about £35 each for the night." Fred's vegetable raids are not without danger: "We've been shot at with salt pellets - they sting but they don't really cut you up."

Describing himself as dyslexic and "not very clever" Fred brings hard work and ingenuity to his scams. Apart from poaching trout from private rivers and "recovering" coal from old rail wagons, and selling the bounty for cash, he offers his services for payment in kind. "I worked two days digging out footings for this bloke and he fitted me a bathroom suite. If you want anything like that, you do odd jobs: I painted someone's house and they gave me a carpet for the lounge. I got the curtains in return for putting a wall up. I got the television and video helping a bloke assembling aerials. It's common in our village - my neighbour works the fields in the daytime and delivers pizzas at night - cash in hand."

Fred has been caught twice by the DSS and prosecuted, but says he cannot afford to be concerned. "It's not a question of being worried. I can choose to starve or to survive."

In rural south Norfolk, knitwear designer Anne Laverne, 46, is part of a project which enables women to start their own businesses. The Full Circle programme, funded by the Women's Employment Enterprise and Training Unit (Weetu), provides financial and tactical support for small groups or "circles" of women whose business schemes are separate but complementary.

"We have an enamalist in our circle," says Anne, who lives in the hamlet of Old Buckenham, 14 miles south of Norwich. "She makes buttons and logos for my knitted 'Annebags' and I give her one of the bags. With a lady painter I swapped the value of one of my designer garments for a painting and some cash. I did the same with someone else who makes mirrors and wicker lampshades. Chumming up with like-minded women and forming a circle means that, though I'm on my on, I don't feel isolated. Years ago I used to have coffee - now I have meetings."

Among the scattered villagers of Wiltshire's Vale of Pewsey more rudimentary subsistence systems are in place. Tony is a trapper. A security guard by day, at nights and weekends Tony and his friend Mick, a farm worker recently made redundant, are up on the Downs taking roe deer with a .22 rifle, or trapping rabbits. "I net the holes first and put the ferret in. Sometimes he'll catch them and that's that, or he'll chase them into the net. We can get 75p each for them at the butcher's or swap them at the pub for beer."

In a small hamlet near Devizes, unemployed ex-pub landlord, Judy Burrell, gives talks on antiques to the Women's Institute at £10 a time. She also teaches piano, makes cricket teas, caters at local point-to-points and looks after elderly neighbours. When Burrell ran her pub she paid her "unofficial" staff with cheese and doesn't feel the least qualm at supplementing her benefit income with earnings in cash and kind.

"I was in the Wrens, I've always worked, but when you're over 50 you might as well give up. I get £79 a week from the state, but my car is on its last legs and the nearest food shop is a £5 return bus ride away. It gets so cold here in the winter; sometimes it takes £20 a week just to warm the cottage. I couldn't manage without my bits and pieces of jobs, it's my form of begging I suppose."

Dan Friston, 33, an unemployed classical guitarist living in rural north Gloucestershire, trades gardening work for musical training. Friston is a member of the Fair Shares scheme, a barter system which uses time as its currency and is based on acts of neighbourliness. "This is not about money, the people involved in the scheme (there are about 190 members) understand the ethos behind it, which is trying to build up community links."

Fellow Fair Shares member Clare Sheridan, 47, who used to work in the NHS, offers child care, bereavement counselling and lifts into local hospitals in exchange for body massages and aromatherapy. "Money is not part of it, so people don't feel they're getting charity, and everyone can feel important because everyone has something to offer."

Martin Simon, the director of Fair Shares, says the scheme encompasses 100 different skills and is trying to recreate a time when people did share and get involved in each other's lives. "Fair Shares is a community building tool, everybody gives and receives - which is the essence of community. We hope to instill a sense of belonging."

 Fair Shares can be contacted at City Works, Alfred Street, Gloucester GL1 4DF.

"Fair Shares is a community building tool, everybody gives and receives - which is the essence of community. We hope to instill a sense of belonging."  Fair Shares can be contacted at City Works, Alfred Street, Gloucester GL1 4DF.

fields.headline: Taste of the good life
fields.standfirst: French eco-villages have appealed to urban idealists escaping the rat race but their success has been mixed
fields.trailText: French eco-villages have appealed to urban idealists escaping the rat race but their success has been mixed.
fields.body:
Do you want to live organically, sustainably - and in France? Eco-villages are a concept which is spreading fast, with dense clusters in the warmer zones. Surprisingly, the main problem they have is shortage of residents. Brits are welcome too.

The French eco-village network's website lists more than 30 communities - with such alluring names as La Ferme du Bonheur and Le Projet Hier et Aujourd'hui Pour Demain. Eco-villages aim to provide a good life without taking more from the earth than they give back. There are thousands around the world - many successes and many disasters. All face the same problems: how do urban idealists fit into conventional rural life? How can they live sustainably while making a decent living?

Beau Champ eco-village has eight hectares of woods and meadows on the edge of the Dordogne. John Cant, founder and owner, is a squat and solid Scot who bought the ruined farmhouse and the land with the proceeds of a legacy. With the help of British summer volunteers known as wwoofers (willing workers on organic farms) the house has become almost comfortable, a perma-culture garden flourishes, the woods provide sustainable firewood and timber for building and a reed bed system cleans waste water from the kitchen and bathroom and re-circulates it into the garden.

But John is short of members. The resident community has shrunk from five to two. "The problem was that, while I was economically viable (I'm a computer nerd), others were not. So people were dependent on me, and that creates resentment on both sides." Now he has built enough rooms for a community of eight and he's looking for permanent members "who can make their way in the world as it is and yet are attracted to making a shift", and visitors who want to help out for a few weeks or months and move on.

Over in the south-east, in the Drome, Paulianne Farm is selling time-share flats to ecologically-minded British holidaymakers and hopes to use the proceeds for organic farming. The old farmhouse is in a huge estate of fields and woodlands surrounded by snowy peaks.

Tucked into a mountain fold 1,000 metres high, the stone houses of Eourres, in the lower Alps, are strung out in a picturesque line with the church at the top end. The village had 800 people in 1789. Only 10 elderly peasants were left in 1990 when a group of eco-idealists decided to restore and re-occupy it. Soon 10 French adults with two children formed a community called Terres Nouvelles, led by Gilles Roy, a charismatic new-ager who had learned community skills at Findhorn in Scotland. They produced organic goats' cheese and honey.

By 1990 most had left because they couldn't make a living and there were not enough schools for their kids. Gradually they were replaced by people who found Eourres a good proposition even though, or perhaps because, it was no longer a community. The newcomers and the few pioneers who stayed have turned Eourres into a viable oasis of organic vegetable and sheep farming with sustainable waste disposal in a reed bed, a publishing firm, high quality music-making, catering for tourists and rearing donkeys for mountain safaris. They number 60, including 15 children.

Today Eourres is one of the most successful eco-villages in France - but ironically, the residents have decided to drop the title as they are busy and don't want to be bothered by itinerant eco-freaks and journalists.

This movement has plenty of dreamers who don't make it. I climbed to a lofty hamlet in the Ardèche where a Parisian had bought 66 hectares of scrubland to found "an eco-village for people who love beauty, deep ecology and the sacred at all levels." But Jean-Pierre Maitre has been waiting on his mountain for 10 years and has found no takers. Meanwhile, hostile neighbours set fire to his barn and bulldozed his fence. His own dog killed 15 of his sheep. Maitre is still there, still hoping.

An eco-village of more promise is Bio Lopin, in the Jura. It is dedicated to eco-friendly building techniques with materials like straw bales, wool, hemp and logs bonded with sawdust and anchored in a mortar of lime and sand. Alain Richard inherited the 17-hectare farm, went on an eco-building course and used his new skills to build a farmhouse, stable, office, storehouse, pottery studio, and a lodging house for tourists.

In the brave and precarious world of eco-villages, disaster always looms. At Valensolette, in the Provencal Alps, everything that can go wrong did. "The members of this community had no method and no recruitment procedures but plenty of psychological problems," said Marcel Charran, the only one left on site. He had invited people to join him in turning the farm he inherited into an eco-village. Some, he conceded, "were into serious organic agriculture, but the rest were into some kind of anarchist utopia."

Charran has not given up. A wiser man, he plans to start again with a new team. Meanwhile he is converting a farm shed into tourist rooms. Once again, if you want to step aside from the consumer economy you still need to make money from it. Happily, it is possible to do both - and recruits for viable eco-villages never dry up.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Alliance wish list
fields.body:
Alliance wish list

The Countryside Alliance, the organisation that grew out of the pro-hunting lobby, has proved a thorn in the side of the government and continues its tirade in a new policy handbook. It makes many reasonable points about the need for rural post offices, pubs, the problem of rural crime and the general neglect of services. But there are other more outlandish complaints and claims which allow the organisation's original colours to show through.

 On the right to roam: the alliance complains bitterly of the liability of landowners for walkers who are injured on their land, and the difficulty of getting insurance to cover them. "There are countless land management operations such as fencing and tree felling during which a landowner cannot possibly make the land safe for walkers." It regards the landowners right to close land for only 28 days a year inadequate and the idea of suspending land management at weekends to allow in walkers as "preposterous".

 Raptors: the alliance does not like birds of prey and devotes a whole section to their economic effect on grouse moors and how to deal with it, asking for special dispensation to get round laws protecting raptors. They particularly object to (very rare) hen harriers which can have a "devastating effect on grouse populations if left unchecked". They suggest capturing and shifting raptors to other suitable locations. If that does not work and the birds breed then "sustainable harvesting of the population" should be permitted. Presumably that means a return to gamekeepers shooting and poisoning them.

 Hunting: it contains the most bizarre claim so far on the need for hunting to continue. "Country sports enthusiasts undertake a large amount of unpaid conservation management throughout the year, and this benefits biodiversity and other countryside users. For instance, fox hunts throughout the country traditionally practice hedge laying for its recreational value of creating jumps for mounted followers. This practice increases the conservation value of hedgerows."

Strength in numbers

And finally, a clue to why "the great car economy" is doing as well under New Labour as under its great champion Mrs Thatcher. There are 30 car manufacturing plants in the UK plus eight truck and bus building companies (excluding engine, tyre and component offshoots). Britain is said to have the largest number of car plants of any country in the world. This all adds up to a lot of political clout.

fields.headline: Key to confidence
fields.standfirst: A can-do, will-do philosophy is central to a new scheme in south London encouraging the unemployed to get motivated. John Cunningham reports from the classroom
fields.trailText: A can-do, will-do philosophy is central to a new scheme in south London encouraging the unemployed to get motivated. John Cunningham reports from the classroom.
fields.body:
What's wrong with the whole range of official and voluntary initiatives to help the jobless, says Philip Collett, is that they miss out the vital first step: motivation.

This is a brash assessment of the millions poured into schemes to get young people into work. But then Collett is no academic or politician: he is a businessman who founded and runs a telephone messaging service. He has also started a company offering courses to raise the self-esteem of unemployed clients. "It's my mission," says Collett, "I don't make money on it".

Which is why eight people in their late teens and early 20s, none of whom has ever had a full-time job, are attending a two-day course in Peckham, south London. They are being put through the Goals motivation programme. Over the past five years, about 5,000 clients have tried Goals - a total which Collett, who first encountered the programme on a visit to the US a decade ago, finds frustrating. He is convinced that low self-esteem lies at the root of much alienation from the jobs market, and that the courses should be used more widely.

Each student gets a workbook which sets out 10 keys to success. And on a video screen there are clips from a seminar where the president of the Foundation for Self-Esteem, Jack Canfield, expounds his can-do philosophy. The authorities in California are so impressed that all recipients of welfare payments must go on a Goals programme.

"You are going to learn practical ways to improve your life that self-made millionaires, Olympic athletes, famous movie stars and people like you have used to create successes in their lives," promises Canfield's introduction in the workbook. In the context of Peckham "people like you", explains the course facilitator, John McNamara, can mean those who experience poor education, poverty, drugs and crime. Participants on courses in other cities include former industrial workers in Glasgow and ex-prisoners.

The cost per person is just £25, but the courses are not a quick fix; there are lasting improvements for many takers, insists Collett. His argument is that training, re-skilling and coaching in interview techniques are of no use unless the jobless can be convinced to adhere to a progression of targets. This begins with simple rules such as: "Use only positive self-talk, I can... I will"; advances through medium-term goals, for example: "I will get a day care centre job within six months"; and culminates in a career target like: "I will be director of a day care centre in 18 months' time."

The emphasis Goals places on taking any job, however menial or low paid, as the first step does not find favour with some experts on employment; and the undeniably American spiel of Canfield and the videoed testimony of others, which has a touch of the religious revivalist meeting, might be a turn-off for some.

Day two in Peckham. A young man who did not turn up the first day has now joined the group; another day-one client misses the morning session, pops in at lunch, promising to be there in the afternoon, then fails to show. If McNamara is exasperated, he doesn't let on. It is a big effort for many clients to turn up at 10am, he says, as their days usually begin much later.

Mid-afternoon. One participant, lets call him Ben, has had enough of the 10 stages in his workbook. No need to write down what he is aiming for, as McNamara suggests, because Ben reckons he can keep it all in his head. McNamara says that setting down goals makes the exercise more real.

Not to me, insists Ben, who adds that he is self-employed "so I know what I want to do". By now, he is putting on his puffa jacket, exclaiming that "this is school stuff", and heading for the door.

McNamara deals with his exit calmly; attendance is voluntary, after all; and the others - a bit of ribbing and a few street-smart asides thrown in - seem impressed at what they have achieved in two days. They have been told that it is no good blaming others for their problems; change lies within their own grasp. They have co-operated in an exercise in "guided visualisation" led by McNamara. With eyes closed, deep breaths and rather spooky music in the background, they have conjured up their ideal home, relationship, career - and set dates for getting them.

The important message is learning the technique for boosting self-confidence; then using it at home, week after week, until the situation improves. That is the hardest part. But the message is optimistic. McNamara gives out his phone numbers, enjoining the group to ring him anytime for encouragement. And Collett, self-made businessman with an altruistic streak, dreams of starting an institute of self-esteem; of getting ministers to agree to a monitoring programme to show whether Goals works and hopes of taking his message to Tony Blair.

In the US, more than 600,000 participants have taken part in Goals, and many swear by it. In Peckham, one young woman says it was really helpful, though it seemed to have been less useful in employment terms than in aiding her to sort herself out after the end of a relationship. Her friend is enthusiastic, too. By autumn next year, she wants to be on a media studies course. Igniting that flickering hope, at £25 a time, may be worth it after all.

Does the New Deal work?

Unemployment may be at a 25-year low, but it is twice as high among young adults as among the workforce as a whole. In the 18-24 age group, 11% are jobless and seeking work and almost four in 10 of them have been in that position more than six months. Of the 412,000 unemployed in that age group in the UK, 157,000 have been jobless more than six months, 68,000 more than a year and 28,000 more than two years. The latter is the highest since 1998.

Argument over the success, or otherwise, of the government's new deal programme rages on. Labour promised to find work for 250,000 young people unemployed for more than six months, and by the end of April had done so for 216,000. But more than a quarter have returned to the dole within 13 weeks.

How much of this is attributable to the New Deal is debatable. In the year before the programme became fully effective, in spring 1998, the number of people aged 18-24 who had been jobless more than six months fell 60,000 due to strong economic growth. Some estimates suggest that two in three who leave the New Deal for jobs would have found work irrespective.
