fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Interactive froth
fields.body:
Interactive froth

Jonathan Kaye's vision as expressed in Why interactive will mean active, (August 16) did not do justice to two related seminal issues in disabled people's lives - disposable income and power. At long last, disabled people's power is being recognised as real. Our collective voice is beginning to bite. Paradoxically, interactive TV and new technology generally, while holding tremendous potential to liberate and empower us, holds equal power to take our collective eye off the ball. Groceries delivered to my door are only part of the struggle. While succumbing to a growth in home-based services, I fear we could be seduced into a false sense of security and become less radical in our demands - for a share of the power held by non-disabled people.

The other issue is the financial cost of new technology. Most disabled people don't have much money - a significant part of what we do have is taken away (including benefit payments) by local authority social services departments for basic, essential support services. Within the last month the government has committed itself to continue charging disabled people for services that most people can do for themselves, like getting out of bed and getting back into it. Interactive TV, like most fashionable panaceas, is froth. Until the state addresses the continuing basic denial of human rights to disabled people we will forever be outsiders looking in.
John Knight
Essex

Key skills

How refreshing it was to see an article (Price is right, August 16), not only discussing NHS procurement, but also acknowledging the holistic skills and considerations that such procurement requires.

Internal purchasers need rewards that reflect their skills. A good procurement officer will save far more than his salary, as your cited examples reflect, and to attract such staff calls for good pay and conditions. Conversely, poor purchasers, or their managers, should not be allowed to go on without review.

Politicians and NHS management must make it worthwhile for healthcare providers to wish to make savings. As long as we have a public sector ideology within which it seems acceptable to operate at a loss (through fear of subsequent cuts should budgets be under-spent), there is little motivation for providers to review the situation into which procurement has unfortunately been driven.

With annual budgets being the major driver for NHS provider spend, it will remain hard for organisations to make relatively heavy up-front investment for long-term efficiency and financial benefit. It seems unforgivable not to redress this reality.
Dr Gill Wade
Celtic Dimensions
Gwynedd

Nothing to be proud of

The article Walk in the Past by Janet Snell (August 9), leaves many key questions unanswered.

Why are NCH Action for Children and Joan Kerry pleased about their achievements? Their response to the plight of Britain's former child migrants, who were in their care, is both too little and far too late.

The agencies involved in the child migration schemes removed thousands of young children from their country of birth, their families and their friends. Former child migrants have been deprived of their identities and denied their families for decades. Many parents have died not knowing where their children are.

These agencies were first alerted to these issues and the consequences of their cruel and inhumane practices over 10 years ago, but they chose to do precious little until recently. Why did it take a House of Commons select health committee inquiry to jolt these agencies out of their complacency?

How many former child migrants or their parents have died over the past decade? How many might have been reunited with their parents if NCH had been more rapid and generous in its response? Instead, they are left to visit a graveside.

Why did NCH not contract out this service to an independent agency? Fewer than half the survivors wished to use the NCH service. Who was consulted about this half-hearted project? Certainly not this association.
Harold Haig
International Association of Former Child Migrants and their Families
Australia

Legal strain

I was surprised to see that the only response to Jenny Sinclair's article on fostering (Letters, August 2) made no attempt to reply to her apparently justified complaints about her situation. Although she did mention the lack of support offered by the agency which employed her to care for very difficult youngsters, her main problems seemed to be with the intolerable constraints placed upon her family life by the needs of the laws which insist upon detailed checks on anyone who might come into contact with the foster children. If this situation is common, it must cause anyone who might contemplate fostering to think again.
Hilary Brindley
London SE24

Lack of care

I am 80 years old and live alone. I was briefly in hospital for an operation on my hand and was visited by social services who asked if there was any help I would need when I went home. Yes, I replied, someone to bathe me and clean the house. These things are not possible, she said. They are not insured for bathing clients and cleaning was limited to "dusting the tops", no furniture could be moved. How awful it must be to be disabled and dependent on social services - never to have a bath, and never to have the dust cleared out from behind your chair or under your bed.

Do people realise what care in the community amounts to?
Barbara Hutton

fields.bodyText: Interactive froth Jonathan Kaye's vision as expressed in Why interactive will mean active, (August 16) did not do justice to two related seminal issues in disabled people's lives - disposable income and power. At long last, disabled people's power is being recognised as real. Our collective voice is beginning to bite. Paradoxically, interactive TV and new technology generally, while holding tremendous potential to liberate and empower us, holds equal power to take our collective eye off the ball. Groceries delivered to my door are only part of the struggle. While succumbing to a growth in home-based services, I fear we could be seduced into a false sense of security and become less radical in our demands - for a share of the power held by non-disabled people. The other issue is the financial cost of new technology. Most disabled people don't have much money - a significant part of what we do have is taken away (including benefit payments) by local authority social services departments for basic, essential support services. Within the last month the government has committed itself to continue charging disabled people for services that most people can do for themselves, like getting out of bed and getting back into it. Interactive TV, like most fashionable panaceas, is froth. Until the state addresses the continuing basic denial of human rights to disabled people we will forever be outsiders looking in. John Knight Essex Key skills How refreshing it was to see an article (Price is right, August 16), not only discussing NHS procurement, but also acknowledging the holistic skills and considerations that such procurement requires. Internal purchasers need rewards that reflect their skills. A good procurement officer will save far more than his salary, as your cited examples reflect, and to attract such staff calls for good pay and conditions. Conversely, poor purchasers, or their managers, should not be allowed to go on without review. Politicians and NHS management must make it worthwhile for healthcare providers to wish to make savings. As long as we have a public sector ideology within which it seems acceptable to operate at a loss (through fear of subsequent cuts should budgets be under-spent), there is little motivation for providers to review the situation into which procurement has unfortunately been driven. With annual budgets being the major driver for NHS provider spend, it will remain hard for organisations to make relatively heavy up-front investment for long-term efficiency and financial benefit. It seems unforgivable not to redress this reality. Dr Gill Wade Celtic Dimensions Gwynedd Nothing to be proud of The article Walk in the Past by Janet Snell (August 9), leaves many key questions unanswered. Why are NCH Action for Children and Joan Kerry pleased about their achievements? Their response to the plight of Britain's former child migrants, who were in their care, is both too little and far too late. The agencies involved in the child migration schemes removed thousands of young children from their country of birth, their families and their friends. Former child migrants have been deprived of their identities and denied their families for decades. Many parents have died not knowing where their children are. These agencies were first alerted to these issues and the consequences of their cruel and inhumane practices over 10 years ago, but they chose to do precious little until recently. Why did it take a House of Commons select health committee inquiry to jolt these agencies out of their complacency? How many former child migrants or their parents have died over the past decade? How many might have been reunited with their parents if NCH had been more rapid and generous in its response? Instead, they are left to visit a graveside. Why did NCH not contract out this service to an independent agency? Fewer than half the survivors wished to use the NCH service. Who was consulted about this half-hearted project? Certainly not this association. Harold Haig International Association of Former Child Migrants and their Families Australia Legal strain I was surprised to see that the only response to Jenny Sinclair's article on fostering (Letters, August 2) made no attempt to reply to her apparently justified complaints about her situation. Although she did mention the lack of support offered by the agency which employed her to care for very difficult youngsters, her main problems seemed to be with the intolerable constraints placed upon her family life by the needs of the laws which insist upon detailed checks on anyone who might come into contact with the foster children. If this situation is common, it must cause anyone who might contemplate fostering to think again. Hilary Brindley London SE24 Lack of care I am 80 years old and live alone. I was briefly in hospital for an operation on my hand and was visited by social services who asked if there was any help I would need when I went home. Yes, I replied, someone to bathe me and clean the house. These things are not possible, she said. They are not insured for bathing clients and cleaning was limited to "dusting the tops", no furniture could be moved. How awful it must be to be disabled and dependent on social services - never to have a bath, and never to have the dust cleared out from behind your chair or under your bed. Do people realise what care in the community amounts to? fields.headline: Pulling together
fields.standfirst: Propaganda and myths have obscured what it was really like to live through the blitz.  Bob Holman remembers his boyhood
fields.trailText: Propaganda and myths have obscured what it was really like to live through the blitz. Bob Holman remembers his boyhood.
fields.body:
Sixty years ago on September 7, 1940, German bombs killed 430 civilians and seriously injured 1,600 more in London's East End. The blitz had started.

The year before, when war had been declared, over 1m children - my sister and I among them - had been evacuated from the cities. By January, 1940, most of us had returned home as the bombs never came. Then Hitler changed tactics. For 76 consecutive nights, save for two evenings of bad weather, the planes rained destruction upon London.

Our family lived in Ilford, to the east of the city, which was a target as it contained a large munitions factory. Nights were spent in stuffy, overcrowded shelters. Daytime entailed queuing with mum for scarce food. Bread and potatoes were available, although sometimes they could not be cooked because bombs had shattered gas and electricity mains. Baths could only be taken in a regulation five inches of water and even today I feel guilty if I use more.

It was irksome, but more than that, we were scared. One morning, we emerged from the shelter to look at London burning with 1,500 fires. We saw maimed people being dragged out of ruined buildings and huge craters in which nobody could have survived. We were scared of death. And we were scared of invasion, for the German forces were poised to cross the channel. Trauma, death, fear was the blitz childhood. There was one compensation: most schools were closed. But youngsters roamed the streets and public air-raid shelters had to be protected against vandals. The number of under-17s convicted of breaking the law doubled.

The blitz sparked further evacuations from bombed cities. We stayed, however, because my parents could not bear to be parted from us again. One night, we were too slow to reach the shelter. We stood hand-in-hand on the landing of our house with dad saying: "If we go, we go together." Shrapnel smashed the windows, but we survived.

By May 1941, the blitz was almost over. Ironically, we were then evacuated after one of the last raids rendered our home uninhabitable. This time, mum went with us to the country. Within two years, the threat of bombs apparently over, we were glad to come back to a repaired home, a re-opened school and, soon after, a new baby brother.

But the optimism was false. Germany launched its V1s and V2s: the former bomb-laden pilotless planes, the latter flying rockets against which there was no defence. On November 24, 1944, my school was shaken by an enormous explosion. I ran back through a death-strewn street. A nearby rocket had crushed our house. As I stood in the rubble in tears, a hand came on my shoulder and a voice said: "It's all right, son." Dad, mum and the baby had been dug out seriously injured.

Eventually, they recovered and we were evacuated again. Mum and we three kids lived in one room. I was unhappy at an overcrowded school where the teachers resented the "vaccees". But within six months, the war was over and we were home for good.

Children are, of course, allowed to be scared. Government propaganda constructed the myth that blitzed adults were all brave, cheerful and devoted to the royal family and Winston Churchill. Far from it.

Some adults fled from London. Looting occurred. The king and queen were booed by some East Enders who contrasted the royals' luxury with their lack of food. Grievances could erupt and the radical priest, John Groser, smashed open a food depot in Stepney, in the East End, when officials were slow to feed his bombed-out neighbours.

Nonetheless, the bombs did stimulate acts of courage. My dad worked in the munitions factory. In the evenings he joined other air raid wardens in smothering incendiary bombs with blankets and digging out the wounded. He would come home ashen from his harrowing experiences. He was both brave and scared, a mixture found in thousands of men and women who served in the home guard, as emergency ambulance drivers, firefighters and auxiliary nurses.

The involvement of masses of ordinary people in vital posts lifted morale. The number of suicides and mental health problems dropped. The participation was significant for two other reasons. First, it taught many working-class citizens that they could organise and lead. Blitzed areas survived less because of central government action, more because of neighbourhood action. Second, it radicalised a section of society. In the endless hours of waiting, politics was discussed - one reason why Labour won a landslide victory in 1945.

The evacuations undoubtedly saved lives. Yet welfare worker Lucy Faithfull was involved in a study which showed that, with the exception of education, children who stayed with their families through the blitz fared better physically and emotionally. Shortly before her death in 1996, the then Baroness Faithfull told me that, as a children's officer, she advocated keeping families together "because I realised that wherever possible children should remain with their parents". Today, with more youngsters entering care and custody, it is a lesson which needs learning again.

I hardly went to school and failed the new 11-plus exam. Later, I did make it to university, thanks to war-time reforms which opened up higher education to the working-class young people. Unfortunately, the same government failed to build upon the local action which flourished during the blitz. Instead, it concentrated on centralised corporations run by appointees. Sixty years later, Britain has 3,000 socially blitzed neighbourhoods. If the government's social exclusion unit wants to regenerate them, it should learn from the blitz - that the solutions are to be found among local residents, not by outside agencies.

Life for the evacuees

The bombs led to three waves of evacuation in 1939, 1940 and 1943-44. Children and young mothers went from danger areas to reception areas where foster parents were compelled to take them.

The foster parents were either middle class or stable, rural inhabitants. The evacuees were mainly from working-class districts. Middle England met urban poverty.

The Women's Group on Public Welfare made a famous study which stated: "The dreadful lesson of evacuation was the light it threw upon the home conditions of the lowest of town dwellers." Middle-class voices then added to the pressure for a welfare state.

The evacuation also focused attention on the needs of separated children. Local authorities had to expand their numbers of child care staff to help unhappy and disturbed evacuees. The inadequacies of services were revealed and Lady Marjory Allen led a wartime cam-paign which culminated in the 1948 Children Act, requiring authorities to establish children's departments.

Some evacuees enjoyed their time in the country. Others were badly treated, and only in recent years has it emerged that some were physically and sexually abused. But, at least, the evacuations did lead to the first local authority service with the sole task of caring for children "deprived of a normal home life".

Britain in wartime

 From London, the blitz spread to most large British cities. In one night's bombing, 554 people were killed in Coventry and the word "coventrated" came to mean a town razed to the ground. In two nights in February, 1941, Clydebank had 35,000 of its 45,000 population made homeless.

 The government was reluctant to admit the existence of Germany's special air weapons. Not until 1944 did it concede the existence of parachute bombs. Yet in 1941 a landmine attached to a parachute drifted on to a pub in Clayhall, Ilford, killing more than 60 people. Initially, official propaganda attributed the V1s to gas explosions.

 In all, 70,000 tons of bombs fell on Britain, killing over 60,000 civilians and destroying or damaging over 3.7m homes.

 During 1944, 980,000 citizens worked part-time as air raid wardens. Not enough MPs volunteered and the House of Commons burned down.

 Infant mortality fell from 53 to 49 deaths per 1,000 live births. Despite food shortages, the health of many children improved because of welfare foods and better medical services.

 Births outside marriage rose from 4.4% in 1939 to 9.1 % in 1945. The divorce rate almost tripled.

 Male unemployment figures dropped from over 1m to 40,000 in 1944. Demand for labour pushed up male manual wages by almost 50% by 1945

 Bob Holman is a community worker and author. His latest book, Kids at the Door Revisited, is published by Russell House at £9.95

fields.headline: $20m upload
fields.standfirst:
MP3.com pays off Sony
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Online music provider MP3.com signed a crucial copyright deal with Sony Music Entertainment yesterday. It is expected to pay the Japanese company about $20m (£13.5m) damages to settle a legal row over copyright violations.
fields.body:
Online music provider MP3.com signed a crucial copyright deal with Sony Music Entertainment yesterday. It is expected to pay the Japanese company about $20m (£13.5m) damages to settle a legal row over copyright violations.

MP3.com will pay a fee each time music owned by Sony - including work by Bob Dylan, Jay Kay's Jamiroquai or Bruce Springsteen - is downloaded. It has already signed similar deals with three other leading record labels, bringing its legitimate database to about three-quarters of all CDs sold, according to analysts.

Though shares rose by 31% yesterday, unless it reaches agreement with Universal, the world's largest record label, the company could face court-imposed sanctions as early as next week. A US court ruled in April that MP3.com's database breached copyright laws.

webTitle: Clean-up investigations in China scare small-time corrupt officials

fields.headline: China's graft net scares little fishes
fields.standfirst: As a senior official awaits execution, lesser sinners who constitute the greater threat start to take note
fields.trailText: As a senior official awaits execution, lesser sinners who constitute the greater threat start to take note.
fields.body:
Huang Zuolin, a communist party local official, is the most filial of sons, and has built a splendid tomb for his ancestors on a hill in south China. Facing south to secure the right feng shui, it stands on a marble plinth 20 metres (65ft) high inscribed with pious invocations to those it commemorates.

It is one of the finest monuments in Zijin, a poor rural county in the province of Guangdong which has missed out on China's economic boom. Or rather, it was. Last week Mr Huang panicked as Beijing's anti-corruption campaign gathered pace, finally yielding to complaints that he had built the mausoleum with public funds.

"Several party officials told me the best idea is to knock it down," he admitted. "Destroying it may be bad luck, but it's become a millstone around my neck."

Mr Huang says the money for the monument came from a relative in Hong Kong. But when the Nanfang Weekend newspaper in Guangzhou began to investigate, he hired a gang of tough peasants and went out by night to smash it to pieces.

The deputy party chairman of Zijin county is a very small fry swept up in the net of the new campaign. His sins do not begin to compare with those of Cheng Kejie, the party boss in neighbouring Guangxi province, whose death sentence for corruption was confirmed yesterday.

Cheng, a former deputy chairman of the Chinese parliament, was found guilty last month of accepting nearly £3.3m in collusion with his mistress Li Ping.

A party spokesman blamed his downfall on "the temptations of women and money". An anti-corruption exhibition has opened in Beijing with Cheng's case as its centrepiece. Photographs have been published of the gold, diamond rings and expensive watches which the couple acquired. They are said to have been caught on closed-circuit videos blithely gambling away their loot in casinos in Macau.

The death sentence has to be ratified by the supreme people's court, but "legal experts" in the Chinese media have already declared that he has no chance of escaping execution.

Li, who collaborated with the authorities after being brought back from her hideaway in Hong Kong, has been given a life sentence. Known as the "Madame Mao" of Guangxi province, she may have friends who can ease her plight.

Although Mr Huang's alleged malpractices are on a minute scale compared to these big fish, his sort of local corruption is a more serious threat to the regime.

Conspicuous spending in poor communities cannot escape notice: over-taxed peasants see "their money" being frittered on lavish buildings, expensive cars, banquets and prostitutes.

Mr Huang built his family mausoleum in 1994, at the high tide of the "get rich first" enthusiasm promoted by the late leader Deng Xiaoping. He says it "only" cost 170,000 renminbi (£13,000): the average annual income today in Zijin is 2,800 renminbi (£215).

Mr Huang set up a "development zone" in Zijin, annexing good farmland from the peasants for low compensation. Rich capitalists from the special economic zones on the coast near Hong Kong, he claimed, would move their industries to Zijin to take advantage of cheap local labour. He even spent 60,000 renminbi (£4,600) hiring a helicopter to fly in potential customers

Eight years later the site remains almost empty. Mr Huang's son is accused of being involved and making a quick profit by the sale of plots of land.

Mr Huang says that he has been chastened by the anti-corruption film Choice between Life and Death, which is compulsory viewing for Communist party officials all over China. It tells the fictional story of an upright mayor who persists in fighting corruption when he discovers that his wife is involved.

How to tackle corruption is certainly the political flavour of the year. President Jiang Zemin and his colleagues discussed the problem yet again during their annual seaside holiday.

But it is not only taxi-drivers and small shopkeepers who express scepticism about the chances of success. The English-language China Daily said in a special feature yesterday that graft had become a part of life in the past 20 years of economic reform.

The party journal Outlook is even more pessimistic. "Graft and corruption are like cancer cells," it said last week. "As long as conditions remain the malignancy will grow and spread."

A more severe test of the campaign than the fate of Mr Huang is about to be made in the coastal city of Xiamen, where a huge smuggling scam has been exposed by a special team of 300 investigators.

Senior local officials are expected to go on trial in the next month or two, but the web of alleged corruption extends to Beijing. Everyone is waiting to see how high the indictments will reach.

webTitle: Labour ditches ethical arms trade bill

fields.headline: Labour ditches ethical arms trade bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText:
Robin Cook's ethical foreign policy has suffered a
severe setback after his bill to regulate the arms trade
failed to secure a place in the government's autumn
legislative programme.
fields.body:
Robin Cook's ethical foreign policy has suffered a severe setback after his bill to regulate the arms trade failed to secure a place in the government's autumn legislative programme.

Labour will be open to accusations of hypocrisy by going into the general election without having implemented the recommendations on arms brokering made by Sir Richard Scott, who conducted the inquiry into the arms-to-Iraq affair. The Foreign Office had been keen to put through the legislation to send a positive signal to counter criticism it has faced over dubious arms sales to countries such as Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe.

The revelation that the measure has not been included in the Queen's Speech is an embarrassment to Mr Cook, who made his parliamentary reputation in opposition by hounding the then Conservative government in 1996 over the arms-to-Iraq affair. Over the last few months, Mr Cook and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, fought hard in private Whitehall meetings for parliamentary time for the arms bill.

They were backed by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon. But they were overruled on the ministerial committee that decides what bills should be included in November's speech.

The arms bill, which had already been drafted by the Department of Trade and Industry, would have forced Britons involved in the export of arms to be licensed. At present, the trade is governed by loose legislation introduced in 1939.

The US and other countries within the European Union, such as Germany and Sweden, license companies selling arms abroad. Licences are withheld from dealers regarded as dubious.

Spokesmen for the Foreign Office and the Department of Trade yesterday stuck to the standard government formula when asked about the Queen's Speech, saying they could not anticipate its contents.

But Whitehall sources close to the ministerial negotiations confirmed the bill had dropped off the list. "The bill is dead," one said.

As the Queen's Speech is almost certainly the last before the general election, Labour is designing one that will have electoral appeal, devoted to health, education and crime. The arms industry is not regarded as a vote-winner.

Expectations that the bill would be in the Queen's Speech were raised in February when Department of Trade officials were given the go-ahead to begin drafting, which normally guarantees a slot. A white paper on strategic export controls had first been published by the Department of Trade in 1998.

This proposed "to control the involvement of persons in the UK or UK persons abroad in trafficking and brokering in arms and other controlled goods to any country subject to an embargo". Those breaking the proposed law would be subject to criminal charges.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said last night: "Labour promised much in opposition when it reaped the dividend of Tory cynicism over arms-to-Iraq. To fail to make the necessary changes in legislation in the course of a parliament hardly suggests the kind of commitment to change for which Labour argued when the Scott report was published."

Kevin Mullen, a spokesman for the Campaign Against the Arms Trade, expressed disappointment: "Tough controls are required to stop UK nationals profiting from conflict hot spots. If the government fails to act, it will be yet another disappointing episode on this issue, considering their promises to control illicit arms sales and their posturing on the problem of blood diamonds."

The Foreign Office has led a campaign this year to restrict the sale of diamonds from Sierra Leone, Angola and the Congo that contribute to their civil wars.

Paul Eavis, director of Saferworld, another campaign group, said: "It is outrageous that the government is not bringing forward legislation to tackle the problems caused by arms brokers and shipping agents."

In the last year, Mr Cook has been overruled several times by Tony Blair, who came down in favour of Mr Byers and Mr Hoon in allowing contentious arms sales. But Mr Byers was an enthusiast for this bill. To a lesser extent, so was Mr Hoon.

webTitle: Leeds fans arrested after Hitler chants

fields.headline: Leeds fans arrested after Hitler chants
fields.trailText: Thirteen Leeds United fans have been arrested in Munich after chanting "Heil Hitler!" and raising their arms in Nazi salutes.
fields.body:
Thirteen Leeds United fans have been arrested in Munich after chanting "Heil Hitler!" and raising their arms in Nazi salutes.

The men, aged between 19 and 44, were detained on Tuesday night in Munich's Hofbraeuhaus beer garden and will be held until after tonight's Champions League third round qualifying match between Leeds and TSV 1860 Munich.

Under German law, it is illegal to make a Hitler salute, display swastikas and other Third Reich symbols, or to disseminate Nazi propaganda.

A police spokesman said the men, who were wearing Leeds replica shirts and football scarves, had otherwise not misbehaved and there had been no other incidents involving English fans.

The detained supporters would be brought before a court today, he added, but would not be freed to watch the game, which Leeds lead 2-1 after the first leg.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Galliford and Try
fields.trailText: Poor margins and lowly stock market ratings for the construction sector have made consolidation a goal for many players but there has been more talk than action on the merger and acquisition front until lately.
fields.body:
Poor margins and lowly stock market ratings for the construction sector have made consolidation a goal for many players but there has been more talk than action on the merger and acquisition front until lately.

Galliford and Try Group yesterday confirmed plans to merge with the former taking a 51.5% stake in its smaller rival, propelled to fame by its construction work on the number one court at Wimbledon tennis club.

Earlier this month it was Scottish builder Morrison which said it was in talks which could lead to a takeover; Furlong Homes has already been gobbled up.

The City liked the latest deal and marked up Try's shares 3.25p to 31.75p, although Galliford slipped 1.5p to 23.25p. Roger Hardman of research group Hardman and Co said the companies dovetail nicely. Galliford had good construction margins but poor housebuilding margins, while Try had the opposite problem.

Under the terms of the proposed merger, Try shareholders will receive 1.5 new Galliford shares for each Try share they hold. The offer values Try shares at 36.75p.

The combined Galliford Try will have a market capitalisation of £50m and be able to boast greater reach. Galliford had been strong in the north and midlands and Try best known in the south. Clients such as BP Amoco, AstraZeneca and Railtrack look for national reach and the group should also be better placed to take advantage of the government's private finance initiative, so far kind only to Galliford.

Neither side will say how much can be saved that, arguing this is not a cost-cutting story. They would like to participate in further mergers to double their market capitalisation.

The firms are managed well with an eye to the future but the housing market is turning down, public sector deals are slow to materialise and contract cock-ups are a sectoral speciality. Build your portfolio elsewhere.

fields.headline: The National Lottery
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the race for control of those lucky balls
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the race for control of those lucky balls.
fields.body:
1. The new National Lottery operator had been expected to be announced today after six months of secret deliberations.

2. Camelot, the existing operator, and Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, backed by Microsoft, were the two contenders vying to win the licence to run the lottery for the next seven years.

3. But the National Lottery commission announced that neither bidder had secured the franchise.

4. We must now wait another month to know who is to be responsible for collecting the funds for such public treasures as the Millennium Dome.

5. If its bid is successful, Camelot has pledged to invest £1bn in technology which would enable people to play the lottery via the internet, and do away with the fat-cat bonuses which have earned it so much criticism.

6. During its tenure, Camelot has also been reproached for failing to direct as much of the Lottery's profits towards good causes as the government white paper required.

7. In response, Sir Richard has promised that the People's Lottery will be entirely non-profit making.

8. Sir Richard may be unable to get back to Britain in time to see if his altruism has paid off. In a stroke of bad luck which ill befits a prospective lottery winner, Sir Richard found he was unable to leave the holiday island of Necker, where he was staying, because of Hurricane Debby, which was expected to pass over there last night.

9. The Virgin owner isn't the only one to experience lottery-related misfortunes. Bad luck often follows directly on the heels of a lottery win: just look at Harold Dittmer and Peggy Terry Dickson.

10. Sir Richard is by no means the first public figure to have recognised the potential of those lucky balls: Casanova beat him to it when he helped found the French state lottery in Paris in 1757.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: When a player gets selected for England does the FA make any payment for their services - or do they literally play for a cap? asks Mike Wren.
fields.body:
When a player gets selected for England does the FA make any payment for their services - or do they literally play for a cap? asks Mike Wren.

Players are paid - although the FA doesn't like anyone knowing about it. "There is a match fee, but it's not usually disclosed to the media," admitted the unusually sheepish FA librarian David Barber.

However, under sustained LA Confidential-like questioning - OK, we exaggerate - he eventually told us: "It's a substantial four-figure sum, and they get all their expenses as well."

And just in case you're wondering, this isn't a recent trend - there's been a financial reward for playing for England since the late 19th century.

Did the father of Gil Scott-Heron, jazz radical, play for Celtic in the fifties (maybe sixties) and if so for how long and to what effect? asks Greig Aitken

Gilbert Heron began his footballing career in the Canadian Air Force and went on to play for the Detroit Wolverines, Chicago Sting and Detroit Corinthians.

He signed for Celtic in 1951 after scoring twice in an open trial. Heron would only play one league game for the Hoops, however, although he would make four appearances in the Scottish League Cup, scoring two goals. He was released by the club in 1952 and went on to enjoy short spells with Third Lanark and Kidderminster Harriers.

His son - who made his name in 1970 with the superb jazz-funk polemic The Revolution Will Not Be Televised - was recently asked about his father's exploits by Scottish magazine One: "It's a blessing from the spirits. Like that's the two things that Scottish folks love the most; music and football, and they got one representative from each of those from my family. Personally I support Rangers and I'm going to wear my Celtic scarf and Rangers hat when I come over."

Why did the goalkeeper in English teams always used to wear a green shirt? asked Luis Andrade Sa.

"As a goalkeeper is expected to wear a different colour to all 20 field players, and since green was seldom used as the colour of a team's strip, it was an obvious distinctive choice for goalkeepers," says Austin McDermott - an explanation confirmed by the FA's David Barber.

Who was the first black professional footballer? wonders Thomas Daley.

According to Phil Vasili, the first black professional footballer was Arthur Wharton (1865-1930) who played for Sheffield United, Preston North End and Darlington. Arthur was born to parents who were both mixed race (his father was half Grenadian and half Scottish, and his mother was half Scottish and half Fante Royal of the stool family of Ekumfie) and he lived in a Victorian society where cultural Darwinism was rampant.

But Wharton made a mockery of such racial theories. Not only was he the world's first professional footballer (he was on United's books at the same time as the legendary "Fatty" Foulkes), but he also held the world record for the 100 yard dash and was probably the first African to play professional cricket in Britain.

Sadly, Wharton died in poverty and is buried in an unmarked grave in Edlington, near Doncaster. For more information read: 'The First Black Footballer - Arthur Wharton 1865-1930: An absence of Memory' by Phil Vasili.

Why did the East German team play in blue? This isn't a colour traditionally associated with the eastern states, and was hardly the colour of communism. If you could supply an acceptable and conclusive answer (to German intellectual standards!) then I'll for once be able to get my German friends to shut up when they go on about how the English know nothing about German football" wrote James Spackman.

Well James, maybe the Germans are right. Maybe we don't know anything about their football. Because all we've had so far is response is an email from Richard Stacey who says: "Perhaps it has something to do with the fact that there is a colour called "Prussian Blue." Perhaps - or do you know better?

Can you help?

What is Kanu's squad number for Nigeria? I know his Arsenal number is 25 but I'm sure it's different for internationals, reckons Ross Kenny.

Is it possible in a normal game for the goalie to swap positions with one of his outfield colleagues, as is the usual practice in park football? asks Mick Kassim.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

fields.headline: Regulating the arms trade
fields.standfirst: The government will not include a bill to regulate the arms trade in the Queen's Speech. Mark Tran and Patrick Barkham explain the tensions between arms sales and an "ethical foreign policy"
fields.trailText: The government will not include a bill to regulate the arms trade in the Queen's Speech. We explore the tensions between arms sales and an "ethical foreign policy".
fields.body:
Isn't this a blow to Robin Cook's ethical foreign policy?
Absolutely. The foreign secretary has fought hard for parliamentary time for the arms bill, backed by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon. But as the Queen's speech is almost the last before the general election, Labour is concentrating on health, education and crime. Cleaning up the arms trade is not seen as a vote-winner.

What would have been in the bill?
The arms bill, which has already been drafted by the Department of Trade and Industry, would have introduced tighter export controls on arms exports. A white paper on strategic export controls in 1998 proposed "to control the involvement of persons in the UK or UK persons abroad in trafficking and brokering in arms and other controlled goods to any country subject to an embargo". Those breaking the proposed law would be subject to criminal charges.

What is Labour's policy on arms sales?
"Labour will not permit the sale of arms to regimes that might use them for internal repression or international aggression," the party's manifesto promised before its election in 1997. In government, say critics, it has followed a subsequent manifesto pledge more closely: "We support a strong UK defence industry, which is a strategic part of our industrial base as well as our defence effort."

How important are arms sales to Britain?
The sale of arms to foreign countries is big business - and Britain is the second biggest exporter of arms in the world. The latest annual report on British weapons sales records the granting of more than 10,000 export licences in 1998 to a number of countries, including Argentina, China, Colombia, India, Mozambique, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe.

What has Mr Cook said about arms sales?
Mr Cook, who inaugurated an "ethical foreign policy" one month into office, last year reaffirmed the importance of ethical considerations when selling arms. He said that the government "will not issue an export licence if there is a clearly identifiable risk that the proposed export might be used for internal repression" and promised to publish an annual report detailing arms export applications.

But the tension between Labour's two manifesto promises has continued, as demonstrated by rows over the sale of arms to Indonesia and by the issuing of arms export licences to Pakistan.

How are British-made weapons sold to other countries?
Licences to export "strategic goods" are issued by the government's export control agency, which is part of the Department of Trade and Industry. Businesses wanting to export their products fill in a form (they can even do it online). The DTI circulates relevant licence applications to other ministries, such as the Foreign Office and the Department for International Development, before approval is given.

A raft of regulations and guidance notes for exporters restricts the sale of arms or other goods which could be used to make weapons, to regimes embroiled in conflict.

What about export credit guarantees?
The government's export credit guarantee department (ECGD) operates as insurance for British exporters involved in risky export projects. It guarantees that if a foreign country defaults on paying for British goods then the government will recompense the exporter. Last year, more than 50% of ECGD cover supported arms sales.

webTitle: A confused cocktail of sport and politics

fields.headline: A confused cocktail of sport and politics
fields.trailText: Keeping politics out of sport is a worthy concept, but often futile. Mixing the two can be important - take the boycott of South Africa's apartheid regime. At other times, politics enrich sport: the Olympics, for example, are much duller now that the Iron Curtain has fallen. Sport can even aid the political process by bringing countries closer together. Past cricket and hockey tours between India and Pakistan have built bridges, albeit temporary ones, when the two governments have been deadlocked. But India's decision to withdraw from this year's Sahara Cup tournament in Toronto is a case of politicians interfering in sport to no-one's benefit.
fields.body:
Keeping politics out of sport is a worthy concept, but often futile. Mixing the two can be important - take the boycott of South Africa's apartheid regime. At other times, politics enrich sport: the Olympics, for example, are much duller now that the Iron Curtain has fallen. Sport can even aid the political process by bringing countries closer together. Past cricket and hockey tours between India and Pakistan have built bridges, albeit temporary ones, when the two governments have been deadlocked. But India's decision to withdraw from this year's Sahara Cup tournament in Toronto is a case of politicians interfering in sport to no-one's benefit.

A good argument could be put forward for cancelling the tournament on the basis that public confidence and interest in these "offshore" circuses has been lost, and that India and Pakistan, more than others, have done cricket a disservice by accepting meaningless invitation after meaningless invitation. Indeed India would be excused for withdrawing because the team and fans are totally demoralised after a year of failure on the pitch and disgrace off it.

Citing the Kashmir conflict as the reason for withdrawal, as India did last year, simply panders to the rabble-rousers on both sides of the divide. Kashmir isn't a clear-cut issue like apartheid and it has been waxing and waning ever since partition in 1947. If you used the current Indian government's rationale, India and Pakistan would never have played each other. Does that mean that India will pull out if they face Pakistan in the ICC Knock-Out Trophy in Kenya? I doubt it.

The Indian sports ministry wants India's sullied stars out of the team until they are cleared but the cricket board is backing the players and their inclusion.

Sports minister SS Dhindsa has been regularly critical of the board's administration and its soft line on the suspected players. A few weeks ago, the Indian board had assured its Pakistani counterparts that India would be competing in Toronto and touring Pakistan later in the year for a three-match Test series. Now the Test series is in doubt too.

Indian cricket needs unity of purpose from its rulers but the two bodies have shown that they are unable to work together effectively. SS Dhindsa should either let the board get on with its job or, if he believes that it is incompetent, he should appoint officials he can work with and who he thinks are more effective.

While this year's Sahara Cup might have been a folly for obvious reasons, India should have kept politics out of its decision. India's tour to Pakistan will be the first since 1989-90 when all four Tests were drawn. Dhindsa and Co. mustn't be allowed to interfere again. This is a tour that the fans want to see, and cricket can help dismantle political barriers. After all, it is only 18 months ago that a victorious Pakistan side was applauded around the Chidambaram Stadium in Chennai by heartbroken but sporting Indian fans.

webTitle: Man found hanged after British woman vanishes in Japan

fields.headline: Man found hanged after British woman vanishes in Japan
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office was today investigating reports from Japan that a man questioned by police about the disappearance of a young British woman has been found hanged in his apartment surrounded by photographs of her.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office was today investigating reports from Japan that a man questioned by police about the disappearance of a young British woman has been found hanged in his apartment surrounded by photographs of her.

Lucie Blackman, 21, of Sevenoaks, Kent, vanished seven weeks ago while working as a hostess in a bar in Tokyo. A report published today in Weekly Jewel, a Japanese magazine, said that police believed her disappearance was connected with the mysterious death of a 52-year-old man earlier this month in Kanagawa, south of Tokyo.

Friends, neighbours and relatives of the man, who was not been named by the magazine, said he lived a double life. Outwardly he was a respectable and happily married Japanese "salaryman", but he also kept a secret flat filled with hardcore sadomasochistic pornography featuring western women.

The Weekly Jewel said that he had been interviewed by police investigating Lucie's disappearance on August 5. Three days later his body was found in the apartment, half-naked and apparently smeared with excrement.

The single-roomed rented flat contained police posters featuring Lucie's photograph which were used to appeal for information about her disappearance.

The Weekly Jewel said the man found hanged had worked as a manager in the technology division of a famous Japanese firm, which was not named. He was said to be due for promotion, had no debts or any obvious reason to take his own life.

Police in Tokyo today refused to comment on the report, as the investigation was still continuing.

The Foreign Office became aware of the allegations last night. A spokeswoman said: "The Japanese police have told us that they do not want to make a comment, but are aware of the death. We will keep in touch with them, but are not party to all aspects of their investigation." She said that the missing hostess's father, Tim Blackman, was being kept informed about the case.

Mr Blackman, from the Isle of Wight, was flying back to Britain today for a rest after weeks of fruitless appeals. He is expected to return to Japan after a week's break. His youngest daughter, Sophie, 19, was flying to Tokyo today to take his place. Mr Blackman yesterday offered a reward of 1.5m yen (£9,500) for information leading to Lucie's discovery.

Lucie disappeared on July 1 after meeting a man believed to be a customer at the Casablanca bar where she worked. Her best friend and fellow hostess Louise Phillips, of Orpington, Kent, received a phone call the next day from a Japanese man who claimed that Lucie had joined a religious cult. Mr Blackman says he believes this is a red herring and that his daughter was abducted for criminal or sexual purposes.

fields.headline: Vieira to stay with Arsenal
fields.trailText: After 24 hours of persistent rumours to the contrary, it looks this morning as though Patrick Vieira will be staying with Arsenal.
fields.body:
After 24 hours of persistent rumours to the contrary, it looks this morning as though Patrick Vieira will be staying with Arsenal.

The 24-year-old French international has been sent off twice in his first two games for the Gunners this season and, in the face of a five match ban, was thought by many to have played his last game in England.

However, in an interview in this morning's Mirror, Vieira claimed he will not be quitting Highbury. "I can handle it. I will not be driven out", he said. "I am much stronger than that."

Many other papers gave a contrary impression this morning. The Daily Mail suggested that Juventus would renew their summer-long interest in the midfielder, while the Sun interviewed Vieira's close friend Olivier Dacourt who said: "He is finished with the Premiership."

But it now looks as though the man much loved by the Arsenal faithful will pull on the red-and-white shirt again. As Arsene Wenger said this morning: "I don't think he will leave. He is very down and frustrated but he wants to stay because he loves the club."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the rumours caught in bed together
fields.trailText: Boudewijn Zenden's transfer to Lazio is on the verge of collapse after the Italian champions admitted they cannot raise the £8m Barcelona are demanding. Chelsea may make a fresh bid.
fields.body:
Boudewijn Zenden's transfer to Lazio is on the verge of collapse after the Italian champions admitted they cannot raise the £8m Barcelona are demanding. Chelsea may make a fresh bid.

Chelsea and Valencia have both offered Middlesbrough £7.5m for Christian Ziege. The German international isn't interested, though - he's accepted Liverpool's offer of a contract worth £45,000-a-week.

Aston Villa manager John Gregory has denied making a bid for Real Madrid striker Savio. Teamtalk suggest Gregory is more likely to go for Celta Vigo's Benni McCarthy instead.

Celtic and Liverpool are both taking a serious look at Wigan defender Ray Carroll.

Leicester and Sheffield United are locked in battle over the signature of Swedish striker Jones Kusi-Asare. The 20-year-old, who plays for Djurgardens IF, is having trials at both clubs.

Jean-Claude Darcheville, the former Nottingham Forest striker who now plies his trade in France for Lorient, is a target for Charlton.

Ramon Vega doesn't want to move to Celtic. Martin O'Neill has offered £1m for the Spurs defender, but the Swiss international has begged: "I have shown Tottenham a lot of commitment and loyalty. Now they have to do the same to me. I do not want to go."

Everton defender Richard Dunne's £2.5m move to Wimbledon is likely to be resurrected over the weekend. The move fell through over personal terms, but the Dons have made an improved offer.

Newcastle, Middlesbrough and Leicester are tracking FK Bryne's Norwegian U-21 international defender Ragnvald Soma, according to Planet Football. But the player is not at all sure he would enjoy a spell in English football. "Their drinking culture does not tempt me," he told the site. "I don't have a problem with players who take a pint after a game, but when they get blasted and stink of alcohol the next day in training, it is bad for the rest of the team. I haven't experienced this myself yet, but everyone knows it is going on over there. If I had to choose between an English and an Italian club I would definitely go to Italy."

Derby's Jacob Laursen will join FC Copenhagen if the clubs can agree a fee.

Former Chelsea, Tottenham and Rangers striker Gordon Durie is about to sign for Australian club Northern Spirit.

fields.headline: More hardcore films pass censor
fields.trailText: More videos showing hardcore sex have been approved by film censors in the last month than in all of last year, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
More videos showing hardcore sex have been approved by film censors in the last month than in all of last year, it was revealed yesterday.

The British Board of Film Censors last month brought in new guidelines which allowed more explicit scenes of real sex to be shown on films sold through licensed sex shops to adults.

One leading porn film distributor yesterday predicted a rise of up to 50% over the next year in the number of videos sold because the rule relaxation will allow stronger material to be shown.

The rise in the number of titles classed as R18 has been mainly caused by a backlog which built up while the new rules were being drafted, said the board.

In addition, video distributors have starting resubmitting films so as to have scenes reinstated which were cut under the old rules.

Guidelines were changed following a high court ruling against the board for refusing certificates to seven sex films.

Rather than continue the appeals process, the body opted to alter its rules.

Previously banned material which can now be shown includes close-up shots of penetration by penis, finger, tongue or sex toy, ejaculation, oral-genital contact, and masturbation.

Since the changes on July 18 which moved Britain's censorship laws closer to the rest of Europe, the board has given a further 23 R18 ratings, which is two more than were given in the whole of the previous year.

The average number of R18s handed out over the past nine years is around 22, which rep resents less than 1% of the 5,000 video titles handled annually by the board.

An R18 classification is given to a film during which real sex is shown, while simulated sex acts will usually get an 18 rating.

Distributors of hardcore porn films are preparing for increased profits as a result of the relaxed rules.

Gary Campbell, a director of Prime Time, the second largest UK distributor, said the more liberal censorship laws could curtail the black market for sex videos, which was seven times larger than the legal market.

"The punters for years wanted stronger material. Now the material is in line with Europe, demand is going up, which is good as it takes it away from the black market."

Sue Clark, spokeswoman for the board, said no videos had been denied an R18 rating since the new guidelines started: "The industry knows what the guidelines are. They don't put any videos in to be turned down, because it's a waste of their money."

She added that the initial rise in numbers had been anticipated as film companies held back their titles until the situation was clarified.

"We would have expected this because of the backlog which built up as we waited to get the new guidelines through. We deal with over 5,000 titles a year and these videos are only a tiny part of that work."

 A series of films which were refused certificates is to be screened at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London later this year as part of a debate on the future of censorship organised in collaboration with Channel 4.

webTitle: Three bailed in internet banking fraud inquiry

fields.headline: Three bailed in internet banking fraud inquiry
fields.trailText: Three people who were arrested yesterday after one of the first ever police investigations into internet banking fraud have been released on bail.
fields.body:
Three people who were arrested yesterday after one of the first ever police investigations into internet banking fraud have been released on bail.

The suspects were held for questioning after officers from the National Crime Squad swooped on addresses in Buckinghamshire, Bedfordshire and Northamptonshire.

The allegations centre on fraudulent applications made to the internet bank Egg.com. Staff at the bank have worked with police over the last six months to help with the investigation.

Egg said that no money was stolen and customers were not affected. Egg's operations director, Gary Clifton-Marshall, told BBC Radio 5 Live that the alleged fraud related to criminals attempting to establish bogus accounts to access funds. "Fortunately we have robust systems in place that will prevent this taking place," Mr Clifton-Marshall said. "In no way have any of our customers suffered."

Officers seized computer equipment, cash and drugs in the raids, which took place yesterday. An NCS spokesman said the arrests came after an investigation into fraudsters who were targeting internet banks to gain "considerable sums of money". The suspects were bailed for "several weeks", he added.

Egg, which has about 1.1m customers, said that earlier this year "fraudulent applications" were made to the bank in order to obtain money, but there was no breach of security and no money was obtained.

Egg shares fell more than 4% in early trade today but later recovered.

webTitle: BBC sells net stake to America

fields.headline: BBC sells net stake to America
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: e-finance

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday opened the way to a flotation of its commercial internet business after selling a 13.5% stake in the operation to a US venture capital firm for £32.5m.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday opened the way to a flotation of its commercial internet business after selling a 13.5% stake in the operation to a US venture capital firm for £32.5m.

The deals gives the business, comprising Beeb.com and internet service provider Freebeeb.net, a valuation of £240m. That is far lower than some previous estimates and reflects the change in sentiment about internet companies.

Rupert Gavin, chief executive of BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the corporation, said the deal would provide the business with funds to expand while allowing the BBC to retain control. The US firm, TH Lee Global Internet Managers, will have two places on the board of the subsidiary, to be renamed Beeb Ventures.

Investors were invited to come forward last year but Mr Gavin shrugged off the suggestion that the BBC could have achieved a better price had it clinched a deal before the reversal of internet fortunes in March. Cable company NTL and broadcaster Flextech also held talks with the BBC.

"In an uncertain market this is a very good valuation," he said. "It is important that we are retaining the majority of the economic interest."

Mr Gavin said all options would be considered when TH Lee looks to recoup its investment. The typical route for a venture capital firm is a stock market flotation within three to five years of an investment, a move that would need approval from the BBC's board of governors and the government. A flotation would draw claims of creeping privatisation.

Beeb.com made revenues of £2m last year, largely on the back of advertising. It has been putting a series of e-commerce partners in place which will be linked to programme websites. Users are, for instance, offered a CD shopping guide by clicking through to Beeb.com from a Top of the Pops site.

Mr Gavin said there would be clear markers to make users realise they were leaving a public service site and entering a commercial one.

Sharon Pipe, managing director of TH Lee, which has more than $1bn under management, said: "There are few game-changing investment opportunities where you are getting involved with a company which will be the leader in its field. Beeb.com is probably one of them."

The deal does not affect the corporation's public service internet operation which includes the award winning News Online and the recently launched Sport Online which are both licence fee-funded.

One of the first signs of the new funding will be a £7m advertising campaign for the online ventures from September.

webTitle: Pub bomb victim to sue brewery

fields.headline: Pub bomb victim to sue brewery
fields.trailText: A survivor of the Soho pub bombing has been granted legal aid to sue the brewery for failing to warn customers about the risks of  an explosion, it was reported today.
fields.body:
A survivor of the Soho pub bombing has been granted legal aid to sue the brewery for failing to warn customers about the risks of an explosion, it was reported today.

Gerald Wheatley, 49, suffered serious injuries when the bomb ripped through the Admiral Duncan pub in May last year, killing three people.

Bomber David Copeland was convicted of murder at the Old Bailey earlier this year. He denied the charges but admitted causing three explosions.

Copeland began his campaign by targeting Brixton and Brick Lane markets. Amid fears that the bombs had been planted by right-wing extremists, the Metropolitan police warned that gay haunts could also be at risk.

The Admiral Duncan was believed to have received a specific warning that it could be a target, according to The Independent.

fields.headline: Memo from the mandarin
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, casts his eye over our proposals for trade and industry.
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, casts his eye over our proposals for trade and industry.
fields.body:
The problem that the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) faces and has faced for many years is just what its there for. Its a mixture of the interventionist (sometimes positive as the manifesto suggests in relation to what it might do for new technology and the internet), hands off but occasionally desperately reactive (as it was, for instance, in the case of Rover), sometimes exhortatory in encouraging British trade interest whether specific or general, and sometimes regulatory (as in, say, company law and regulation).

There may always be some need for all of these aspects, but the manifesto is wise to suggest that it would be constructive, forward looking and possible to put much more emphasis on the first, coupled with a change of title of the department and maybe hiving some of these other activities to other bodies or agencies.

This would not be old style "picking winners" which on the whole didn't succeed, but a new style involvement and support in leading Britain and British industry into the new economy. This could certainly include the provision in one way or another of support to smaller companies who want to hook in to this area. More support for developments such as solar and wind power, though desirable, seems to be something else and might be better done by some other agency.

Elsewhere the manifesto proposals may be more difficult to deliver for they point up fundamental features of the structure of government. The RIP bill, for instance, does not "belong" to the DTI but to the Home Office, although it could seriously affect industry. Equally, exchange rate policy (and by extension, the euro, and via the Bank of England, interest rates: things of very substantial interest to industry) do not "belong" to the DTI but to the Treasury, which is in fact the real department for industry in all the fundamentals.

What is wanted is not head-on advocacy of one policy or another - and some would argue, in any case, whether in the longest run a lower exchange rate is best for industry - but a forum for sensible discussion in which such matters can be teased out and where the DTI's basic function, representing the interests of business and commerce, can be properly exercised. Some lateral thinking on government machinery is needed here.

fields.headline: SMG casts eye over HTV
fields.standfirst: Share placing's popularity underlines Scottish success story
fields.trailText: SMG, the former Scottish Media Group, yesterday emerged as a potential bidder for the HTV television franchise shaken loose by the most recent round of ITV consolidation.
fields.body:
SMG, the former Scottish Media Group, yesterday emerged as a potential bidder for the HTV television franchise shaken loose by the most recent round of ITV consolidation.

Andrew Flanagan, SMG chief executive, said the company would naturally be interested in HTV, the Wales and western England franchise. Granada needs to sell the business to meet the demands of regulators after acquiring the ITV interests of United News & Media earlier this year.

"ITV is a core business of ours so of course we will be interested in looking at acquiring another part of it," Mr Flanagan said. "The question is price. We don't have unlimited capital and we have to make choices. We would have to compare HTV to our national businesses which give us a broader profile and to those in faster growing markets."

Many had assumed that Carlton Communications, Granada's chief rival, would be the only realistic bidder for HTV, which is expected to be sold for between £400m and £500m.

SMG's determination to expand outside Scotland was also underlined as it raised £45m through a share placing to pursue further acquisitions.

The group, which earlier this year heightened its profile with the takeover of Chris Evans' Ginger Media Group, placed 14.6m new shares which were oversubscribed more than three times. Shares in the group closed 8% higher at 324.5p yesterday.

SMG has been transformed over the past five years from Scottish Television, which owned a single ITV franchise, to a group with interests in cinema advertising, newspapers, posters and radio. The company rebranded earlier this year to reflect the growing amount of business outside of Scotland. "There are probably more strategic options out there now than there have ever been before," Mr Flanagan said. "The share placing will provide us with the financial flexibility to capitalise on opportunities as they arise."

The placing was made as SMG turned in a 37% increase in revenues to £153m for the first half of the year. Pre-tax profits were up 25% at £30m.

Mr Flanagan said the results silenced critics, including the group's largest shareholder, Granada, who had accused SMG last year of overpaying for Ginger. The Ginger deal gave SMG Virgin Radio and made it the sixth largest TV production business in Britain - uniting the likes of the now axed TFI Friday with the company behind detective series Taggart.

"People were criticising that deal without really any knowledge of the company. They were assuming that we were paying £225m for Chris Evans the DJ and TV presenter but that wasn't the case.

"We were paying for the fundamental value of the business. It turns out that Ginger is a far better business than even we had realised."

fields.headline: Losing out in adoption
fields.standfirst: Priority should be given to keeping families together
fields.trailText: Priority should be given to keeping families together
fields.body:
I saw my birth father just the once, at his back gate, as he was driving home from work. I'd been longing to meet him, as his potential emotional assassin, for a good many of my 28 years. It was 1978. I introduced myself to this man as his son from the relationship he'd had when he and my birth mother were both 18. As a five minute conversation, it was one of the more memorable I've had.

With the numbers of missing or absent fathers in Britain, more of these bizarre meetings and conversations are taking place every day, with children, now adults themselves, compulsively setting out on a journey to discover their origins. Not so much The Origin of Species, as the origins of a foetus.

Growing up adopted had its ups and downs. I had a better education in London than I would have done as a child of a shunned single parent in the north-east during the 1950s. On the other hand, I might have met Bobby Charlton on the streets of Ashington. While I am probably better off in material terms, I have no sense of place or community to return to. I always thought I was in the wrong place in a west London suburb, but then so did lots of my mates. We saw the suburbs as a British wilderness, as culturally arctic.

The politics of adoption is just politics. It trades in quick fixes to irreconcilable personal traumas. In my adoption quadrangle, four groups lost out: myself and my adopted sister, who felt deprived of our rightful families (she has different birth parents); my adoptive parents, as we were patently not the answer to their sterile childless marriage, but who did nothing wrong; my birth mother, who was forced to relinquish me or else be banished from her own family and community; and my own family who have had to live with those of my moods directly attributable to a detached and muddled childhood.

If there is one thing I find depressing but predictable about government thinking, whichever party is in power, it is the obsessive kow-towing to adults who want to adopt, and the implicit policy of being seen to maximise their chances of realising their dream, even if nobody else can. The voices of children and birth mothers, and the role of family support in keeping families together, are scarcely audible.

Of course many children are desperate to be adopted, and more children should be settled with secure families rather than drifting hopelessly through the care system. But if it was hard to find the right adoptive families 50 years ago, let's not fool ourselves it's any easier now. The kids are usually older and more disturbed, second-hand children with burned-out engines who disrupt and reject the very love they need to get started again in life.

Many will never be able to let go and trust, however wonderful the adopters. Some will need foster care. Some will need residential care, unfashionable as that has become. Just as many should be placed with relatives as should be placed for adoption. Where do we hear or read of the role of grandparents, aunts and uncles and the post-placement support they need? Or, indeed, of a properly resourced national placements budget which funds what's needed, rather than cash-limited local authority child care budgets which face countless other priorities?

Don't get me wrong. I support present government policy. Setting up a national adoption register to match children with adoptive families is sensible, although placing a child in another part of the country is not as simple as it sounds. Children are often bullied if they arrive at school with a different accent. And we must not return to the days when inner-city children from minority ethnic races and cultures were placed in the middle of white-only areas. The jury will be out for many years yet on whether trans-racial placements work. Some do, but you can't base social policy on a hit-and-miss success rate.

Relationships are changing faster than politics. In some urban school classes, few if any children come from two-parent families. Serial families and temporary households are commonplace. Many children in the care system face a future in which their caseworkers and carers routinely move on, so there is no constant person in their life. Minor legal reforms, and speeding up the adoption process, will make a small difference when the current prime ministerial review is implemented, but a greater challenge will be to find enough carers, whatever their status, for children with exceptional levels of need and disability.

Adoption as an issue is a red herring in terms of the future of British child care provision. The real issue is resource deficits - of carers, of sufficient skilled and trained social care professionals, of post-placement support and of preventative services. Solving those will take more than soundbites.

 Anthony Douglas is executive director of community services for Havering, east London, and chairs the London group of the Association of Directors of Social Services. This article is taken from Inform, the association's journal.

webTitle: An eye on the big picture

fields.headline: An eye on the big picture
fields.standfirst: Terry  Bamford
fields.trailText: Terry Bamford, social care consultant and former executive director of housing and social services at Kensington and Chelsea council.
fields.body:
The modernisation agenda in social services comes after years of growth. Despite the public's perception of cuts, there has been a real increase in spending every year. Ministers have grown increasingly impatient at the failure to translate these increases into visible improvements in services and are issuing more directives.

First, the national priorities guidance set joint priorities for health and personal social services with annual targets. Then the Quality Protects initiative set specific targets for improvement in the lives of looked-after children. These targets were not just annual, but required a three-year improvement programme. Some reappeared in the performance assessment framework with its 48 target areas.

Couple these targets with the approach taken by the joint review process, with its naming and shaming of failing authorities, add in the best value agenda with its own programme of reviews and targets, and one has a truly daunting agenda for change. The national care standards commission will serve as a further check on local authority performance.

The focus for social services is meeting targets, bidding for new money - usually with stringent conditions attached - and preparing the position statements and strategies to meet the demands of the fast-growing legions of auditors and inspectors. Less time is spent on ensuring standards are maintained in old people's homes, day centres and home care. Yet that is precisely where some authorities have failed in the past. It is relatively easy to get funding for new projects, but an uphill struggle to maintain the current level of resourcing for existing services.

The modernisation agenda and the determination of ministers to back policy objectives with hard cash and specific targets is admirable. But they need to appreciate there is a limit to the pace of change. Government is about priorities. The danger in the current torrent of initiatives is that when everything is a priority, nothing really is.

The message for ministers and senior managers alike, is to keep an eye on the big picture - the overall direction of change - and not to get sucked into micro-management. Performance management is about more than targets. It is about establishing clear lines of accountability, giving maximum delegation and setting explicit quality standards. Those simple truths are getting lost in the proliferation of targets.

 Terry Bamford is a social care consultant and former executive director of housing and social services at Kensington and Chelsea council
