webTitle: Tube's chief engineer warns on safety

fields.headline: Tube's chief engineer warns on safety
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: London Underground faces a "deterioration in control over fire safety" and the risk of a significant fire unless action is taken to change the management structures set up for the part-privatisation of the tube, a private memorandum from LU's chief engineer has revealed.
fields.body:
London Underground faces a "deterioration in control over fire safety" and the risk of a significant fire unless action is taken to change the management structures set up for the part-privatisation of the tube, a private memorandum from LU's chief engineer has revealed.

In a sharply worded warning to managers overseeing the break-up of the tube for the partial selloff - which has been passed to the Guardian - Keith Beattie says there does not seem to be any contractual requirement for the private sector companies to ensure safety compliance.

The latest disclosure follows last week's leak of a letter written this month by the government's chief rail inspector, Stanley Hart, which complained of growing concern over safety and "potentially serious consequences" of John Prescott's plans to hand over the tube's infrastructure and maintenance to the private sector.

Officials insisted at the time that the safety problems on the underground were not related to preparations for the public-private partnership, but Mr Beattie's warning - written in March - specifically links the risks to the "shadow running" of the part-privatised structure.

Earlier yesterday, LU's managing director Derek Smith launched a thinly-veiled attack on London mayor Ken Livingstone for "alarmist scaremongering" about the safety risks of the partial selloff - which the government appears determined to force through before it hands control of the underground network to the mayor - and for seeking to "turn the operational foundation of our business into a political football".

A spokesman for LU said safety and operational matters would "always take priority over a media sideshow of out-dated political arguments" and that the issues raised in Mr Beattie's letter were being addressed as part of the "shadow running" process.

But Mr Livingstone said last night of the newly-leaked document: "I am appalled that none of these problems have been brought either to the attention of myself as mayor or the travelling public. Those responsible must now respond to these concerns.

"The health and safety executive has made clear the real issue is that they have lost confidence in London Underground since preparations began for part-privatisation of the tube."

Meanwhile, pressure on the government and London Underground management over tube safety intensified yesterday when it was announced that LU and one of its former signals managers are to be prosecuted by the HSE for allowing dangerous working practices during maintenance work on the Central line.

The prosecution was launched after the safety watchdog found that workers were being exposed to moving trains and the risk of electrocution while repairing the line. An inspector visited Loughton station in Essex last November, the HSE said, and found men working on the track while rails were live.

webTitle: Comment: Russians aren't the only ones who have been telling lie

fields.headline: Perfecting the art of evasion
fields.standfirst:
Russians aren't the only ones who have been telling lies

Special report: Iraq

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Before the current crowing over Moscow's untruths and public relations blunders about the Kursk submarine disaster strays into a hubristic never-never land, a little sober reflection on Britain's own record of official lying is necessary.
fields.body:
Before the current crowing over Moscow's untruths and public relations blunders about the Kursk submarine disaster strays into a hubristic never-never land, a little sober reflection on Britain's own record of official lying is necessary.

Twelve days of deceit and cack-handed public relations from the Russian authorities have certainly fuelled popular anger about the Murmansk tragedy, while western commentators have blamed the legacy of Soviet secrecy.

But it was only last week that British claims about the scale of Serb killings in Kosovo were shown to be false. The death toll was likely to be less than 3,000, war crimes investigators revealed, rather than the 10,000-plus insisted on by the Foreign Office at the time. That followed the leaked internal Ministry of Defence report that most British bombs dropped on Yugoslavia missed their targets, contrary to earlier boasts of devastating accuracy. And last month Lord Gilbert, defence minister during the Kosovo war, told the House of Commons that the Rambouillet terms offered to Serb leaders had been "absolutely intolerable" and designed to provoke war, a proposition ridiculed by the British government last year.

Throughout the past decade, official Anglo-American lies about Iraq have been two-a-penny. During the Gulf war it was said that the al-Amiriya bomb shelter in Baghdad, where hundreds of civilians were incinerated, had been a military command centre; that the pulverised Biladi baby-milk factory was really a biological weapons plant; and that Iraqi soliders in Kuwait had ejected babies from hospital incubators. All these tales were later accepted as untrue. More recently, there was Robin Cook's fictitious story, repeatedly used to shore up Labour support for the Desert Fox bombing campaign against Iraq 18 months ago, that a 16-year-old Iraqi boy had been incarcerated since the age of five for throwing stones at a portrait of Saddam Hussein.

In general, however, British officialdom prefer to avoid what they call "direct lies" wherever possible. Their speciality is the partial disclosure designed to disguise or obscure a larger truth. "Half the picture can be true," Robin Butler, the then cabinet secretary, told the Scott arms-to-Iraq inquiry. Whitehall's attitude was immortalised by Robert Armstrong, Butler's predecessor, as being "economical with the truth".

A textbook case was the presentation of Margaret Thatcher's decision to sink the Belgrano during the 1982 Falklands war when the Argentine cruiser was outside Britain's exclusion zone and sailing away from the islands. It took two years to force Thatcher to admit the damaging truth about when the Belgrano was first sighted.

Nuclear accidents are a prime target for mendacity and cover-ups - as highlighted by the case of the British nuclear submarine, HMS Tireless, damaged earlier this year and now moored off Gibraltar. The Gibraltar government says that it was initially given the impression by the Ministry of Defence that there was "no risk at all" in repairing it in the Rock's harbour. It was later told the risk was "modest". The MoD says it cannot disclose its full safety report for security reasons.

Tony Benn, former energy secretary, said in parliament recently that he had never been told the truth by the nuclear industry - and only found out about the 1957 fire and fallout at Windscale (now Sellafield) years later on a visit to Japan. The scale of the Windscale incident was not officially acknowledged until 1986, the year Chernobyl took over the dubious accolade of the world's worst nuclear accident.

webTitle: Sierra Leone rebels boost peace hopes

fields.headline: Sierra Leone rebels boost peace hopes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) said yesterday, a day after changing its leader, that it would cooperate with UN troops on disarmament, raising hopes of a renewal of the peace process.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone's rebel Revolutionary United Front (RUF) said yesterday, a day after changing its leader, that it would cooperate with UN troops on disarmament, raising hopes of a renewal of the peace process.

An agreement to end Sierra Leone's civil war was signed in Lome in July 1999 but fell apart in May when RUF fighters captured peacekeepers from the United Nations Mission in Sierra Leone (Unamsil).

"The RUF high command calls for the early deployment of Unamsil troops from the sub-region in our areas of operation in Sierra Leone and assures [the UN] of our readiness to cooperate with them in order to ensure the success of the DDR [disarmament] programme in particular and the peace process in general," the RUF said in a statement.

On Monday, the Sierra Leone government announced that the RUF had chosen battlefield commander Issa Sesay as leader, replacing Foday Sankoh who is under arrest and faces trial for human rights offences.

The news was relayed to Mr Sankoh on Monday by the presidents of Nigeria and Mali, acting as mediators, and they said he had accepted the move.

The RUF high command pledged in its statement, issued in Monrovia, capital of Liberia, to work with the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) to achieve peace in Sierra Leone.

It said it hoped the Sierra Leone government would "fulfil its total obligations under the Lome accord". That agreement brought the RUF into government, giving Mr Sankoh the status of vice-president.

But the disarmament process proved slow and the RUF still controlled much of the country, when the fighting broke out in May.

President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah pledged to release 171 RUF fighters in response to the replacement of Mr Sankoh and called on the new RUF leadership to cooperate on the disarmament programme.

Government forces, backed by a more muscular approach from the UN, have forced the RUF onto the defensive in recent weeks.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival: A powerful new female Hamlet

fields.headline: So the prince was really a princess ...
fields.standfirst:
A powerful new Hamlet suggests that women are better equipped to convey the emotional depths in Shakespeare's troubled hero. By Michael Billington

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: A powerful new Hamlet suggests that women are better equipped to convey the emotional depths in Shakespeare's troubled hero.
fields.body:
Hamlets come in all shapes and sizes. They can be lean and attenuated like David Warner and Jonathan Pryce. They can be short and mercurial like Mark Rylance and Anton Lesser. They can be mellifluously poetic like Michael Pennington and Derek Jacobi or prosaically brutal like Nicol Williamson. But two of the more unusual Hamlets are about to be unveiled: at the National Theatre we have a Hamlet in the pleasingly rotund shape of Simon Russell Beale, while at the Edinburgh festival the role is taken by Angela Winkler, a sinuous German brunette.

No one need be surprised by the idea of a female Hamlet: women have been playing the Prince for generations. I saw Frances de la Tour make a vigorous Hamlet at the Half Moon; if anything, she underplayed the character's femininity. No such accusation was levelled at Sarah Bernhardt's Hamlet, which arrived at the Adelphi in 1899 and which Max Beerbohm described as "très grande dame". Before that, in England, there was the obscure Mrs Bandmann Palmer, who toured the Northern circuits and, according to JC Trewin, was said to have acted with melodramatic force, "though because of rheumatism she had trouble rising from her knees". On screen in 1920 there was the Danish actress Asta Nielsen, who revealed that Hamlet was actually a woman reared as a boy for dynastic reasons.

Winkler is not only the latest in a long line: she's a great actress in her own right. She was part of Peter Stein's original Berlin Schaubuhne company in the 1970s, has been in many European films and became the mesmeric centre of Peter Zadek's Berliner Ensemble production of Pinter's Moonlight. As Bel, the wife of bedridden Andy, she was full of sensuous affection and extra-sensory intelligence. While soothing her dying husband, she seemed strangely alert to the ethereal presence of their daughter and registered anguish at the suffering of their estranged sons. Even the dead and departed became for her a living presence.

That is clearly a prerequisite for anyone playing Hamlet; and Winkler's performance, which I caught in Hanover on its last stop before Edinburgh, is characterised by its extra ordinary imaginative sympathy and emotional directness. Winkler makes no obvious attempt to impersonate a man. She wears tights, a long black smock that comes down to her knees and retains her own long hair that she frequently brushes out of her eyes. She does not adopt a surface maleness; instead she absorbs Hamlet's emotions into her own personality.

Oscar Wilde said there is no such thing as Shakespeare's Hamlet. What he meant is that the role is coloured by the individuality of each particular performer. And what Winkler brings out - in a way that no man I have ever seen quite has - is Hamlet's enormous capacity for love, a capacity that is constantly baffled and frustrated. With the Ghost, whose presence is announced by jangling finger-bells, Winkler is all filial devotion. Her passion for Annett Renneberg's much-abused Ophelia is also palpable and explicit: during the Play scene they sit together endlessly fondling and stroking each other. Even Hamlet's asperity towards Gertrude is offset by Winkler's affection: in the closet scene she nuzzles her mother's breast as if seeking reassurance and warmth. But Winkler's unused capacity for love is not exclusively sexual: in the course of the duel, she offers her hand to Laertes with courtly grace, only to find herself cruelly rebuffed.

Cross-gender casting works in a variety of ways. Men, I've noticed, delight in identifying with women and in highlighting a skittish sexiness: that was certainly true of Adrian Lester's Rosalind and Mark Rylance's Cleopatra. Women, instead of impersonating maleness, universalise the character: that certainly applies to Vanessa Redgrave's Prospero and now Winkler's Hamlet. But Winkler also suggests that the consequence of Hamlet's thwarted love is a desperate desire to communicate. In consequence the soliloquies are delivered downstage with Winkler desperately raking the front stalls in order to make eye contact. It's as if, in the dislocated world of Elsinore, we become her only friends: the only people to whom she can unburden her inmost thoughts. Winkler fully vindicates the idea of a female Hamlet: she proves that solitude, despair, ethical doubts about revenge and a sense of betrayed love are qualities that transcend gender.

I suspect the real controversy in Edinburgh will rage not around her performance but around Zadek's production. He's a brilliantly unorthodox director who has the capacity to scrape off the barnacles of Shakespearean tradition. I recall a German Merchant of Venice he brought to Edinburgh in which Gert Voss's besuited, merchant-banker Shylock was barely distinguishable from the Christians. I remember with even greater pleasure his witty, subversive Antony and Cleopatra in which Voss and Eva Mattes (the Gertrude in Hamlet) played the leads as outrageous narcissists slapping on their makeup before going into battle.

Zadek's Hamlet is similarly unromantic. He has moved a long way from CE Montague's vision of the play as "a monstrous Gothic castle of a poem full of baffled half-lights and glooms". Instead, the basic set is an industrial container, a huge, metallic rectangular box that swivels round to reveal the varying facets of Elsinore. It is pragmatic, functional and deliberately un-beautiful. But, however one responds to the set, Zadek has an enormous capacity for animating individual characters and scenes. I've never before seen an Ophelia so incessantly mauled and pawed by father and brother as if she were a sexual toy. Zadek also solves the perennial problem posed by the Play scene: why on earth does it take Claudius so long to realise its dangerous content? Zadek answers the question by treating it initially as knockabout drag comedy, all twanging bra straps and galumphing movement, that only gradually turns into sinister mimicry of reality.

This is a deeply German Hamlet: one that strips the play of its romantic accretions and offers a running directorial commentary as well as a full-blooded realisation. But at its heart lies an astonishing performance by Winkler. She gives us hints of Hamlet's ferocity, not least in her feral snarls, and of his manic-depressive moods: on "the play's the thing" Winkler leaps in the air as if she has cracked an insoluble problem. But, above all, she proves that Hamlet as a role depends less on the particularities of gender than on the width of sensibility. I've seen many more lethal Hamlets than Winkler's but few so endowed with such generosity of spirit or largeness of heart.

Hamlet is at the Royal Lyceum, Edinburgh (0131-473 2000), from August 30-September 2.

webTitle: Putin faces fury of the Kursk crew's families

fields.headline: Putin faces families' fury
fields.standfirst:
Wives accuse Russian leaders of leaving Kursk survivors to die
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin travelled north to the mourning naval garrison of Vidyayevo in the Arctic Circle last night to face the grief and fury of the widows and relatives of the 118 crewmen of the Kursk nuclear submarine.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin travelled north to the mourning naval garrison of Vidyayevo in the Arctic Circle last night to face the grief and fury of the widows and relatives of the 118 crewmen of the Kursk nuclear submarine.

Mr Putin, who has been maintaining an ill-judged low profile for the past 10 days, declared today a day of mourning.

He had earlier flown into the closed naval base of Severomorsk outside Murmansk. The media were kept away to avoid more adverse publicity for a president whose prestige has taken a hammering because of his response, widely seen as inadequate, to a disaster that has transfixed and engaged the compassion of all of Russia.

Later Russian television showed him meeting the widow of the commander of the Kursk. Dressed in a black suit, and a casual black shirt, he was shown talking sombrely with Irina Lyachin before leaving to see wives and relatives of the crew.

Earlier, Irina Belozorova, 32, whose navy captain husband Nikolay perished in the Kursk and who lives with her 10-year-old son Alexei on the Vidyayevo base, had been relishing the chance of telling Russia's president what she thought of him.

"I'll just tell him how glad I am that I didn't vote for him. He's not a president. He's just a stooge," she said bitterly.

Some 500 distraught relatives of the dead seamen have arrived in Vidyayevo for the grieving rituals, many of them refusing to accept Monday's official announcements that all the crew were dead. They had been lied to by the authorities for more than a week.

Yekaterina Bagryantseva, widow of Captain Vladimir Bagryantseva, the chief of staff of the northern fleet's seventh submarine division and the most senior officer to go down with the Kursk, said relatives were being callously treated by the authorities in Vidyayevo.

"Putin has got nothing to say to us. He can't bring my husband back," she said in Murmansk before returning to the garrison, situated in an Arctic fjord, last night.

"Officers have told us there are still people alive down there. The first and the ninth sections [of the submarine] are flooded, but the other sections are not. The officials are lying. None of us believes them. They just don't want to save them because they don't have the money. They don't even have the money to pay the Norwegian divers. Russians are strong and so are our boys. They're still alive, but the government doesn't want any witnesses to this tragedy. It wants them dead."

As special services were planned for today and Mr Putin prepared to board the battleship Peter the Great at the site of the disaster, Mrs Bagryantseva's sister Marina said: "When they declare a day of mourning in this place, it just means they want to forget about us the next day."

Mrs Belozorova said she would not go out to the Barents Sea to the disaster site. "None of us wants to go there. I'm not going to wear black. I don't believe they're dead."

Access to Vidyayevo and to Severomorsk was strictly restricted. Only Russian state television was allowed to distribute film of the president arriving. Mr Putin,was shown disembarking and shaking hands with top admirals.

With the president under unprecedented attack, Patriarch Aleksy, head of the Russian Orthodox Church, made an unusual attempt to defend him - saying, in a TV address that he knew how painful the tragedy had been for Mr Putin.

But the Kremlin's mishandling continued. It was left to Norway to declare first the Kursk lost and yesterday Norwegian seamen were the first to scatter wreaths on the Barents Sea before sailing home.

Ilya Klebanov, the deputy prime minister who Mr Putin put in charge of the government inquiry, left himself a hostage to fortune when he assured a crowd of distraught wives: "We're not leaving here until we get everyone out [of the submarine]. I promise you."

Mr Putin yesterday put another deputy prime minister in charge of a commission to look after the crewmen's families. Mrs Bagryantseva said each of the Vidyayevo families was receiving 1,000 roubles (£25).

fields.headline: Polar data left unused
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Data from top secret navy submarine missions under the North Pole holding vital clues to the nature and speed of global warming could end up lying unused because scientists have not been given the money to finish analysing it.
fields.body:
Data from top secret navy submarine missions under the North Pole holding vital clues to the nature and speed of global warming could end up lying unused because scientists have not been given the money to finish analysing it.

In an unprecedented act of openness about one of its murkiest areas of operations, the Ministry of Defence has released sonar measurements of Arctic ice thickness taken by nuclear submarine crews during eight previously unreported polar voyages. The data was given this year to Peter Wadhams, of the Scott Polar Research Institute, in Cambridge, who has accompanied nuclear sub crews on other journeys below the Arctic ice.

Together with data already analysed from US navy subs, the new figures would give climate experts a powerful tool to quantify the impact of man-made warming on the global environment. They expect to be able to confirm scientists' fears that, largely due to global warming, the ice pack is vanishing, and the Arctic basin could be completely ice-free in summer by 2050.

But the government has given Dr Wadhams only half the money that he needs to turn the raw data into usable information.

"Up till now, instead of having data for every year, we've had gaps," Dr Wadhams said. "So when we see a thinning of the ice it's possible for people to say that, in the missing years, it got thicker again.

webTitle: Job loss fears as Harland and Wolff faces cash crisis

fields.headline: Job loss fears as Harland and Wolff faces cash crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast said last night that it was facing a financial crisis, triggering expectations that hundreds more redundancies will be announced at a politically sensitive time.
fields.body:
Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast said last night that it was facing a financial crisis, triggering expectations that hundreds more redundancies will be announced at a politically sensitive time.

The yard recently lost a first round court case over a £23m unpaid bill and has no large contracts left for its 1,000 workers. It is running up losses of £2.5m a month being paid for by its Norwegian parent group Fred Olsen Energy.

Harland and Wolff is one of the biggest employers in Northern Ireland and its problems come as the province faces increased violence and social instability.

Yard officials blamed its precarious position on an American rig owner which is refusing to pay a £23m instalment. A spokesman for the ship and rig builder said: "Our company is in a critical financial position because of the actions of Global Marine in not paying for the second of two drillships we built for them." He refused to say whether further job losses were now inevitable on top of the cuts in the staff that were made earlier this summer. "No decisions have yet been made," the spokesman said. But Peter Williamson, regional secretary for the AEEU union said: "The situation is extremely serious. Substantial job losses are inevitable." He expects a board meeting of Fred Olsen Energy in Oslo to confirm redundancies.

Fred Olsen, whose family is the major shareholder in Fred Olsen Energy, met union officials from the GMB and AEEU at the yard on Monday. Both sides expressed concern at the escalating problems facing a yard which has rarely made profits and has been riddled with problems since it was privatised in the 1980s.

Nowegian industry analysts say Fred Olsen is becoming increasingly frustrated by the Belfast yard and is under pressure to sell it off. In July Fred Olsen Energy issued a profit warning saying Harland and Wolff would produce an £8m net loss in the second quarter and 254 employees left the yard in June. Yard management hopes to firm up orders for four ferries worth £300m and has letters of intent for two cruise ships worth £200m. The yard is also battling to win roll-on roll-off ship orders from the MoD.

A year-long legal tussle between Harland and Wolff and Global Marine came to a head two weeks ago when a High Court judge ruled the US company could remove the rig from the yard.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith's daily dose
fields.standfirst:
News from the fringe

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: News from the fringe
fields.body:
Simon Munnery's show is magnificent and funny. I saw it in the company of, among others, an art critic and a conceptual artist. Neither of them went to a lot of comedy and were probably of the opinion that comics have nothing to say to the art world. It's just knob-gags and ideas sacrificed on the altar of the punchline. They were gobsmacked by Simon's show, which contained more original, radical thoughts in 10 minutes than a lot of hyped-up Britart conceptualists manage in a career. They were forced to concede that many conceptual artists are just comedians who aren't good enough to get laughs. They were forced to concede this partly, I admit, because they're staying at my flat, drinking my whisky, eating my Scottish plain, and are therefore obliged to agree with me about everything. But I think they meant it anyway.

Lizzy Roper, who has just bought me a pint and a Scotch, tells me about the show she has devised: "An extraordinary comic monologue by a man trapped in a house with his lesbian mother and obsessed with Jonathan Swift. Alan Bennett on acid." Regular readers (Mr S Smith of Bath) will know I disapprove of this last phrase, but of course I am corrupt. Simon Munnery, you owe me £12.

You can contact Arthur Smith via arts@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Loyalist Adair back in prison
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson orders arrest to maintain public safety

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
Johnny Adair, the notorious loyalist paramilitary leader
who orchestrated the violent feuding in Belfast, was
arrested last night and sent back to prison in an
attempt to calm the atmosphere in Northern Ireland.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and Jamie Wilson  in Belfast
fields.body:
Johnny Adair, the notorious loyalist paramilitary leader who orchestrated the violent feuding in Belfast, was arrested last night and sent back to prison in an attempt to calm the atmosphere in Northern Ireland.

In a well coordinated operation, Adair was arrested on the Shankill Road by armed RUC officers who surrounded his car just after 8.30pm. Adair was taken to Maghaberry prison, where he can be held without a court appearance, after the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, ruled that the former Maze prisoner had breached his licence.

Mr Mandelson, who had proclaimed that he would move against Adair if the RUC linked him to renewed terrorism, said that he had acted to protect the public.

"My priority is public safety and I cannot give freedom to an individual intent on abusing it," he said. "I am satisfied that this particular individual has breached the terms of his licence."

Under the terms of the Good Friday agreement, which sanctioned the early release of paramilitary prisoners, former inmates can be returned to prison if they take part "in the commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism".

The arrest of Adair, one of the most ruthless commanders of the Ulster Defence Association, was the culmination of a carefully planned security operation which followed intensive talks between Mr Mandelson and his security advisers. Hundreds of RUC officers swamped the lower Shankill estate where Adair lives.

Police in riot gear blocked off all the roads and alleyways surrounding Adair's terraced house, while the army set up road blocks at the end of the Shankill Road.

One resident said: "They came in so fast we did not know which direction they were coming from. It was unbelievable. They just beat everybody back off the street and into their houses."

Late last night the police operation in and around Mr Adair's terraced house on Boundary Row was continuing. A crowd of between 60 and 70 had gathered on the green at one end of the street which was blocked off at both ends by RUC Land Rovers and police in riot gear.

Mr Mandelson's decision to order Adair's arrest became inevitable after Adair flouted his licence conditions by appearing amid gunmen at a UDA rally over the weekend and by openly orchestrating the loyalist feud. The violence has left two men dead and several injured.

However, Adair's arrest will anger UDA members who have frequently threatened to break their six-year-old ceasefire.

John White, the chairman of the UDA's political wing, said that Adair's arrest would "exacerbate and inflame" ten sions. Speaking outside Adair's house after the arrest, Mr White said: "I think the police have made a mistake in rearresting Mr Adair. If they are accusing him of orchestrating the recent troubles he will be able to do that from inside prison as well as out. They have taken a big risk."

Adair's loyalist opponents also voiced fears about his arrest. Billy Hutchinson, a spokesman for the political wing of the rival Ulster Volunteer Force, said he feared the feud would escalate.

"I think the feud will now in tensify and I'd expect attacks against our party and the UVF," he said.

Mr Mandelson strongly defended his decision to order the arrest of Adair, nicknamed "Mad Dog" and a former commander of the UDA in Belfast, who was freed from the top security Maze prison last September after serving five and a half years of a 16-year sentence for directing terrorism. Mr Mandelson said that the RUC had presented him with clear evidence that Adair was directly involved in terrorism.

"The people of Belfast do not want to live under the heel of gangsters and thugs who use old-style paramilitary methods for their own ends," he said. "It is time for all of us to confront the dark side of Northern Ireland's society, the Mafia culture created by decades of paramilitary conflict."

Mr Mandelson, who said that Adair would be detained indefinitely, said nobody in Northern Ireland was "untouchable".

Before the arrest, an uneasy peace descended on Belfast after regular troop patrols resumed for the first time in two years following Monday's dou ble murder by the UVF. Five men were being questioned last night, although this was not believed to be in connection with the murder of the UDA member Jackie Coulter and his friend, Bobby Mahood.

As the troops resumed patrols, the government held intensive talks with the paramilitaries' political groups with the hope of brokering a truce. However, there is little chance of an imminent breakthrough.

webTitle: Cervical cancer three times more likely in poor

fields.headline: Cervical cancer three times more likely in poor
fields.trailText: Women from poorer backgrounds are three times more likely to contract cervical cancer than those from affluent homes, according to a report.
fields.body:
Women from poorer backgrounds are three times more likely to contract cervical cancer than those from affluent homes, according to a report.

The study, by researchers at Glasgow University and Leicester Royal Infirmary, also found that women from more deprived areas tended to suffer from a more aggressive form of the disease, with faster growing tumours.

The research, which will be published in the British Journal of Cancer, has concluded that unhealthy diets and smoking are partly to blame and said it was vital for women to have regular smear tests and to increase their intake of fresh fruit and vegetables.

There are 300 new cases of cancer of the cervix every year in Scotland.

Researchers say that vitamins in fruit and vegetables mop up harmful and potentially cancer-causing chemicals, and smoking reduces the levels of betacarotene, which prevents a virus present in many women from growing into cancer cells.

Professor David Hole, one of the report's authors, said: "Certainly the role of vitamins and betacarotene, which are the substances we get from fresh fruit and vegetables, might be quite important in controlling the rate at which these tumours grow."

Professor Hole said the study, which was funded by the Scottish Office home health department, was set up to establish why some patients had larger tumours, and looked at issues such as diagnostic delay or a delay in patients seeking help. The research team found that the speed at which the tumour grows was more important than delay, and women from the less affluent areas had tumours that grew more rapidly.

He said the study may provide a model for other types of cancer. "The research is significant in that it should change the emphasis away from delay to an attempt to try to understand how these tumours grow so rapidly," he said.

"The message for women is still to get regular smear tests and go to your GP if you have any symptoms. Also, boost your fruit and veg intake; and here's another reason to kick the cigarette habit."

Professor Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, welcomed the study, which he said put the emphasis on a message the charity was keen to get across. "This important work reinforces the campaign's main anti-cancer messages: eating a well-balanced diet with five pieces of fresh fruit or vegetables a day and stopping smoking will help prevent cancer."

A total of 177 cervical cancer patients in the west of Scotland took part in the study over a 20 month period.

fields.headline: Bidding for the big prize
fields.standfirst: Branson's day of reckoning
fields.trailText: People's Lottery
fields.body:
People's Lottery

Richard Branson, the figurehead of the People's Lottery, will be one of six non-executive members of the People's Lottery board. His team will include Don Cruickshank, the chairman of Scottish Media Group who led an investigation into competition between banks, and Caroline Marland, outgoing managing director of Guardian Newspapers. Michael Blakenham, John Jackson and Henry King are also on the board.

US lottery operator AWI, rivals of GTech, Camelot's American operators, are on Branson's list of operators. The team also includes KPMG Consulting, Energis, Compaq, Kelloggs, Microsoft and Cisco, who will supply the technology, and advertising agency J Walter Thompson. According to Mr Branson, suppliers will not be shareholders.

The People's Lottery has pledged to create 2,500 new millionaires and raise more than £15bn, all the profits, for good causes.

The game under Branson would change to a six balls out of 53 system instead of the present 49. They say this will create eight double and two triple rollovers a year and that the chances of winning £1m will become 1 in 3m with them, compared to 1 in 14m with Camelot.

Camelot

Camelot says it will raise at least £15bn for good causes as well as setting up a new promotional body to raise awareness of national lottery funding.

It will introduce at least four new on-line games and will keep the current standard game, Thunderball and Instants.

It claims that by 2002 players will be given a wider choice of games and ways to play, including on the internet, mobile phones and interactive TV.

One thousand new retail outlets will be included and £1bn will be be spent on new technology, terminals, marketing and infrastructure.

Shareholders' profit will be reduced to around 0.5p in every £1 and executive director's pay will be reduced by a third and special bonuses will be abolished.

Camelot says non-cash prizes will be added including a possible trip to the moon. The public will also be canvassed for new games ideas.

The shareholders are Cadbury Schweppes, De La Rue, Racal Electronics and ICL. If the bid is successful, the Post Office will take a one-fifth stake.

The team running the new operation include Dianne Thompson who joined Camelot in 1997 from the Signet Group as chief executive.

webTitle: Ed Vaizey: Tories uneasy over developments in Northern Ireland

fields.headline: We Tories are uneasy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The recent release of 80 Northern Ireland convicted criminals in a single week was rightly condemned by the Tories.
fields.body:
The recent release of 80 Northern Ireland convicted criminals in a single week was rightly condemned by the Tories. Michael Ancram, the Tory chairman and a man well-versed in the politics of Ulster, has called for the two most prominent released loyalist prisoners to be put back behind bars. Defence spokesman Iain Duncan Smith once again voiced Conservative party concern about prisoner releases.

But the Tories are in a double bind as far as the peace process is concerned. Not only are they hemmed in by the bipartisanship that has characterised this latest attempt to answer the Irish question. They also have an awkward relationship with unionism and Ulster. The party has bred some of unionism's most articulate defenders, such as Ian Gow and Enoch Powell. Today, there are still many Tory journalists, MPs and thinkers who are passionate supporters of the union. At the same time, the Tory party has to acknowledge that it has played its full part in appeasement, from the secret Whitelaw talks with the IRA in the 70s, through to Thatcher's Anglo-Irish agreement and Major's Downing Street declaration which led directly to prisoner releases.

The Tories are having to think hard and fast about Ulster. It is an issue that is breaking out again, and may be prominent at their conference this year. Recently the Tories have been thrown a challenge from the right of their party. The Centre for Policy Studies, still the foremost Conservative thinktank, has published a pamphlet called The Price of Peace. Its author is Michael Gove, the biographer of Portillo and an articulate polemicist of the right. He argues that the peace process has taken us down a dangerous and erroneous path.

Among the Tories there is a mood for a harder line on the peace process. Many who originally felt concern have had their fears confirmed by the hijacking of the peace process to Blairism and the attendant political correctness which the Tories love to hate and are keen to highlight. Gove gives grist to his audience's mill in this regard, focusing on the work of the Northern Ireland Human Rights Committee and its concern for the right of transsexuals. Blair's Ulster has become a microcosm of Blair's Britain, a land of less RUC and more PC.

Gove's thesis goes wider. It deserves to be considered seriously by liberals and conservatives alike. The peace process has seen democracy subverted by violence. We have had the concession that terrorists should be allowed to take part in elections. We have had the further erosion that they should do so without promising to renounce violence or decommission any weapons.

Gove's analysis shows that, in an effort to achieve "balance" and "representation", the system of designating parties as nationalist or unionist entrenches sectarianism and will prevent the development of parties of the left or the right. The further guarantee of ministerial portfolios for all parties in the assembly enforces a coalition that the people have not necessarily voted for, and removes from these ministers any sense of accountability.

The solution, in Gove's eyes, is to abandon the peace process and substitute for it a strategy of "resolute security action"; the ending of prisoner releases; the banning of any party still associated with the principle of violence from participation in the peace process. More broadly, he shows the dangers inherent in appeasement. It is one thing to seek peace, another to put into effect methods of government that one would not contemplate elsewhere in one's country. Peace may be achieved in the short term, but at the price of the long-term infection of the body politic.

Gove's thesis is not for everyone. But it is a timely reminder of the implications of short-term decisions, ill-thought-out compromise and the belief that only one path can be followed. The reason that Gove's analysis will play so well with the Tories is that it echoes both the appeasement process of the 30s and the appeasement of the 21st century, namely the inevitable march to the euro.

There is a case for a principled politician to condemn the peace process. There is room for a broad cross-party consensus. The trouble is that most of us do not think long or deeply about Ulster. For many English people it is and will remain a foreign land. It will not feature in any opinion polls' top 10 issues that concern voters. Most people are glad that the bombing has stopped on the mainland. And every day that this remains the case the peace process will command public support.

For these reasons, expect the Tories to continue to snipe, but not to perform a volte-face.

fields.headline: All that glisters
fields.standfirst:
Andrew Clements applauds Scottish Opera's cheap and cheerful Rheingold

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements applauds Scottish Opera's cheap and cheerful Rheingold.
fields.body:
A new Ring for the Edinburgh Festival, the first in Scotland for more than 30 years, and the omens are very good. Scottish Opera got halfway through a cycle in the early 90s, but a lack of funds forced its abandonment; the future of this one, though, commissioned by the festival and sponsored by the Bank of Scotland, seems far more secure. After this Rheingold, Die Walküre and Siegfried will be presented at the festival in the next two years; the last instalment, Götterdämmerung, will open in Scottish Opera's spring season in 2003, with two complete cycles to follow at that summer's festival.

The finance may be in place, then, but that doesn't mean this is a lavish, no expense-spared production, far from it. The director Tim Albery and designer Hildegard Bechtler have come up with a spare, airy concept, made up of a number of discreet elements that doubtless will return again in different guises: no prizes for predicting that the huge slab of slate on which Wotan and his wife Fricka are sleeping at the opening of the second scene of Rheingold might well serve as Brunnhilde's rock in Walküre and Siegfried, for instance, or that the carapace-like flats, speckled with the night sky on one surface, which are deployed to define the different spaces of the gods and the Nibelungs here, will fulfill the same role in future instalments. But it all works, that's the main thing; the action moves lucidly, Albery's production maintains a tight grip of the narrative and on the importance of what every character is saying at every moment, while the stage pictures are often elegantly beautiful.

The Rhinemaidens, real temptresses in stockings and suspenders, cavort in a Rhine suggested by abstract, translucent waves, around which they lead the bespectacled, bedraggled Alberich a merry dance. A skyscraper Valhalla gleams in a display case when Wotan is trying to wriggle out of his contract with the giants Fasolt and Fafner, who arrive in a silhouette head, their faces visible through its eye-holes; when Fafner murders his partner in the final scene, one eye shuts. The transformations are simply achieved - a monstrous claw appears around the edge of the proscenium when Alberich turns himself into a dragon - and though there is no rainbow bridge for the Gods' entrance into Valhalla, a series of gorgeously lit cubicles descend, into which they all solemnly arrange themselves like a Greek frieze.

Within this framework, every character is sharply defined. The gods are beskirted; Wotan sports a jacket and tie above his, and when Alberich is wielding his power through the ring he dares to wear one too. Loge, half god, half man, is a cross between Rupert Bear and Doctor Who; the giants are warehouse men, with Fasolt as shop steward determined to get a fair deal for their labours. Every image is thoughtful, and potent, nothing jars or intrudes, nothing is fussy.

There's no fussiness in the performance either. Richard Armstrong conducts a fleet, lively performance, quite devoid of bombast or unnecessary rhetoric; he makes it clear that Rheingold is the beginning of a long musical journey, and the real weight and depth are to come later, and provides a flexible, supportive platform for this very musical cast.

There are no great Wagnerian voices on show here, though Matthew Best, as a wracked and devious Wotan might well mature into one. Peter Sidhom's Alberich is both sly and wretched, more than usually sympathetic, Anne Mason's handbag-wielding Fricka is not to be denied. Peter Bronder's Loge, a gift of a part, makes every acidulated aside count; Inka Rinn, Marianne Anderson and Leah Marian Jones are a suitably sexy trio of Rhinemaidens, Carsten Stabell and Markus Hollop an all-too-believable pair of jobs-worth giants. Solid, intelligent performances all round, and a very good start to a project that promises more riches and insights to come.

At the Edinburgh Festival Theatre (0131-473 2000) tonight, Saturday, and Monday, then touring in the autumn.

webTitle: Comment, Polly Toynbee: The United States has become insufferable

fields.headline: The lesson from America is that Europe is our only hope
fields.standfirst:
The United States has become insufferable as it has grown all-powerful

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The United States has become insufferable as it has grown all-powerful.
fields.body:
The land of the free now wields an absolute power, free of responsibility, such as the world has never known. The rest of the globe watches its elections with renewed anguish as powerless spectators and demi-subjects. The two conventions displayed all that is most repugnant and alien in a political system corrupted beyond recognition in the democratic world.

The $100m campaigns lift off in an obscene haze of sanctimonious, lachrymose religiosity, oozing family unction and lies. With 77 days to go and contenders neck and neck in the polls, George W Bush says that Jesus is his guiding influence, Al Gore and Joe Lieberman share a prayer with reporters and both campaigns promise instant gratification and no sacrifice for anything or anyone ever. Dishonest fantasy politics turn America into an out-of-control, self-absorbed, infantilised monster.

The richer, stronger and more globally unaccountable America becomes, the more self-centred its politics grows. The end of the cold war should have brought great psychological dividends. Generous in global victory, free of paranoia and with wealth beyond imagining, here at last was its chance to become what it has always believed itself to be - the brave, the beautiful, the free and so on.

The high-flown rhetoric of the conventions is echoed in every high school valedictory speech, in every rotary and church, pledging allegiance to a constitution that has lost any vision of society beyond the pursuit of happiness. God's chosen people, uniquely blessed, nurture a self-image almost as deranged in its profound self-delusion as the old Soviet Union. The most advanced, knowledgeable, educated, psychoanalysed, therapised nation on earth knows nothing of itself, irony-free and blind to the world around it.

This is the indictment:

 Global warming: both poles are now melting and the process can never be stopped or reversed without America. The US federal government report on climate change itself predicted a 5-10C heat increase this century, with attendant fires, droughts and floods. A quarter of the world's population consumes 80% of its energy, most in the US. At Kyoto the US agreed to a very modest 7% cut in emissions by 2010. Congress refused to ratify it and since then America's emissions have increased by over 20%.

The Republicans deny the cause of global warming, Democrats say nothing of cuts. As a result other countries are now sliding out of Kyoto promises, finding loopholes. Why should politicians in France or Germany take huge political pain in demanding cuts from their voters when the monster across the Atlantic goes on guzzling? With global power should come global responsibility to lead, but it doesn't.

 Defence: Congress's refusal to sign the comprehensive test ban treaty last October virtually urges others to acquire their own weapons. The Bush camp talks of tearing up the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty. Both parties are committed to the insane national missile defence system, putting the US under an umbrella protecting it from imaginary threats by "rogue" states that might lob a missile across, presumably unafraid of retaliation. It will end the old mutually assured destruction policy by which the world survived the cold war. Costing $60bn, it works even less well than the smart bombs of recent wars but still arouses fear and anger in China and Russia. Zbigniew Brzezinski calls it the mentality of the "internationally gated community".

Such isolationism will make the US role as a good global police force less likely: already political cowardice at losing any US soldier's life damaged its moral credibility in a genuinely unself-interested intervention in Kosovo.

 The third world: the US promised $600m towards the relief of third-world debt, with 25 countries partly aided by the end of this year. Not a penny has been paid because Congress refused. The rhetoric was good - a recent US poll showed half the population thought the problem already solved - but even Uganda, the exemplary "good" poor country, has still received nothing.

Following US parsimony, the EU and Japan have been dragging their heels too. If the world's richest country, whose GNP has risen by a third in five years, hasn't paid, why should anyone else? Then there are the world trade negotiations, wrecked instead of saved by US political selfishness.

 Poverty: a nation that does next to nothing about its own poor is unlikely to offer much to other countries. While US stock market values have increased five-fold in a decade, with half of all shares owned by 1% of the people, welfare has been cut to a five-year lifetime limit. With 40% of the people not covered by medical insurance, Medicare for the elderly is being cut by $115bn - and the Republicans promise far worse to come.

Virtually all the income gains of the last five years have been enjoyed by the top 20% of the population. The real value of the minimum wage is still below what it was in John F Kennedy's day, income distribution as unequal as in the 1920s. (Bill Gates' wealth is equal to that of the entire bottom 40% of the nation). The poor go to jail in a country that imprisons more than any dictatorship - 5% of adult males are under "correction". Some 3,500 people await execution on death row; 580 have been executed since the Supreme Court lifted its ban.

This is not the portrait of a civilised modern state. We are deceived by history. We are deceived by the myriad rainbow wonders of America, this mighty engine of invention and imagination, of creativity and enthusiasm from sea to shining sea. Europeans visit New York, San Francisco or Cape Cod, read the great American novelists and intellectuals, revel in America's popular culture, films and art and admire the super-sophistication of its academic discourse.

It's rather like visiting St Petersburg before the revolution, wondering at the brilliance of Tolstoy, Pushkin, Chekhov, Dostoevsky or maybe Fabergé, while trying to disregard the Tsar. The US constitution is kept on a mighty altar and lowered into a bomb-proof shelter at night as if it were indeed the guarantor of freedom: all it proves is that constitutions, freedoms of speech or information are only a small part of a good society. (The Soviet constitution was a pretty good document too.)

In elections there is always a better and worse. Bush is terrifying - in hock to oil and arms, promising a $1.3 trillion tax cut to the exclusive benefit of the top few. Gore is better. But whoever wins, America's dismal failure to address the key questions with any realism must strengthen European resolution on future unity. The life, views, values, ideas and politics of any town or village anywhere in the EU feels much more like home than any small town in middle America these days. The more we look at alien America, the more European we feel and the stronger we need to become.

webTitle: The North Pole is under water

fields.headline: The heat is on
fields.standfirst:
When a group of American tourists turned up at the North Pole on board an icebreaker earlier this month, they found no ice to break. It had all melted. Is this yet another example of the global warming that has caused flooding in Bangladesh and the deserts to expand in Africa? James Meek reports on

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: That sinking feeling The North Pole is under water. Could it be East Anglia next? James Meek reports on the true cost of global warming.
fields.body:
Had there been anyone there to watch, they would have thought that some gigantic, terrible sea creature was trying to break through the ice. There, at the North Pole, on March 17, 1959, a wind-scoured expanse of flat snow and hummocks was being broken into from below. With an eerie lack of sound, a huge black shape burst through the ice and settled, long, featureless and menacing, in the wasteland.

That was the day that Commander James Calvert and his men, the crew of the US nuclear submarine Skate, made history by being the first to test the thickness of the ice at the top of the world in the most dramatic way possible, with the hull of the boat they relied on to get them back home.

Since then, scores of submarines, including many from Britain, have visited the pole this way. A long, sometimes anxious, often boring, cruise under the ice; the search for a way up: a crack in the ice, known as a lead, an area of open water - a polynya - or a stretch where the frozen layer between water and sky is thin enough to break; the call to action stations; and the careful easing of the vessel up to the surface, sometimes with heart-stopping sounds of cracking and straining as the ice yields. And then, for the Royal Navy at least, a spot of football at the pole. Or, as has been known, the best cricket playable in three layers of clothing and Arctic mittens.

These cruises were for the sake of apocalyptic wars to come. The measuring of the thickness of the ice by sonar as the submarines hummed through the dark waters was just a by-product. But as scientists began to analyse the results of these measurements, they noticed a curious thing: year after year, the ice was becoming thinner. Amid fears of global warming, with the cold war gone, it starts to look as if the main legacy of those under-ice voyages will be the warning of a completely different apocalypse, equally man-made and equally destructive - the floods and famines of a world grilled under a blanket of greenhouse gases.

Earlier this month, a group of American tourists were startled, when they reached the North Pole on board a Russian icebreaker, to find that there was no ice to break. The pole, in our imaginations a flat white sheet scoured by twisting lines of wind-blown snow, was open water. Gulls flew overhead. The nearest stretch of ice capable of bearing the weight of the tour party was six miles away.

"There was a sense of alarm," said Dr James McCarthy, an oceanographer and one of the tourists. "Global warming was real, and we were seeing its effects for the first time that far north."

Arctic specialists read fearful media accounts of the icebreaker tour with mixed feelings. On one hand, they knew that open water at the North Pole is not, in fact, unusual - as the repeated submarine surfacings there show. Even in winter, the winds which keep the ice constantly moving across the sea of the Arctic basin cause cracks, ridges and large polynyas to appear. The Skate surfaced in 1959 through a lead of open water which had recently frozen over.

Yet they knew, too, that the tourists had witnessed something new - the thinness of the ice across the whole Arctic region, where historically it has been up to 3m thick. The evidence is mounting. The US Navy has provided its data, the Royal Navy has just released its last classified figures for analysis, and the Russians are rumoured to be preparing to put their information on the market. From 1300km up, satellites are able to measure ice thickness with incredible accuracy - to within 10cm. All the signs are that the sea ice over the Arctic is melting, and in 50 years' time, in summer, there could be no ice there at all.

"The average ice thickness in summer has decreased by 40% between the 1970s and now," said Peter Wadhams of the Cambridge-based Scott Polar Research Institute, who is a veteran of Arctic submarine voyages. "That's a pretty major decrease. And we're looking at satellite images showing the area of ice to be shrinking too - that's been going down by 5% a decade. At that rate, it will have vanished in 50 years."

An ice-free Arctic. Should we care? If all the sea ice melts, it won't affect sea levels: an ice cube melting in a drink does not make the drink overflow. Merchant ships would be able to cut almost 5,000 miles off the Europe-Japan sea route by zipping across the North Pole. Oil prospectors and trawlers would move in. Siberians and Canadians would cash in. But it would spell disaster for creatures such as the polar bear; it would mean the end of one of the world's last true wildernesses. And for humankind, it could be the beginning of a great climatic catastrophe.

The North Pole has always inspired passion in scientists. The passion to get there first, and the passion to be right about what is happening in the remotest and most mysterious of places. The man long accepted as the first to have reached the pole, Robert Peary, turned out to have wanted the honour so passionately that he lied - it now seems likely that he never got closer than 100 miles from the pole. The first to make it was probably a Soviet airman, Ivan Papanin, and he didn't make it until 1937.

The current debate about the causes of Arctic ice-thinning is, appropriately, one of the fiercest and most keenly watched in the whole field of climate change. Computer models of the world's climate predict that if changes take place, they will take place in the Arctic earlier and faster than anywhere else on the planet. The question under dispute is simple: is global warming to blame for the watery pole, or is it part of a separate weather cycle, whereby the ice shrinks and thickens in a regular way over decades?

Johnny Johannessen, of the Nansen Environmental and Remote Sensing Centre in Bergen, Norway - where scientists have predicted the demise of the Arctic summer sea ice in 50 years - said: "It's a challenge to be able to pin down how much ice thickness is changing as a result of global warming and how much is due to atmospheric conditions which, we know, undergo huge changes in the Arctic from decade to decade."

Dr Wadhams said he was convinced that global warming was the cause. In particular, the ice was being undermined from below by warmer seas. The idea that a change in the winds which shift the sea ice would simply "flip" the cycle back to a rethickening of the ice was, he said, unconvincing. "The balance of probability is that this is a real global-warming effect. It's not going to go back."

If global warming really is found to be responsible for the melting of the Arctic, it has two sets of consequences - one direct, the other demonstrative. If scientists can point to a shrinking skein of ice floes where valiant explorers once walked with huskies, it will help them to wake up the world to the powerful changes that man-made climate change is capable of making to all our lives.

Directly, the disappearance of the shiny white ice at the pole means the loss, for the planet, of a huge reflector, beaming the sun's heat back at it. Open water is darker and absorbs heat better. In other words, the loss of the ice would add to the rise in global temperatures.

Another direct consequence is a particularly ugly one for Britain. Global warming is predicted to mean steadily rising temperatures for our islands, bringing Mediterranean balm to the south. But within 100 years, this could change. With the melting of the Arctic ice, some models say, the existing circulation of cold and hot, fresh and salt water in the Atlantic would be dramatically violated. The gulf stream, the current of warm water which keeps our temperatures higher than they should be so far north, would falter and be turned back south of Ireland. Temperatures would sink till they were lower than they are now.

As a first, early sign of how global warming can bring real, swift and disturbing change to the world we grew up in, the thinning of the Arctic ice appears as an early warning light, closer to home and bigger than the inundation of little island nations, more clear-cut than the doubtful premise that global warming means more storms.

The melting Arctic will not bring flooding directly. But it looks like a sign that melting glaciers in the ancient, kilometres-thick ice caps of Greenland and AntArctica will. Sea levels are predicted to rise by 70cm in the coming century, putting the people of low-lying countries like Bangladesh at ever greater risk of disaster. Rising temperatures will render swathes of semi-arid African land desert, and lead to increased rainfall elsewhere, meaning greater floods.

Sceptics of global warming point to the lack of reliable weather records going back more than a century, arguing that it is impossible to distinguish between natural cycles in the weather and man-made changes. Yet examination of ice and sediment samples going back hundreds of thousands of years suggests that, in fact, the recent rises in temperatures are an aberration.

Accepted theories about the wobbles in the Earth's orbit, which are thought to cause ice ages, suggest that we can expect our next ice age in 25,000 years time, and that we are approaching the peak of natural warmth in the ice-age cycle. The difference in average global temperature between getting vineyards in Yorkshire and getting glaciers in Scottish glens is very small - only four degrees celsius. In other words, by adding a few degrees to the planet's natural temperature at the time when it is peaking anyway, we are moving into wholly unpredictable territory.

Politically and - some scientists fear - practically, there may be little we can do but try to help protect developing countries, which are likely to suffer the hardest, from the consequences of global warming. For the next few generations at least, western Europe and North America are set to experience climate change that is dramatic enough to notice but not dangerous enough to be beyond management, making it still possible to ignore the plight of nations and ecosystems which are more at risk.

Not that the changes won't be brought home to our shores in painful ways. "The 1953 floods on the east coast of England were caused by storm surges," said Wadhams. "If there are higher sea levels to begin with, it will be worse. The chances are there are going to be some disastrous floods on the east coast in the next few years. If I were living near the coast in Suffolk or Essex, I'd really be a bit worried."

Global warning:What will happen if the world keeps getting hotter

* Increased risk of flooding in Bangladesh: already ravaged by periodic floods, loss of life and property gets worse as the sea level rises. Nile delta also at risk.

* Famine in Africa: semi-arid regions in sub-Saharan Africa turn to desert, making the food situation for some of the world's poorest countries worse.

* Disease moves north: mosquito-borne diseases such as malaria, yellow fever, dengue fever and encephalitis spread into new territories.

* Trouble in New York: ferocious storms become a regular occurrence. Parts of Manhattan experience frequent floods.

* The map changes: the Florida everglades are inundated, changing the shape of the US.

* Danger in England: rising sea levels combine with storm surges to overcome the sea defences on the east coast.

* Birds die: an estimated 24m geese, sandpipers, dunlins and stints have to find new breeding grounds or perish, due to forestation of the Arctic tundra.

* Polar bears starve: as global warming melts the Arctic ice, the bears have less chance to fatten up on the seals they catch through the ice - their weight plummets and cubs starve. Additional research by Alison George.

webTitle: Charges dropped against student in Shayler case

fields.headline: Charges dropped against student in Shayler case
fields.standfirst:
Special report: David Shayler
Special report: freedom of information
MI5
Freedom of information bill
fields.trailText: A police inquiry into a student arrested under the Official Secrets Act in connection with the former MI5 officer David Shayler has been abandoned, the Guardian learned yesterday.
fields.body:
A police inquiry into a student arrested under the Official Secrets Act in connection with the former MI5 officer David Shayler has been abandoned, the Guardian learned yesterday.

Julie Ann Davies, a mature student at Kingston University in Surrey, was taken out of a lecture in March to be arrested by four special branch officers, who removed her computer and other personal belongings while holding her in a cell.

Ms Davies had been active in the campaign to have charges against Mr Shayler dropped and for more accountability of the secret agencies. She was questioned about an MI6 report which appeared on the internet that lent credence to Mr Shayler's allegations about MI6 involvement in a plot to kill the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy. She had been bailed three times and was recently told to appear again before the police next month.

Ms Davies' lawyer, Gareth Peirce, said last night that the charges against Ms Davies had been "politically inspired".

Ms Peirce yesterday received a letter saying no further action would be taken against her client. The letter was dated Monday, the day Mr Shayler was charged with making disclosures three years ago about MI5 but not over his more serious allegations about the Gadafy plot.

Ms Davies, 36, who was studying engineering, last night accused the police of wrecking her career and violating her human rights. "They did not tell me what I was supposed to have done," she said. She said she was considering taking legal action against the police.

webTitle: Comment, Alan Travis: News of the World's public support

fields.headline: Figure it out
fields.standfirst:
The News of the World's claims of public support for their paedophile campaign are not quite what they seem

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The ultimate justification for this summer's News of the World campaign "outing" sex offenders was that the paper was articulating a public anxiety with which both politicians and professionals have failed to come to terms.
fields.body:
The ultimate justification for this summer's News of the World campaign "outing" sex offenders was that the paper was articulating a public anxiety with which both politicians and professionals have failed to come to terms.

In the face of ugly scenes of vigilante action and the News of the World's humiliating decision to stop publishing its weekly photo-gallery of sex offenders, the paper's editor, Rebekah Wade, took comfort in the idea that her actions had overwhelming public support.

Media commentators who tut-tutted as vigilante mobs drove people out of their homes then went on to praise Ms Wade, saying that she had understood public feeling about released paedophiles in a way that no other newspaper editor had managed to do. Some went further and said that she had tapped so brilliantly into this public mood that if she managed to push her paper's circulation back above 4m then, in some way, the whole thing had been a success.

The News of the World is keen to paint the entire episode as a great victory. Last Sunday its front page trumpeted "82% of Britain wants Sarah's law". This was based on the findings of an exclusive Mori poll for the paper. They claimed that the poll revealed "huge support for our crusade to protect the nation's kids" and "for an urgent shake-up of the country's outdated and ineffective sex laws".

Even in the dismal history of newspaper coverage of specially commissioned opinion polls, this must stand out as one of the most remarkable pieces of selective reporting and amnesia in the cause of self-justification.

The evidence for this is on the polling company's own website, mori.com, where the full results are set out so that the pollsters can be absolved of any charge of fixing the results. Mori interviewed 1,004 adults by telephone between August 17-18 and the data has been weighted to the known population profile.

The first piece of evidence lies in the public's response to question 10: "As you may know, there has recently been controversy over the publication by the News of the World of names and photographs of people convicted of sex crimes against children. Do you think the News of the World was right or wrong to pursue this 'naming and shaming' policy?"

The results - right 38%, wrong 51%, neither 6% and don't know 5% - were clear cut. A majority of the public does not think that the News of the World was right to pursue its naming and shaming policy. Perhaps it is unsurprising that the paper failed to report this part of the poll.

The misrepresentation in the second exhibit is slightly more subtle but in some ways even more damaging. The News of the World printed a large chart purporting to show the full results to the first question asked: "What, if anything, do you think could be done to improve the safety of children in your area?"

Mori's actual results were illuminating about the public's fears. Top of the list came more policing (backed by 24%), followed by restrictions on speed limits/traffic control (23%) and more safe areas/parks for children to play in (16%).

These were followed by better parenting/responsibility for the safety/care of children (13%); more clubs/places to keep children/teenagers off the streets (11%); all adults/people should be aware/have more interest (7%); better community spirit/projects (4%); more education on safety/self defence (also 4%); more parking wardens (3%); and then public naming of convicted paedophiles (3%). Finally there were tougher sentences for child attackers (3%); bringing back the death penalty (2%); and the electronic tagging of convicted paedophiles (2%).

The News of the World chart clearly showed that more policing and more restrictions on speeding motorists were what the public put at the top of their list of what would make their children's lives safer. However, when it came down to the lowly tenth position in the public's solutions - just below the need for more parking wardens - the fact that only 3% of the public mentioned the public naming of convicted paedophiles (the central demand of the News of the World campaign) was strangely omitted.

The final piece of evidence lies in the main question, which claims that 82% support for Sarah's law. In the paper this was reported as having read: "Do you support Sarah's law?" But the Mori results show that the full question was: "The 'Sarah's law' campaign wants to introduce a new law in Britain that would ensure every parent's right to controlled access to information about individuals in their neighbourhood who may pose a risk to their children. Sarah's law would also include severe penalties for misuse of this information. The campaign is endorsed by the NSPCC, the Association of Chief Police Officers and the Association of Chief Officers of Probation. Do you support or oppose the introduction of 'Sarah's law'"? Now that is what most judges would call a heavily loaded question.

Recent Home Office research shows that the public's appetite for tougher criminal justice policies is often based on a completely misplaced conception of the length of sentences imposed by the courts. In this case the News of the World, far from reflecting public opinion, looks as though it might be guilty of trying to inflame it.

fields.headline: Mandelson's dilemma on prisoner releases
fields.standfirst:
Minister faces tricky decision on whether killings breach loyalist ceasefire
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The sight of loyalist gunmen roaming at will throughout the Shankill area of Belfast has presented Peter Mandelson with an dilemma as he settles back to work after the summer break.
fields.body:
The sight of loyalist gunmen roaming at will throughout the Shankill area of Belfast has presented Peter Mandelson with an dilemma as he settles back to work after the summer break.

Judging by the behaviour of a handful of paramilitaries led by Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, some of Belfast's most prominent loyalists should be immediately frogmarched back to the Maze prison.

Adair, who appeared at an Ulster Defence Association rally over the weekend in the company of masked gunmen, was released early under the terms of the Good Friday agreement on a special licence which can be revoked if he resorts to terrorism. Security forces believe Adair is orchestrating the present loyalist feud - with the stroke of a pen Mr Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, could return him to the Maze, unionists claimed yesterday.

Adair's opponents in the Progressive Unionist Party, the political wing of the Ulster Volunteer Force, could also find themselves in trouble with the government. The PUP spokes-man Billy Hutchinson has admitted that the UVF was responsible for Monday's double murder, allowing Mr Mandelson to rule on whether the UVF has breached its ceasefire.

For the moment Mr Mandelson is keeping his counsel and is unlikely to take action against Adair or the UVF. The Tories, who are longing to turn the peace process into a simple law and order issue, claim this shows that the government is going soft on terrorism. Belfast was relatively calm until the likes of Adair were released from prison, the Tories say, which means that the government is partly to blame for the violence.

Ministers dismiss the Conservative claims, insisting the present feud demands a more sophisticated response than simply revoking the prisoner releases. One government source said yesterday that the feud between the UVF and the UDA was a long-standing dispute which predated Adair's release from the Maze prison last year.

This may be wishful thinking: even government sources admit that "one or two" well known individuals are involved in the present feud. But ministers are reluctant to open up the Maze for fear of undermining the support for the peace process among former prisoners.

Loyalist and republican prisoners played an important role in supporting the peace process in its early days from the Maze and they have mainly behaved themselves on their release. "Prisoners have tended to have a pacifying influence and have acted in sup port of the peace process," one government source said yesterday. "This matter has to be considered in the round and ministers have to consider the impact on a [paramilitary] organisation of suspending a prisoner's licence."

This point was reinforced by the Rev Roy Magee, the Presbyterian minister who brokered the 1994 loyalist ceasefire, who warned that sending paramilitaries back to prison would have a destabilising effect on the peace process. His warnings are being heeded in government circles, although the security forces are monitoring Adair's every move and will pounce on him if he breaks the law.

The government is on firm ground in refusing to punish the UVF for Monday's gun attack. Government legislation makes clear that ministers can introduce sanctions only if there has been a "complete and unequivocal breakdown" of a ceasefire.

One government source said: "Nobody is excusing what the paramilitaries did on Monday. But ministers have to consider whether there has been a considered and collective decision to break a ceasefire. This has not happened - the shootings were a tit-for-tat settling of old scores unrelated to the peace process."

The Tories were drawing up plans last night to launch a high profile attack today on the government for appeasing terrorists. But their claims will be undermined by their own activities in government during the early days of the peace process.

The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, who yesterday rounded on the government, was a minister at the Northern Ireland Office in 1995 when ministers turned a blind eye to breaches of the first IRA ceasefire. Ministers defended their action in private at the time, saying that it was the sort of difficult decision which had to made in the interests of peace.
