webTitle: It's like the wild west, says mother as family flees warfare

fields.headline: It's like the wild west, says mother as family flees warfare
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Jane has lived on the lower Shankill estate for the best part of 18 years, but yesterday she and her four children were hurriedly packing their possessions to be loaded into a removal van waiting outside.
fields.body:
Jane has lived on the lower Shankill estate for the best part of 18 years, but yesterday she and her four children were hurriedly packing their possessions to be loaded into a removal van waiting outside.

The first inkling she had that anything was wrong was on Saturday afternoon when a friend came knocking at the door. He had heard her name was on an Ulster Defence Association list of people to be "burned out" of the estate. Her 18-year-old son plays in the Shankill Protestant boys' band, which is linked to the rival Ulster Volunteer Force. In the internecine warfare gripping the loyalist heartland of Belfast, that fact alone was enough to put the lives of her and her family in danger.

On Saturday night she stayed up until 3am, listening to a rave organised by the UDA/UFF hero Johnny Adair as part of a "cultural festival" to celebrate loyalism. Between records Adair took the microphone and to wild applause listed the names of more than 20 families, supposedly linked to the UVF, who were to be expelled from the estate. The lower Shankill would be a UDA state before Christmas, he said.

"I was terrified," Jane, 36, said. "There is no sense in those people at the best of times, and they were full of drink and drugs. I didn't sleep at all waiting for something to happen." By Sunday afternoon she had had enough and she and her four children, aged between 11 and 18, moved to her aunt's house in a different area of Belfast.

"It's ethnic cleansing that is going on here. An image keeps flashing in my mind of black and white film of the Jews being forced out in Nazi Germany. Acquaintances I've known for years won't even look you in the face in case they are seen by one of Adair's henchmen and accused of fraternising.

"It's like the wild west, the way they went down the road swinging crowbars and toting their guns. But at least in the wild west the sheriff wasn't scared to take on the bad guys."

Jane is certain she will never return to the lower Shankill. "The IRA never forced people out despite 30 years of trying, but Johnny Adair has managed it in three days."

The Belfast housing executive is trying to find safe accommodation for all the families who have been forced out.

Even the removal men clearing the houses had to be given police and army protection from a barracking crowd that had gathered on the road.

But after the orgy of violence that swept the loyalist stronghold on Monday, sparked by the double murder of Jackie Coulter and Bobby Mahood by the UVF, the rest of the Shankill Road was relatively quiet. But despite the presence of the security forces, few people seemed to think the violence was over.

"I've never known it this tense," said Sammy Graham, 70, a retired foreman at the Ford motor company. "People are really frightened. Things have changed. When there were IRA bombs people would pick themselves up and get on with things, but with this battle going on now between loyalists people just don't feel safe."

The Rev Roy McGee was instrumental in brokering the loyalist paramilitary ceasefire in 1994, and has acted as mediator in numerous disputes between loyalist factions. But yesterday even he sounded pessimistic. "Mediation can only take place when the leaders of the opposing factions are willing to enter into it. But sadly at the moment we are not at that stage. Sanity has to prevail."

fields.headline: In the frame
fields.standfirst: Hirst's novel self-portrait
fields.trailText: Damien Hirst has exhibited sheep, cows and most famously a tiger shark embalmed in formaldehyde. In his latest work however the most terrible of the enfants who shook up the British art scene in the early 1990s has preserved a far more endangered species; traditional painting.
fields.body:
Damien Hirst has exhibited sheep, cows and most famously a tiger shark embalmed in formaldehyde. In his latest work however the most terrible of the enfants who shook up the British art scene in the early 1990s has preserved a far more endangered species; traditional painting.

In a piece titled Contemplating a Self Portrait (as a Pharmacist), Hirst has taken the trappings of the figurative painter; easel, canvas, smock, palette, brushes and tubes of oil paint, and encased them in a series of glass boxes.

The piece is, according to an accompanying text by Gemma de Cruz, "a confessional, romantic work" that expresses Mr Hirst's love of traditional painting and his frustration at being able to work only in a "mechanical" style. Mr Hirst, who is holidaying with friends in Spain, was unavailable to comment on this interpretation.

The previously unseen work will go on show next month in Ant Noises 2, the latest exhibition of work from the collection of Britain's foremost contemporary collector and patron, Charles Saatchi.

Other Hirst works that will go on show at the exhibition, which opens on September 13 at the Saatchi Gallery, north London, include Horror at Home, an oversize ashtray filled with cigarette butts and detritus; The Last Supper, a series of screen prints of food; and Zeolite Mixture, one of his dot paintings.

Earlier this year Mr Saatchi paid £1m for Hirst's sculpture Hymn, a 20ft bronze model of an anatomical toy originally designed for children.

Other artists exhibiting previously unseen work include many of the leading lights of the Young British Artists movement that Hirst so flamboyantly led.

Tracey Emin exhibits photographs of herself in a 14ft weatherboard beach hut in Whitstable she bought with fellow artist Sarah Lucas in 1992. The beach hut itself, entitled The Last Thing I Said to You is Don't Leave Me Here, is also included in the exhibition, as is My Bed, the unmade bed that brought critical acclaim and opprobrium in equal measure when it was shortlisted for the Turner Prize.

fields.headline: Naughty bits restored to classics
fields.trailText: Faced with Greek and Roman texts which often stray into the downright bawdy, the translators of the Loeb Classical Library have worked hard over the past century to spare the blushes of the more sensitive reader.
fields.body:
Faced with Greek and Roman texts which often stray into the downright bawdy, the translators of the Loeb Classical Library have worked hard over the past century to spare the blushes of the more sensitive reader.

Until now that is. In their new publications, the translators are being allowed to cast aside their euphemisms and talk dirty. The colourful profanities of notoriously licentious authors such as Catullus and Aristophanes are being rendered with no-nonsense accuracy, a move welcomed by many classicists.

In Aristophanes's play Women in Thesmophoria, for instance, two Greeks are discussing the poet Agathon, known for his homosexual love affairs. The first Greek says he knows the poet well, but insists that the other is more intimate with him. "You've never seen him?" "Absolutely not, as far as I know," says the second. The previous Loeb translation then has the first man suggesting: "I fear there's much you don't remember, sir." The new translation, out in the autumn, is rather less coy: "Well, you must have fucked him."

Similarly, a new version of Aristophanes's The Acharnians reintroduces into the main text the exclamation "What tits! How firm, like quinces", from a discreet footnote.

In an earlier translation of Catullus, a line was translated: "Tis you I fear, you and your passions, so fatal to the young, both good and bad alike." The new translation is more blunt: "Tis you I fear, you and your penis, so ready to molest good boys and bad alike."

Some passages considered inappropriate were previously simply left out, such as the pungent image in Catullus of "Libo's soft and subtle farting", and the section, in a work by the physician and alchemist Theophrastus, on plants said to cause abortions.

The Loeb Classical Library was founded in 1910 by James Loeb, the son of a New York banker who studied classics at Harvard. His aim, according to an early preface, was to "place these treasures within all who care for the finer things of life".

Loeb called on translators to remove or edit passages which might offend.

A Greek word thought to be too close to the mark tended to be passed over in the main text and translated in a footnote into Latin. A Latin word would be translated into modern Italian.

The Loeb publications are respected aids to classics students, and the use of the sillier euphemisms has become a standing joke among scholars.

When production and distribution was taken over by Harvard University Press in 1989, editors began commissioning new, more accurate and less cautious translations.

Peg Fulton, administrative editor of the Loeb Classical Library, said: "Some of the texts were badly in need of revision. Take Aristophanes, he's raucous and comic but was given a translation that made him sound like he came from the Victorian age. It has a certain charm but it's just not Aristophanes."

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What fairground workers are watching
fields.trailText: What fairground workers are watching.
fields.body:
Debs: "I'm the sort of person that really hates the TV when it's on, I think it's just noise, but when I really watch I find myself laughing. At all the wrong things, hahah! What like? Oh car crashes ahaha. Not really, no, don't put that. What do I like? I like pubs that have TV that you walk into and everyone's silent cos they're all watching the box. Only Fools And Horses, I like it. Bit old isn't it? Don't think I've seen much recently. Last night of the Proms? Not on your life, mate."

Darren: "Got no idea. Don't watch it. I like the relaxation of the porn video laws though, hahah! Do we get offered dodgy stuff from wanderers? What?? [Thinks] No. We do get offered cats and dogs and things, but we don't use animals. I don't think people quite know what we do, really. They think we trade cabbages to peasants, or we're homeless or something. Favourite TV personality? Carol Vorderman, she's so silly. Teaching people maths, no one wants that."

Geoff Kaye: "I don't really know why people are glued to the television when they could be doing something else or learning something. There's a lot more in books you know. [Silence.] Morecambe And Wise. Yes. [Silence.] Christmas time, that's what they remind me of. We don't get to see a lot of TV, us people. We're always on the move. I sometimes see it - no, forget that, erase that one. I don't see it. Not at all."

Jason: "I like Ali G. I think he's hilarious, really good. I don't know anyone else. Who are you again? Why don't you ask some punters instead? Favourite TV personality? Spike Milligan."

Fen Day: "I've got a TV and I like to watch it in the day, melts the mind a bit and I like that. What programmes? Countdown, Fifteen To One, Richard And Judy. Gets the kids up too. I like them, they renewed their vows - no, not my children, Richard and Judy. Yeah. what would I like to see? More sex and violence, haha! No, not really. I'd like to see me."

Sin Pattenden spoke to workers at the fairground in Clapham, south London.

webTitle: Jonathan Romney: Von Trier's insect experiment

fields.headline: Ants misbehavin'
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Romney: Von Trier's insect experiment

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney: Von Trier's insect experiment
fields.body:
Of course, we all know perfectly well that Big Brother is morally indefensible - voyeuristic, intrusive, manipulative, cruel and designed to turn real people into soap characters. But every moral objection, every glimmer of theoretical interest you might have about it was anticipated by Psychomobile 1: The World Clock, an installation staged in 1996 by Dogme founder Lars Von Trier.

The installation is documented in Jesper Jargil's film De Udstillede (The Exhibited), showing in the Edinburgh film festival this week, and if you ever felt that watching Big Brother was like peering into an ant colony, Jargil's film makes a sobering comparison. Wondering what it would be like if people's behaviour were determined by a system they couldn't control, Von Trier set up a video camera to film an ant colony in New Mexico. The image was transmitted live to a gallery in Copenhagen, where the ants' movements triggered sets of coloured lights in 19 rooms inhabited by 53 actors, watched over a month by a live audience.

The actors came equipped only with background information on their characters, exotic oddballs with names like Phi, Emperor, AA, The Cur, Petite 1, Petite 2. They improvised their parts according to the changing lights - a system complicated by the fact that a given colour had an entirely different meaning for each actor. More detailed variables governed particular characters: Richard Bestboy changes personality seemingly at random; anyone touched by Starseed must freeze on the spot.

This being a Danish production, and seemingly a dry run for Von Trier's psychodrama The Idiots, the stakes are higher than on Channel 4, offering sex, violence and madness. Otherwise the two productions are remarkably close. As the characters evolve in Psychomobile 1, the actors confess to being increasingly unable to separate the drama from their real emotions, which are often violent ("There are light changes that changed lives," says one actor).

Psychomobile 1 cannot, of course, have the real moral consequences of Big Brother, which increasingly resembles a machine for screwing up lives. But while the conventions of the gallery installation protect Psychomobile's audience from the real moral consequences of voyeurism, they don't - as far as you can tell from the film - cut out the rush of emotional danger that both actors and audience are exposed to. If anything, they heighten it.

The idea of Psychomobile as a clock regulating the actors' movements makes you realise that Big Brother too is like a clock, and one designed to wind down. In the final weeks, Big Brother's drama will atrophy, its once-crowded stage will be almost deserted and the last few contestants will live out something increasingly resembling a Beckett play filmed according to Dogme rules. Von Trier's players were keen to achieve closure as the installation approached its ending. In the final week, the actors began to worry that the whole thing would end in a bloodbath, with characters killing each other to bring about a show-stopping finale. Come the inevitably lurid climax, one particularly inventive actor broke the rules. When his character was eliminated from the action by a lethal bullet, the actor decided to return covered in talc, as a ghost confronting his murderer.

I doubt that option is open to Nick Bateman, but if the Big Brother contestants hear eerie wailing in the dead of night, they'll know why.

De Udstillede is at Cameo 2, Edinburgh (0131 623-8030), at 5.30pm on Friday.

fields.headline: Turning the tide
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Better By Design/Brain Story/Battle Of Britain
fields.body:
A life jacket, like a divorce lawyer, is something you never want to use but, in the event of an emergency, you'd hope did exactly as it said on the tin.

Yet, as Better By Design (C4) illustrated, in many ferry disasters, a divorce lawyer would probably be as much use as current life jackets.

Helpfully, a life jacket comes with no instructions, so it's your best guess as to how it works that lies between you and a watery death. For many people, and no doubt many of the 852 souls who died on the Estonia ferry disaster in 1994, best guess wasn't good enough.

But "a life jacket should be so simple, people should automatically know how to put it on", as Richard Seymour - evidently separated at birth from Clarissa Dickson Wright - noted, knowing that good design is the kind you don't notice. So he and his chum Dick Powell set about designing a new type of life jacket, more user-friendly and, hence, more life-saving.

With the cooperation of a survivor of the Estonia disaster, design boffins and the sales director of Crewsaver, the company which makes the current kind of life jacket, the pair brainstormed, drew lovely sketches and got prototypes made. It was a real let's-put-on-a-show moment, the kind of montage you get in a film when, with all the odds against the heroes, they get down to some good old-fashioned hard work, turn the tide (as it were) and win the day.

As the stick-in-the-mud of the piece, Andrew the sales director wasn't convinced that there was anything wrong with the present design. After all, in the maelstrom of salty recriminations that follow a ferry disaster, the usefulness (or not) of life jackets bobs to one side in favour of "human error" as a cause of death.

Perhaps unfairly painted as the baddie of the piece, Andrew worried about issues of stowage, user-friendliness for both ferry companies and passengers and, naturally, cost. Thus, when the new design was tested, found to be better in every way, he had to concede he kinda liked it. Crewsaver's managing director liked it too, at least in front of the cameras. In the end though, after all the "Hmmm, it's an interesting concept" and "It's worth taking forward", Crewsaver decided the benefits did not justify the increased cost. Life is cheap. Hardly a happy ending with the triumphant heroes walking off into the sunset. (The paranoid amongst you might suggest there is a conspiracy to off ferry passengers going on, and you'd be half-right. There is a conspiracy but - and earnest lefty moment approaching - it's called capitalism, and we're all complicit).

When Fran Leibowitz said "Modern science is generally practiced by those who lack the flair for conversation", Professor Susan Greenfield probably wasn't around. If the brains behind Brain Story (BBC2) had been, such a maxim would never have made it into the history books. Even when she describes the brain as 1.5 kilograms of matter with the consistency of soft butter, it sounds like poetry. So when she is actually talking about the indescribable, intangible enigma that is consciousness and the mystery of how it is, how it comes to be, how we are, her words are music.

Not only that, she has so much fun with science. She goes out for coffee, she visits stately homes in glamorous silky dresses, she even goes to the Edinburgh festival to stand on a man lying face down on broken glass. (Will she come to mine for dinner, I wonder?) My adoration of Greenfield aside, Brain Story is rather marvellous, but the footage of brain surgery being performed on semi-conscious people was a bit icky for my liking.

Historical reconstructions can verge on the embarrassing, especially as it's all too easy to imagine the participants - all dressed in period costume - queueing at the catering van saying things like "Well, I was an assasinated Roman senator last week and I got a terrible toga burn." The reconstructions of airmen sitting round their airbase in Battle Of Britain (ITV) were not too awful, though there was a suggestion of moustache-twirling and alumni from the Biggles School Of Emoting Like A Man In The 1940s. Still, one mustn't grumble overly much when ITV screens an historical documentary in prime-time (an historical event in itself), even if it did feel like a schools programme. Nevertheless, with first-hand accounts from both sides, Battle Of Britain suggested at least some commitment to thoughtful telly. And overseas sales to the History Channel.

fields.headline: No: 1705
fields.standfirst: Lionel Mann
fields.trailText: Lionel Mann
fields.body:
Age: 59.

Status: World-famous chef to the royal family.

Appearance: Fluctuating between varying shades of green and white. Showing signs of nausea, abdominal cramping, diarrhoea ...

Stop! I don't think we need quite so much detail. Ill is he? He has been better.

Come on, out with it. What's wrong with the man? Actually it's slighty embarrassing. The royal cook for 40 years has come down with a spot of food poisoning. Salmonella in fact.

Oh no! Not another lethal threat to the Queen and her family. Wasn't it just six months ago when she was last at risk from her kitchen staff? Spot on. Kitchen porter Monica Traub was dismissed by the royal household in February for telling staff how easy it would be to poison Her Majesty.

Well, apparently she had a point. Maybe she should take over from the clearly incompetent Mann. Don't be silly. Mann has only been temporarily banned from the royal kitchens until he's entirely better. A courtier said: "The Queen has asked to be kept closely informed about his condition," though whether that's due to concern for her staff or concern for her stomach is another matter.

So, how do you get salmonella? Various salmonella species have been found in eggs, raw meats, poultry, swine, milk and dairy products, fish, yeast, coconut, peanut butter and chocolate. It can be carried in water and by insects, and is found on kitchen surfaces.

Gosh! Buckingham Palace must be going positively apoplectic with worry. I take it the rare steak, the smoked salmon and the pate de foie gras are off the menu from now on. Well no, not exactly. It turns out that Mann actually contracted the bug after giving a cooking demonstration away from the palace.

Windsor? Mexico.

So in fact Her Majesty isn't at risk at all. To be honest, no.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Mousehunt/Lolita/Gorky Park/Bande A Part
fields.body:
Mousehunt

(Gore Verbinski, 1997)

9.30am, 6pm, Sky Premier

Nathan Lane and Lee Evans are dimwit, Laurel-and-Hardy-like brothers who inherit dad's string factory and a crumbly mansion. There's a string attached, too, in the form of a mouse (pictured) with a territorial sense that would put a pitbull to shame. Just the thing for the school holidays.

Lolita

(Stanley Kubrick, 1961)

9pm, TCM

James Mason took Humbert Humbert role after David Niven, Rex Harrison and Noel Coward turned it down, no doubt blanching at the challenge of the arrogant paedophile from Nabokov's novel. Mason comes over as broadly sympathetic, if stuffy, while Sue Lyons scoffs her way through as the knowing nymphet - whose age is nervously increased to 14 from the book's 12. Better are Shelley Winters as her frustrated mum, Peter Sellers as the menacing Quilty. It lacks Nabokov's acidity and is hamstrung by being filmed in England - very obviously thousands of miles from its American mid-West setting, but is a braver stab than Adrian Lyne's later version.

Gorky Park

(Michael Apted, 1983)

1am, Carlton Cinema

A chilly thriller set in a KGB-ridden Moscow, adapted by Dennis Potter from Martin Cruz Smith's bestseller. Wry and wan William Hurt is excellent as investigator Arkady Renko, called in after the discovery of three frozen, mutilated corpses in the park. Brian Dennehy's rogue New York cop and Lee Marvin's menacing businessman are the wild cards.

Bande A Part

(Jean-Luc Godard, 1964)

1am, FilmFour

One of Godard's finest, with all the playful technique which made his early films so endearing, even if it is about three people plotting to swindle an old lady. But the plot is only half the story. Anna Karina does her wide-eyed ingénue thing again, this time charming two juvenile friends (Claude Brasseur and Sami Frey) into crime.

fields.headline: US money to oust Saddam 'wasted'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Two years after the US Congress voted to spend $97m on the overthrow of the Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein, none of the country's resistance groups have received any weapons, but they are learning how to talk about their problems.
fields.body:
Two years after the US Congress voted to spend $97m on the overthrow of the Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein, none of the country's resistance groups have received any weapons, but they are learning how to talk about their problems.

Under pressure to disburse the funds but concerned that rival opposition factions would turn any new weapons on each other rather than on President Saddam's forces, the US state department has sought out more innocuous ways to spend the money.

Much of it, the Iraqi opposition complains, has been awarded to "new age" management consultants in the west who know little about Iraq. The latest beneficiary has been the Conflict Management Group (CMG), an organisation founded by Roger Fisher, a US conflict-resolution guru who wrote the business-negotiation bible, Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In.

Ahmed Chalabi, leader of the main opposition grouping, the Iraqi National Congress (INC), has denounced the scheme as a "great waste of money".

"A fellow called me up about six months ago and said: 'We've got this big contract to organise this meeting. Can you tell me the names of some of the Iraqi opposition leaders?'," Mr Brooke recalled. "I'd be very surprised if anyone significant turned up at all."

A $3m (£2m) opposition conference was also arranged in New York last year, but it failed to heal the rifts in the opposition and was boycotted by the main Iranian-backed Shi'ite rebels; Iraqi opposition politicians complained that too much congressional money had been spent on the event's highly paid US organisers.

The INC organised its own conference earlier this year in London at one-tenth of the cost for each per person, Mr Brooke said.

Leith Kubba, an independent Iraqi analyst at the Washington-based thinktank, the National Endowment for Democracy, said he expected that very little of the money would be spent before the US elections in November.

There were problems in supplying weapons to the Kurds or the Shi'ite rebels, the only significant groups with an armed presence. Arming the Kurds would anger Turkey, while the Shi'ites were based in Iran, he said."However, the state department is being pushed to spend the money anyway, so they look for other recipients," Mr Kubba said. "...the money has been forced on them by Congress."

webTitle: Moving on from canal bank to caravan

fields.headline: Moving on from canal bank to caravan
fields.standfirst: Big reduction in number of rough sleepers
fields.trailText: Jerry, 37, used to sleep rough under a canal bridge. He now lives in a caravan in Manchester and hopes to become a journalist.
fields.body:
Jerry, 37, used to sleep rough under a canal bridge. He now lives in a caravan in Manchester and hopes to become a journalist.

"When I first came [to Britain] I was living in a caravan near Swansea and I worked for a farmer who was also the landlord. I had a job in a cheese factory too," says Jerry, who was born in Leeds, grew up in Zimbabwe, and has lived in Britain since 1981.

"But when the landlord died I had to get out because I was in a caravan and had no rights."

His first home on the streets was a little shelter at the train station nearby. "People did not bother me in a small town - it was the opposite of a big city."

He then moved to Manchester and slept under a bridge on Deansgate canal for two years. "I suffered various forms of violence."

Jerry credits the Big Issue in the North, the Manchester-based magazine sold by homeless people, with helping him move his life forward. "I have been able to use their facilities, learn about computers and get on to a college course.

"Once I started using the computers I began writing and one thing led to another."

He is now doing a BTEC course in radio production at Radio Regen, a community-based project in Manchester, and is still a vendor for the Big Issue.

Jerry moved into his caravan just before Christmas last year.

"When I first moved there it was so nice to have my own space. But now I am finding it quite a problem to readjust.

"I had no worries when I was homeless - apart from the violence."

He has recently been through a detox programme for alcoholism, in which he was advised to treat himself when he had some money - so he bought some clothes.

webTitle: Leader - It is no use Altavista trying to blame BT

fields.headline: Absolutely remiss
fields.standfirst:
It is no use Altavista trying to blame BT

Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: Altavista should have looked up the meaning of the word "truth" in its internet search engine before claiming that unmetered access to the world wide web was "up and running" in a "controlled roll-out".
fields.body:
Altavista should have looked up the meaning of the word "truth" in its internet search engine before claiming that unmetered access to the world wide web was "up and running" in a "controlled roll-out".

That was in July and not a single customer has been identified since. Andy Mitchell, managing director of Altavista UK, told the BBC yesterday that the service had been put on hold a few weeks ago and that he had been "absolutely remiss" in not communicating this. He can say that again. He has also been remiss in blaming BT, because on this occasion BT probably is not guilty.

Unmetered access to the internet - under which customers pay a fixed monthly fee and then get unlimited surfing time - is vital both to accelerate use of the internet and to lessen the extent of any digital divide opening between those who can afford it and those who cannot. One reason the US is so far ahead of most countries in exploitation of the internet is that Americans have had free (ie unmetered) local calls for ages. BT was wrong - and badly wrong - in exploiting its monopoly position by not offering unmetered access five or even 10 years ago. If it had done it then, use of the internet in Britain would by now be more advanced than it is. Belatedly, and only because it came under pressure from service providers and Oftel, BT has at last started to get its act together. Unmetered access should be here within weeks rather than months, once outstanding technical matters have been agreed.

BT must now move equally fast to enable rival companies to have their own high capacity ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) access in the local loop - the distance between the telephone exchange and the home - where BT enjoys an almost total monopoly. ADSL will speed the use of high-speed transmission of video down the telephone line. Competition of this kind is the best way to bring prices down and to speed technological change.

webTitle: Leader - Cook lost in the arms sales sell-out

fields.headline: The arms sales sell-out
fields.standfirst:
Mr Cook has lost; he ought to have won

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor

Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The pinnacle of the political career of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was reached in February 1996. MPs who were present in the Commons that day can still remember how, after only a brief opportunity to absorb its contents, he castigated the Conservative government over the Scott report on the arms-to-Iraq affair.
fields.body:
The pinnacle of the political career of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, was reached in February 1996. MPs who were present in the Commons that day can still remember how, after only a brief opportunity to absorb its contents, he castigated the Conservative government over the Scott report on the arms-to-Iraq affair.

The way in which the Conservatives sought to mislead parliament and the public over arms exports contributed to the general decline in their reputation and so to their subsequent catastrophic defeat in the 1997 general election.

Against this background, there was every expectation that Labour would legislate at some point on the recommendations made by Sir Richard Scott to clean up the arms trade. In February, the Department of Trade and Industry was told that its officials could draft a bill which would license the 150-200 companies at present operating without regulation in this country. It seemed inconceivable then that Labour would go into a general election after four years in government without dealing decisively with an issue on which it had accrued so much credit in opposition. But that is what Labour now intends to do. As we report this morning, Mr Cook and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, have lost their battle for a slot in the Queen's Speech this autumn.

The government has taken some positive measures towards cleaning up the arms trade since coming to power. It has begun publishing an annual report providing for the first time a rough indication of how much military hardware Britain exports. But the report is ambiguous and falls a long way short of the transparency that Sir Richard called for in his report. The government was also a prime mover in the creation of the European Union code of conduct on arms sales. But its own record in implementing an arms policy with an "ethical dimension" has proved to be mixed. Much damage has been done to Labour's reputation through arms sales to Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe.

The arms exports bill backed by Mr Cook and Mr Byers was needed to help redress the balance. It could have sent the necessary signal to the public that, in spite of sales to Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe, Labour was committed to ending the most disreputable parts of the trade. Campaign groups opposed to the arms trade have identified British companies that have been sending weapons and other equipment to countries regarded as neutral, but which turn out to be staging posts on the way to countries involved in conflict.

The government needs to take a much harder look at the arms trade. Questions need to be asked about the way that British defence manufacturers are subsidised and about the exaggerated claims made by the Ministry of Defence about the number of jobs dependent upon exports. We need too to be told why neither the government nor the defence industry is looking seriously at diversification into civilian manufacturing.

Mr Cook was the kind of minister to ask those questions. But neither Downing Street nor even the diplomats at the Foreign Office have been entirely happy with his commitment to an ethical dimension to foreign policy. The defeat of Mr Cook and Mr Byers in the annual interdepartmental fight for space on the legislative programme is to be lamented. The bill they wanted was needed and would not necessarily have eaten up too much parliamentary time, since the Conservatives would have been foolish to oppose it. It is not too late for second, more honourable, thoughts to prevail.

In February, the Department of Trade and Industry was told that its officials could draft a bill which would license the 150-200 companies at present operating without regulation in this country. It seemed inconceivable then that Labour would go into a general election after four years in government without dealing decisively with an issue on which it had accrued so much credit in opposition. But that is what Labour now intends to do. As we report this morning, Mr Cook and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, have lost their battle for a slot in the Queen's Speech this autumn. The government has taken some positive measures towards cleaning up the arms trade since coming to power. It has begun publishing an annual report providing for the first time a rough indication of how much military hardware Britain exports. But the report is ambiguous and falls a long way short of the transparency that Sir Richard called for in his report. The government was also a prime mover in the creation of the European Union code of conduct on arms sales. But its own record in implementing an arms policy with an "ethical dimension" has proved to be mixed. Much damage has been done to Labour's reputation through arms sales to Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe. The arms exports bill backed by Mr Cook and Mr Byers was needed to help redress the balance. It could have sent the necessary signal to the public that, in spite of sales to Indonesia, Pakistan and Zimbabwe, Labour was committed to ending the most disreputable parts of the trade. Campaign groups opposed to the arms trade have identified British companies that have been sending weapons and other equipment to countries regarded as neutral, but which turn out to be staging posts on the way to countries involved in conflict. The government needs to take a much harder look at the arms trade. Questions need to be asked about the way that British defence manufacturers are subsidised and about the exaggerated claims made by the Ministry of Defence about the number of jobs dependent upon exports. We need too to be told why neither the government nor the defence industry is looking seriously at diversification into civilian manufacturing. Mr Cook was the kind of minister to ask those questions. But neither Downing Street nor even the diplomats at the Foreign Office have been entirely happy with his commitment to an ethical dimension to foreign policy. The defeat of Mr Cook and Mr Byers in the annual interdepartmental fight for space on the legislative programme is to be lamented. The bill they wanted was needed and would not necessarily have eaten up too much parliamentary time, since the Conservatives would have been foolish to oppose it. It is not too late for second, more honourable, thoughts to prevail.

webTitle: Big reduction in number of rough sleepers

fields.headline: Big reduction in number of rough sleepers
fields.standfirst:
Good progress, but a great deal more must be done, says adviser's report which shows a concentration of homeless victims in London
Moving on from canal bank to caravan
fields.trailText: The number of people sleeping rough in England has fallen by more than a third over the past two years, according to figures released yesterday by Louise Casey, the government's homelessness tsar.
fields.body:
The number of people sleeping rough in England has fallen by more than a third over the past two years, according to figures released yesterday by Louise Casey, the government's homelessness tsar.

She told the prime minister that good progress was being made towards his target of bringing all rough sleepers in from the cold. But there was a huge amount more to do to help those addicted to a life of drugs and street crime - and to support vulnerable people who were in danger of becoming the next generation of down and outs.

In a progress report to Tony Blair, Ms Casey's rough sleepers unit said there were now about 1,180 homeless people on the streets in England. That was 28% down on this time last year and a 36% reduction on the year before.

The largest concentrations of rough sleepers continued to be in central London boroughs, with nearly a fifth of the national total being in Westminster.

Oxford, Brighton, Nottingham, Birmingham, Manchester, Cambridge, Bournemouth and Bristol each had more than a score of rough sleepers, acording to latest estimates.

They will be among 32 authorities outside London to benefit from an extra £9.5m distributed yesterday by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions as part of a £200m programme to reduce numbers of rough sleepers by at least two-thirds by 2002.

Ms Casey said achievements so far included the appointment of teams in London and other big cities to make contact with rough sleepers and give them the help needed to "come inside".

An extra 800 hostel bed spaces for vulnerable rough sleepers had been created in London, bringing the total to more than 2,000. There were also better services to combat drug misuse among rough sleepers and projects to help people leaving the streets to move on from hostel accommodation into training and work.

Shaks Ghosh, chief executive of Crisis, a charity for the single homeless, said the progress report was an important first step. New bed spaces and services helped to reduce numbers sleeping rough, especially outside London.

"But I am worried about the numbers of people who are coming off the streets only to be warehoused in hostels, emergency shelters, and other temporary accommodation for months and even years." They needed support if they were to have a chance of rebuilding their lives.

Crisis estimated there was a "hidden homeless" population of 400,000, including people in squats, bed and breakfast, and sleeping on friends' sofas. It said many were at risk of becoming the next wave of rough sleepers.

Archie Norman, shadow environment secretary, said: "This is a disgrace, not a triumph for New Labour. The government has promised £200m to tackle rough sleeping - £125,000 per rough sleeper. Yet even if they have managed to get 400 people off the streets, this is still less than the rise in homelessness."

Figures provided to the Conservatives from the Commons library showed 27,050 were classified as priority homeless in the first quarter of 1997, compared with 27,700 in the first quarter of 2000.

fields.headline: MPs attack Railtrack's £139m bonuses
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The Commons public accounts committee today criticises the regulatory regime which allowed Railtrack to receive £139m in performance bonuses at a time when it was missing its targets for reducing train delays.
fields.body:
The Commons public accounts committee today criticises the regulatory regime which allowed Railtrack to receive £139m in performance bonuses at a time when it was missing its targets for reducing train delays.

The committee chairman, David Davis, says: "People should not have to sit in delayed trains reading about Railtrack receiving bonuses that it does not deserve."

The committee, in a report on the office of the rail regulator, says the hasty privatisation of Railtrack in 1996 created serious defects in the regulatory regime which the previous rail regulator, John Swift, had not moved fast enough to remedy.

Tom Winsor, the new rail regulator, said the report endorsed his tough action to force Railtrack to improve its act. He challenged Railtrack to back the PAC report, which criticises the company for failing to know what it owns.

He is seeking to change Railtrack's licence and introduce tougher contracts with the heavily subsidised train operators who paid the £139m performance bonuses. Railtrack, which is responsible for the rail network, including track, signalling and stations, has appealed against the £10.8m fine imposed by Mr Winsor because it failed to meet its delay reduction targets last year.

The company said the bonuses had been justified by improvements, including a 44% reduction in delays caused by the company since privatisation. It is now responsible for 42% of all delays.

The report calls on the regulator to press ahead with plans to get independent verification of delay figures provided by Railtrack. It says Railtrack's licence, drawn up when it was state-owned, contains serious shortcomings because of its hasty privatisation.

As a result, passengers have seen poorer track quality, the report says.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Widows chief returns to US
fields.body:
Widows chief returns to US

The fund management arm of Scottish Widows lost Orie Dudley, its chief executive and chief investment officer, yesterday.

Mr Dudley is to return to the US to join Northern Trust Global Investments in Chicago. His role at Scottish Widows Investment Partnership is to be split between Bill Main, who becomes chief executive officer, and Sandy Nairn as chief investment officer.

Union warns of bank job losses

A union has warned that up to 600 jobs could be lost as a result of plans by Lloyds TSB bank to contract out cheque processing. Unifi said outsourcing clearing operations to a Barclays site in Northampton could mean Lloyds TSB centres in London and Birmingham will close over the next three years.

Lloyds TSB dismissed the claims as speculation. But John Bancroft, Unifi national officer, said: "It is clear that the bank at this stage is not offering redeployment in Lloyds TSB, or indeed voluntary severance. This may mean taking some form of action to fight to save jobs."

The union is to hold an emergency meeting with staff in London today.

Brussels lists EMI worries

EMI has received details of the European commission's objections to its proposed joint venture with Time Warner's music operations.

The commission announced in June it had begun a four-month extended inquiry into the link-up.

"We are not surprised by any of the issues identified in the document and at first reading we do not believe that these cause substantial obstacles to clearance," EMI said. "We remain confident that we are on track to close the venture by the end of this year as expected."

Oil to last 'at least 20 years'

Crude oil should be plentiful for at least 20 years but natural gas will take the world energy spotlight as the fuel of the future, Shell chairman Mark Moody-Stuart yesterday told the Offshore Northern Seas conference in Norway.

"We don't expect significant oil constraints until at least 2020," he said. He expected additional finds of natural gas. "There is a clear and understandable global trend for gas. In Shell, we have long seen a bright future for gas."

Mr Moody-Stuart said oil prices, at a new 10-year high of over $30 a barrel, were unlikely to fall soon.

Microsoft tries to apply brake

Microsoft has again urged the US Supreme Court to let its appeal against anti-competition findings be heard by a lower court first, saying the need for a thorough review was more important than speed.

The filing was a response to the justice department urging the court to consider the appeal on an expedited basis because of the case's importance to the economy.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in June ordered that the firm be split in two.

webTitle: Brown & Jackson blames disappointing sales on poor weather

fields.headline: Cloudy days
fields.standfirst: Brown & Jackson blames disappointing sales on poor weather
fields.trailText: Collapsing sales of sunglasses, tanning lotion and gardening equipment at discount retailer Brown & Jackson yesterday triggered fears of a long, hard summer for the high street.
fields.body:
Collapsing sales of sunglasses, tanning lotion and gardening equipment at discount retailer Brown & Jackson yesterday triggered fears of a long, hard summer for the high street.

The owner of the Poundstretcher, Your More Store and What Everyone Wants chains, said like-for-like sales had fallen 14% since the beginning of July.

But Brown & Jackson is pressing ahead with plans to open 100 stores each year for the next four, creating up to 1,500 jobs.

The sales update overshadowed a 33% profits surge to £31.7m for the year to June. The shares fell 11p to 125.5p.

Chief executive Johan Visser said: "You could almost say we haven't had a summer at all."

Poundstretcher usually sells more than £1m of gardening equipment a year. Mr Visser said revenue from these products had halved, with other seasonal goods suffering equally badly.

Brown & Jackson's woe prompted selling of retail stocks. Matalan fell 11p to 617p, New Look 5p to 86.5p and Marks & Spencer 3.25p to 208.5p.

webTitle: Botts hits at brewer in takeover battle

fields.headline: Botts hits at brewer in takeover battle
fields.trailText: The struggle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries turned nasty last night, as private equity firm Botts attacked the regional beer company for failing to take its £470m takeover approach seriously.
fields.body:
The struggle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries turned nasty last night, as private equity firm Botts attacked the regional beer company for failing to take its £470m takeover approach seriously.

Botts revealed it had financial backing from the American bank Merrill Lynch, as well as from Bank of Scotland and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. In a statement, the firm said it could increase its 500p-a-share proposal, if it was allowed access to Wolverhampton's books.

Botts expressed frustration at the attitude of W&D management, saying the regional brewing group had "summarily dismissed" its proposal on the grounds of conditionality, certainty and valuation - without bothering to ask about any of these issues.

W&D is Britain's biggest regional brewer - the company produces Banks's, Cameron and Pedigree ales. Its 1,700 pubs include the Pitcher & Piano and Varsity chains.

A Botts spokesman said: "They rejected our offer without even talking to us seriously."

W&D claims Botts wants to see unusually detailed figures - including a breakdown of revenue at individual pubs. It is reluctant to open up its books unless the private equity firm tables a formal takeover bid - which Botts says it cannot do without carrying out due diligence.

W&D's management was also put off by a request for exclusive negotiations, including a break fee if the brew agrees to a takeover by another party.

W&D's shareholders are split - Tweedy Brown, which has a 6% stake, has called on the management to hold serious bid talks. Another leading institutional investor said, however: "Until it becomes an official bid, the directors don't have to justify why they've turned it down. I'd rather see a proper bid, and then we can have a public debate."

The company's shares fell 12.5p to 459p. They have fallen from 600p this year, amid problems of integrating two recent acquisitions - Mansfield Brewery and Marston's, Thompson & Evershed.

fields.headline: Mercedes-Benz slashes UK prices
fields.standfirst: Carmaker says move is unrelated to competition commission report
fields.trailText: Luxury car maker DaimlerChrysler gave the debate over the strength of the pound a surprise twist yesterday when it announced it was cutting the list price of its Mercedes-Benz models by up to 20%.
fields.body:
Luxury car maker DaimlerChrysler gave the debate over the strength of the pound a surprise twist yesterday when it announced it was cutting the list price of its Mercedes-Benz models by up to 20%.

The group said the decision was unrelated to the recent competition commission report into car pricing which concluded that British car buyers were paying too much for cars and which prompted trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers to bring in measures to force prices lower.

Sales in the UK have also been affected by British motorists buying cars on the continent.

"We have been looking at comparative prices across Europe for several months. It [the price cut] was not because of the competition commission report," said a spokeswoman for DaimlerChrysler UK.

"It is the ongoing strength of the pound that has helped us to do this."

In recent months British car manufacturers have complained that the strength of the pound against the euro was making cars produced in Britain uncompetitive compared with those manufactured in the eurozone.

DaimlerChrysler does not manufacture in the UK and most of the cars sold in Britain are built in Germany.

Though the strength of the pound is cited as the main factor behind the price cuts - which average 9% - the spokeswoman said a fall in the value of the pound did not mean that prices would have to go back up.

"It hasn't done in the past," she said.

The cuts will mean a top of the range SL600 will fall in price from £96,370 to £80,900, while the price of a A140 Classic will come down from £14,490 to £12,790.

The spokeswoman said that the company had clocked up record sales in Britain in each of the past six years though she acknowledged that sales so far this year are slightly behind the total for the same period in 1999.

"That is because [sales of] the C class, our biggest seller, finished in April and the replacement is not due until September," she said.

Laurence Vaughan, chief executive of the quoted car dealer Sytner predicted the move would put pressure on other upmarket car makers to follow suit. "It will be difficult for other major manufacturers at our end of the market to ignore the [DaimlerChrysler] move," he said.

webTitle: Russia's naval illusions die with its sons

fields.headline: Russia's naval illusions die with its sons
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia's seafaring tradition is woven into the very fabric of Murmansk, the biggest city in the world north of the Arctic circle. Among its 400,000 people there is barely a family without ties to the fishing fleet, the merchant marine or the Russian navy.
fields.body:
Russia's seafaring tradition is woven into the very fabric of Murmansk, the biggest city in the world north of the Arctic circle. Among its 400,000 people there is barely a family without ties to the fishing fleet, the merchant marine or the Russian navy.

The city still displays the red stars, decorative anchors, and communist naval insignia that hark back to the glory days of the huge Soviet navy which projected the Kremlin's imperial power across the world's oceans.

But its docks are crumbling, the fjords of the Kola peninsula are littered with dozens of discarded or inoperable submarines lying abandoned like beached whales. The young seamen of the northern fleet go hungry and unpaid.

And in the wake of the Russian navy's worst peacetime disaster, the grim realisation has struck home as never before: the pipedreams of superpowerdom are gone, the admirals' arrogant delusions of geostrategic clout are risible, the Russian navy faces its biggest crisis of modern times.

"It's money, that's the big problem. Everything's destroyed," said Lilya, a local music teacher who spent the 1980s in Severomorsk, the northern fleet's home port outside Murmansk, with her navy officer husband.

"It was different in those days. Whatever Putin does now, there's no quick fix. The corruption, the thieving, the poverty: it will take a generation to sort things out."

Since Peter the Great built it from scratch three hundred years ago, the Russian navy has gone through several cycles of destruction and reconstruction at colossal cost and with great human suffering: in the Crimean war in the 19th century, in the war with Japan at the beginning of the 20th, in the 1930s, and during and after the second world war.

President Vladimir Putin now faces a comparable challenge. The Barents Sea tragedy has exposed the scale and depth of the naval crisis just when its commanders fostered the hope of supplanting the strategic missile forces as the key repository of the nuclear arsenal.

The senior officer who died in the Kursk, the chief of staff of the fleet's seventh submarine division, was paid £130 a month. The 118 crew were virtual strangers to life at sea, the cost of fuelling and maintaining the submarines being so great that only three of the fleet's 42 nuclear submarines are on patrol at any one time.

"The situation on the Kursk was like that on all the other submarines," Roman Kolesnikov, father of a lieutenant-captain who died in the Kursk, told a Russian newspaper.

"The fleet's repairs base has collapsed. The repair workers don't get paid and go on strike. Then the boat's commanders do the repairs themselves. They sit there all day and night doing the repairs. The boats are leaking.

"No wonder, the boat's only been in the dry dock once in five years. One day it came in to dock and they refused to accept it for repairs."

As the Kursk, the fifth Soviet or Russian submarine sunk in 20 years, lay at the bottom of the sea, one of the Russians' biggest humiliations was the sight of a dozen British and Norwegian divers promptly descending 108 metres to its stern and opening the escape hatch, if too late. "The Norwegian divers accomplished in six hours what the Russian rescuers couldn't achieve in seven days," the Moscow newspaper Vremya MN commented.

The northern navy spokesman, Vladimir Navrotsky, conceded that Russian divers could not go below 60 metres.

Mr Putin may try to exploit this wretched state of affairs by embarking on a more radical reform of the military, puncturing the bloated ambitions of the admirals and generals and tailoring the armed forces to Russia's straitened circumstances.

Heads are expected to roll. But Mr Putin has fed the ambitions of the top brass by repeatedly stressing how central the armed forces are to his promise to restore Russian greatness. The Kursk disaster has cruelly exposed the gap between his rhetoric and the reality experienced by Russia's conscripts and servicemen.

The deep sheltered fjords of the Kola peninsula around Murmansk are the main home of Russia's rickety fleet, and the world's biggest graveyard for nuclear-powered ships and submarines.

Two years ago the people of Murmansk were warned to take iodine pills during a nuclear fallout alert after a submarine fire. The authorities then claimed that the alarm was just an exercise.

"The whole Kola area is one big bomb," a Murmansk airport worker called Oleg said. "People here are very sad and angry about the Kursk, but they've long been fed up with the situation."

Against this background, the large billboards which appeared on the main roads of Moscow a couple of weeks ago look like a sick joke.

"A mighty navy for the glory of Russia," they proclaim, over a picture of a huge cruiser.

They could not have been put there without the Kremlin's blessing, and they chime with Mr Putin's promise to restore Russia's military strength.

Among its 400,000 people there is barely a family without ties to the fishing fleet, the merchant marine or the Russian navy. The city still displays the red stars, decorative anchors, and communist naval insignia that hark back to the glory days of the huge Soviet navy which projected the Kremlin's imperial power across the world's oceans. But its docks are crumbling, the fjords of the Kola peninsula are littered with dozens of discarded or inoperable submarines lying abandoned like beached whales. The young seamen of the northern fleet go hungry and unpaid. And in the wake of the Russian navy's worst peacetime disaster, the grim realisation has struck home as never before: the pipedreams of superpowerdom are gone, the admirals' arrogant delusions of geostrategic clout are risible, the Russian navy faces its biggest crisis of modern times. "It's money, that's the big problem. Everything's destroyed," said Lilya, a local music teacher who spent the 1980s in Severomorsk, the northern fleet's home port outside Murmansk, with her navy officer husband. "It was different in those days. Whatever Putin does now, there's no quick fix. The corruption, the thieving, the poverty: it will take a generation to sort things out." Since Peter the Great built it from scratch three hundred years ago, the Russian navy has gone through several cycles of destruction and reconstruction at colossal cost and with great human suffering: in the Crimean war in the 19th century, in the war with Japan at the beginning of the 20th, in the 1930s, and during and after the second world war. President Vladimir Putin now faces a comparable challenge. The Barents Sea tragedy has exposed the scale and depth of the naval crisis just when its commanders fostered the hope of supplanting the strategic missile forces as the key repository of the nuclear arsenal. The senior officer who died in the Kursk, the chief of staff of the fleet's seventh submarine division, was paid £130 a month. The 118 crew were virtual strangers to life at sea, the cost of fuelling and maintaining the submarines being so great that only three of the fleet's 42 nuclear submarines are on patrol at any one time. "The situation on the Kursk was like that on all the other submarines," Roman Kolesnikov, father of a lieutenant-captain who died in the Kursk, told a Russian newspaper. "The fleet's repairs base has collapsed. The repair workers don't get paid and go on strike. Then the boat's commanders do the repairs themselves. They sit there all day and night doing the repairs. The boats are leaking. "No wonder, the boat's only been in the dry dock once in five years. One day it came in to dock and they refused to accept it for repairs." As the Kursk, the fifth Soviet or Russian submarine sunk in 20 years, lay at the bottom of the sea, one of the Russians' biggest humiliations was the sight of a dozen British and Norwegian divers promptly descending 108 metres to its stern and opening the escape hatch, if too late. "The Norwegian divers accomplished in six hours what the Russian rescuers couldn't achieve in seven days," the Moscow newspaper Vremya MN commented. The northern navy spokesman, Vladimir Navrotsky, conceded that Russian divers could not go below 60 metres. Mr Putin may try to exploit this wretched state of affairs by embarking on a more radical reform of the military, puncturing the bloated ambitions of the admirals and generals and tailoring the armed forces to Russia's straitened circumstances. Heads are expected to roll. But Mr Putin has fed the ambitions of the top brass by repeatedly stressing how central the armed forces are to his promise to restore Russian greatness. The Kursk disaster has cruelly exposed the gap between his rhetoric and the reality experienced by Russia's conscripts and servicemen. The deep sheltered fjords of the Kola peninsula around Murmansk are the main home of Russia's rickety fleet, and the world's biggest graveyard for nuclear-powered ships and submarines. Two years ago the people of Murmansk were warned to take iodine pills during a nuclear fallout alert after a submarine fire. The authorities then claimed that the alarm was just an exercise. "The whole Kola area is one big bomb," a Murmansk airport worker called Oleg said. "People here are very sad and angry about the Kursk, but they've long been fed up with the situation." Against this background, the large billboards which appeared on the main roads of Moscow a couple of weeks ago look like a sick joke. "A mighty navy for the glory of Russia," they proclaim, over a picture of a huge cruiser. They could not have been put there without the Kremlin's blessing, and they chime with Mr Putin's promise to restore Russia's military strength.

webTitle: Market forces: Lloyds TSB is back in demand

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB is back in demand
fields.trailText: Shares in Lloyds TSB moved sharply higher yesterday as a huge American mutual fund decided to buy a chunk of the company.
fields.body:
Shares in Lloyds TSB moved sharply higher yesterday as a huge American mutual fund decided to buy a chunk of the company.

According to traders, the unnamed fund has decided to build a stake in Lloyds because it feels the bank is cheap on fundamentals and in comparison with the rest of the sector.

While the majority of banking shares have risen sharply in the wake of Barclays' (up 44p at £18.03) deal to acquire former building society Woolwich (33.5p higher at 365.5p), Lloyds' share have been sluggish on fears that it will have to make another acquisition to keep its profits coming.

Such concerns about the bank's ability to grow without another major cost cutting deal has been cited as one of the reasons for its poor performance over the past year. In the latest 12 months, Lloyds has underperformed the FTSE All-Share index by 30.4%.

In that time its position as the doyen of the banking sector has been taken by HSBC (21p stronger at 989p), whose shares have outperformed the All-Share by 19.1% in the same period.

There were suggestions yesterday that after HSBC's strong run, the US fund was switching it position in HSBC into Lloyds

By the close of play Lloyds shares were 52p higher at 650p after 63.5m shares had changed hands.

With the rest of the banking sector also in demand - Abbey National rose 29.5p to 843.5p, and Bank of Scotland added 20p to 588p - the FTSE 100 powered to an 11-week closing high of 6,584.8, up 42.6 points.

At its best the blue chip gauge pushed past 6,600, only to fall back as heavyweight telecoms stocks British Telecom , down 31p at 810p, and Vodafone , off 3p to 261.5p, were hit by another wave of selling. It emerged yesterday that BT has been forced to abandon roadshows for a bond sale of up to $10bn after rating agency Standard & Poor's threatened to make a greater than expected cut to its credit rating.

Software accountancy group Sage was among the star performers, rising 40p to 576p as rumours of a profits warning were crushed. After a meeting with Sage's finance director, Paul Harrison, at the end of last week, broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney was so confident the company will meet its forecasts that it has set a 715p price objective for the shares.

"Now that we are only six weeks from the end of its (Sage's) fiscal year, and given the quietly confident air of our meeting, we would be highly surprised if Sage was to bring back analyst numbers prior to the year end," SSSB said in a note to clients.

Billiton led a buoyant mining sector, rising 17p to 294p, closely followed by Anglo American , 114p stronger at £38.50, and Rio Tinto , up 9p to £11.72. Heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch was behind the gains.

In a note to clients the broker pointed out that a soft landing for the US economy (and therefore the global economy) is likely to be positive for the mining sector.

On Billiton, Merrill sees no reason why the company should trade at a discount to its net present value of 305p share. "We believe this company is undervalued in a neglected sector that is rapidly being re-discovered," it said in the note.

Marks & Spencer was again heading south. It shares fell 3.25p to 208.5p, unsettled by a depressing set of half time figures from its footwear supplier, Lambert Howarth , down 33.5p to 200p.

Lower down the corporate scale, Oxford Glycosciences fell 20.7.5p to £17.50, after UBS Warburg cut its rating on the highly-rated biotech outfit to "sell" from "buy".

The move followed comments in the latest edition of the Lancet Medical Journal, in which the safety and efficacy of its drug for Gaucher disease was brought into question.

webTitle: Israeli companies come to the fore

fields.headline: Israel comes to the fore
fields.trailText: Shares in Israeli-based companies Geo Interactive Media and BATM Advanced Communications rose sharply yesterday on rumours that heavyweight investment bank UBS Warburg is organising a trip to the region.
fields.body:
Shares in Israeli-based companies Geo Interactive Media and BATM Advanced Communications rose sharply yesterday on rumours that heavyweight investment bank UBS Warburg is organising a trip to the region.

According to the City gossips, UBS will be taking some of the City's biggest fund managers to Israel to find out more about companies like Geo and BATM, which have a London listing but are based in Israel.

Although both companies are now in the FTSE 250 after rule changes by index compiler FTSE International, they are still a mystery to many fund managers. In comparison with UK-based companies, both are covered by only a handful of research analysts.

Dealers believe the trip could help change that and are predicting some useful gains for the stocks when the fund managers return.

BATM shares rose 23.5p to 690p in trading yesterday, while Geo gained 47.5p to £14.25.

webTitle: Business notebook - There is no such thing as a free lunch

fields.headline: There is no such thing as a free lunch
fields.standfirst:
BT drags its feet over access fees

Net news

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: AltaVista's decision to pull the plug on its unmetered internet access package sparked a predictable round of recriminations yesterday.
fields.body:
AltaVista'sdecision to pull the plug on its unmetered internet access package sparked a predictable round of recriminations yesterday. AltaVista blamed BT, accusing the latter of failing to table an acceptable deal on wholesale call charges that would have allowed it to run unmetered services. Nonsense, said BT.

AltaVista cannot escape blame. It promised the service and failed to deliver. Whatever the obstacles that may or may not have been put in its way it should have made sure it could walk the walk before it talked the talk. The episode has left the company with serious amounts of egg on its face.

BT, however, should not be allowed to shrug of the affair as someone else's problem. True enough its Flat Rate Internet Access Call Origination offer to internet service providers does meet the guidelines laid down by the regulator Oftel. But it meets the letter rather than the spirit of the guidelines. The latest deal is a mixture of capped and open ended charges - making it impossible for ISPs to draw up solid plans for unmetered access.

There is a pattern here of BT dragging its feet on making the changes needed to set the UK's internet sector free.

The company has constantly delayed its launch of new broadband connections - its fourth delay has set back the roll-out of individual digital subscriber lines until next year - and this week Freeserve blamed BT for setting the basic charge for broadband access so high. At every turn BT has sought to protect its short-term monopolies for as long as possible.

One problem is that BT is a player in the ISP market as well as responsible for the local telecoms link. It was BT's Surftime package that stirred Oftel into action and made BT put together a flat rate offer to ISPs. Nothing has happened since then - a situation that helps no one except BT's own ISP.

Britain needs cheap, unlimited access to the net for individuals and small businesses. The regulator and the government must take a hard look at BT's actions and consider a response if that is the only way to achieve such a goal.

Rate dilemma

The European Central Bank is in a bind over whether to raise interest rates. It is damned if it does and damned if it doesn't. Judging by the results of yesterday's auction the betting in the financial markets is that the ECB will raise rates either at its August 31 or September 14 meetings. Others believe the bank might do better to wait a while until it has a clearer picture of what is happening in the eurozone.

The latest sickener for the bank materialised yesterday in the shape of the German Ifo business confidence index. The index was down in June but expected to perk up in July but fell again. One fall might be thought unfortunate, two cause for some concern. If the index falls again this month markets will be talking of a trend.

On the basis of that scenario the ECB might be thought wiser to stay its hand over interest rates. At a time when business confidence in the eurozone's biggest economy appears to be faltering even a 25 basis point rise in interest rates - let alone the 50 basis points some analysts are suggesting - would scarcely be a booster for corporate confidence.

But consider the alternative case. The ECB is thought to have been preparing the ground for an increase in rates because it is worried about inflationary pressures - generated in part by what has happened to oil prices but also by the weakness of the euro.

With the pessimists already believing that the single currency will be testing its all-time low soon and the doom sayers suggesting that 85 cents could be on the cards, the consequences of ducking a rise in interest rates which the markets are now expecting could be severe.

Raising rates looks an unattractive option. Unfortunately not raising looks worse. Faced with such a tricky choice the bank would be better off to increase interest rates. Its brief is price stability and as its neighbour, the Bundesbank, knows only too well - credibility is not easily earned. But how the ECB must envy the Federal Reserve which last night left US rates on hold without raising so much as a flicker in the markets.

Off the block

Another day, another auction. This time it is UK licences to provide wireless internet links for desktop computers which are on the block. After the success, from a taxpayers viewpoint, of the sale of third-generation mobile phone licences in the UK and Germany, it is little wonder that auctions are flavour of the month with licence sellers. But are the first signs of buyer resistance beginning to develop? Yesterday Atlantic Telecom which pioneered the technology in Britain said it would not be taking part, declaring it had better uses for its cash in developing existing licences. Governments be warned.

webTitle: Treasury taps new store of airwave riches

fields.headline: Treasury taps new store of airwave riches
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: The government's lucrative auctioning of airwaves yesterday focused on spectrum that will allow the delivery of high-speed internet access without a phone line.
fields.body:
The government's lucrative auctioning of airwaves yesterday focused on spectrum that will allow the delivery of high-speed internet access without a phone line.

Prospective bidders were told a reserve of £78.3m has been set for the auction of 33 licences, due to start on October 16.

Analysts expect the sale to raise significantly more than the reserve after the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences raised £22.5bn.

British and international telecom operators are said to be interested in licences for the 28GHz spectrum, to deliver internet and multimedia access by wireless links.

Operators will be able to bypass BT and the cable networks to provide such services to the small and medium-size businesses. Colt, Energis, Cable & Wireless and MCI WorldCom are understood to be among those interested.

Kim Howells, minister for competition and consumer af fairs, said: "We have decided on an auction process as it provides a fast, transparent, fair and economically efficient way of allocating the scarce resource of radio spectrum. The levels bid will reflect the bidders' own valuations of the licences and the opportunities they see for broadband fixed wireless access."

Atlantic Telecom has ruled itself out of the bidding for fear the auction process will inflate the price for licences.

The company already owns national licences for fixed wireless operations, but these are run on a different frequency.

Atlantic Telecom is viewed as a market leader in this area and built its strategy on attracting small to medium-size businesses with the promise of high-speed internet connection.

Some analysts have estimated the auction of the licences could raise at least £2bn for the Treasury's coffers.

The government will auction three licences in the 28GHz band in 11 regions. Those licences will last for 15 years.

A spectrum offering even higher speed broadband services at 40GHz, which would enable television and video conferencing on computers, may also be auctioned this year.

Britain is behind Switzerland, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Germany, which have already auctioned their licences for broadband wireless communications.

Switzerland's auction of 13 licences is understood to have raised about £150m.

fields.headline: Europe clears £2.3bn takeoverof Bass
fields.trailText: Bass formally ended its 223-year history of beer production yesterday, as the European commission handed over an investigation into the purchase of the group's breweries by Interbrew to trade secretary Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
Bass formally ended its 223-year history of beer production yesterday, as the European commission handed over an investigation into the purchase of the group's breweries by Interbrew to trade secretary Stephen Byers.

The decision meant the £2.3bn transaction was legally completed, sending Bass's shares up 15.5p to 746.5p. The deal is unconditional on clearance from the British authorities, even though Mr Byers is widely expected to order Belgian-based Interbrew to sell some beer brands.

Bass's chairman, Sir Ian Prosser, said he was delighted at the news. The group's six breweries employ 4,100 people, with large operations in Burton-on-Trent, Birmingham and Tadcaster.

The commission ruled that there were no problems with the sale of Bass's alcopops and its overseas distribution network. However, in a blow for Interbrew, the commission agreed with Mr Byers that there were "significant competitive issues" in the Belgian group taking a 32% share of the British beer market.

A spokesman for Interbrew said: "I wouldn't say we're disappointed. The fact that Mr Byers' clawback request was accepted is no surprise to us."

Interbrew is also buying the brewing operations of Whitbread. Its total portfolio will include three of Britain's leading lagers - Stella Artois, Carling and Tennent's.

Analysts believe the government may order Interbrew to sell Tennent's - which accounts for 43% of the beer drunk in Scotland. Interbrew is resisting any disposals, pointing out that its market share will be lower than those of leading brewers in many other European countries.

 French drinks group Rémy Cointreau is to take over its Dutch rival Bols in a deal worth €510m (£310m).
