webTitle: Mitsubishi admits 30-year cover-up of vehicle defects

fields.headline: Mitsubishi admits 30-year cover-up of vehicle defects
fields.trailText: Mitsubishi Motors will recall a million cars and may face criminal charges after admitting yesterday that it has systematically covered up vehicle defects for more than 30 years.
fields.body:
Mitsubishi Motors will recall a million cars and may face criminal charges after admitting yesterday that it has systematically covered up vehicle defects for more than 30 years.

"Illegal acts have taken place for a long time," the company's president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe said. "We deeply apologise for the immense anxiety we have caused our customers."

The company's share price dropped on the announcement, which is designed to put an end to a scandal that has raised questions about the standards of transparency and quality control at Japan's fourth biggest car maker.

Mitsubishi has been struggling to salvage its reputation since last month, when it emerged that half of its customer complaints were not being reported to the transport ministry. Employees marked such complaints with the letter "H" - the first letter of the Japanese word for "secret" - and covertly carried out repairs.

When the scandal broke, executives said this practice had been going on for only eight years. They recalled 514,000 vehicles with problems ranging from dangerous brake fittings to ill-fitting petrol caps.

In admitting the deep rooted nature of the problem yesterday, they expanded the recall including the Minicab, Lancer, Galant, Eterna, Emeraude, Diamante, Delica and six Fuso truck models.

Now Mitsubishi has admitted it will have to repair 800,000 vehicles in Japan, 50,000 in North America and 150,000 in Europe and other markets at a cost of 7.5bn yen (£45.2m). The transport ministry, which discovered lockers full of hidden complaints at the headquarters, is expected to impose financial penalties by the end of next month.

"It is regrettable Mitsubishi concealed the complaints," the transport minister Hajime Morita said. "This is something that shouldn't have taken place considering users' safety. I get the impression executives may have been aware."

Executives will have their salaries cut as a result of the scandal.

Yesterday, Mitsubishi's share price dropped a further 2%, taking the loss of value since the scandal broke to 10%.
fields.bodyText: Mitsubishi Motors will recall a million cars and may face criminal charges after admitting yesterday that it has systematically covered up vehicle defects for more than 30 years. "Illegal acts have taken place for a long time," the company's president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe said. "We deeply apologise for the immense anxiety we have caused our customers." The company's share price dropped on the announcement, which is designed to put an end to a scandal that has raised questions about the standards of transparency and quality control at Japan's fourth biggest car maker. Mitsubishi has been struggling to salvage its reputation since last month, when it emerged that half of its customer complaints were not being reported to the transport ministry. Employees marked such complaints with the letter "H" - the first letter of the Japanese word for "secret" - and covertly carried out repairs. When the scandal broke, executives said this practice had been going on for only eight years. They recalled 514,000 vehicles with problems ranging from dangerous brake fittings to ill-fitting petrol caps. In admitting the deep rooted nature of the problem yesterday, they expanded the recall including the Minicab, Lancer, Galant, Eterna, Emeraude, Diamante, Delica and six Fuso truck models. Now Mitsubishi has admitted it will have to repair 800,000 vehicles in Japan, 50,000 in North America and 150,000 in Europe and other markets at a cost of 7.5bn yen (£45.2m). The transport ministry, which discovered lockers full of hidden complaints at the headquarters, is expected to impose financial penalties by the end of next month. "It is regrettable Mitsubishi concealed the complaints," the transport minister Hajime Morita said. "This is something that shouldn't have taken place considering users' safety. I get the impression executives may have been aware." Executives will have their salaries cut as a result of the scandal. Yesterday, Mitsubishi's share price dropped a further 2%, taking the loss of value since the scandal broke to 10%.

fields.headline: Plants out of place
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Hot and humid, cool and wet, the weather changes every five minutes. Huge high-rise blocks of cloud produce fierce downpours, and the sunshine between them seems equally ferocious. Perhaps it's a vegetational taste in weather, but I like this spicy, growthful climate and prefer it to endless days of unbroken sunshine when everything browns to a crisp. Although this feels like proper Atlantic weather, not all our wild plants are best suited to it. Perhaps surprisingly, much of Shropshire's flora belongs to a continental biogeographical kind more characteristic of south-east England than the wetter Atlantic area to our west.

This is particularly emphasised by our rare plant species, half of which are really confined to the south-east. Two plants illustrate this well. Violet helleborine is flowering now on damp steep banks in Edge Wood where wild garlic died back leaving bare earth under full shade. These weird, almost anonymous orchids are an exciting note in the bald woodland patches.

The other plant is a tree - a species I knew was local to Wenlock Edge but one that I had not noticed until yesterday. In a stretch of ancient woodland on the steep sides of a valley dropping into a stream that feeds the Shienton brook and from there the Severn, is a strange flight of old brick steps. Having fallen down these steps in a treacherous winter slick, I have a tendency to look down and tread with care. This time, as a patch of sunlight lit up the trees at the top of the flight, I looked up. And there they were, all around me - wild service trees, Sorbus torminalis.

These trees, which the poet John Clare called the "tree of tawny berry rich though wild" were growing in their classic ancient woodland community of small-leafed lime, holly, yew and ash. Famed for their exotic-tasting fruits and a drink once associated with Chequers pubs, these are trees of the southern Weald of Kent and Hampshire, even though the species does occur much further north. The berries taste best after autumn frosts. Roll on autumn.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: What a delightful man my friend Paul Daniels is.
fields.body:
 What a delightful man my friend Paul Daniels is. Martin Kelner writes to say thanks for all the extracts from Book of the Month Under No Illusion - snippets concerning not only Paul's mesmeric power over women but also such contributions to race relations as the explanation as to why the word "nigger" is not offensive and the claim to have been served dog in an upmarket Bombay restaurant.

"These extracts add a new dimension to his appearances on the re-runs on Granada Plus of ancient episodes of the Wheeltappers' and Shunters' Social Club," writes Martin. A fine show, the Wheeltappers'. The late Colin Crompton is much missed. "Given the priapic prankster's strange 1970s thatch and hilarious white suit," Martin continues, "one assumes it is charm and wit that account for his remarkable strike rate [with women]. Handed a 50p piece by one of his stooges on Sunday night's show, Paul said: 'It's shaped like that so you can get it out of a Jew's hand with a spanner.' Priceless."

Yes, priceless indeed.

 The 50p piece is quite a motif with Paul, to judge by a letter from Klim Pye, who recalls an incident from April 1992 when he was busking outside Kings Cross. "Paul Daniels happened by, along with a large lady minder. The millionaire held a 50p coin in front of my face until I stopped playing, I took it from him and put it in the hat." Klim considered his options for a moment, and did his duty. "I skimmed the coin down the tunnel, just missing him as he turned down the stairs ... but I guess he heard the satisfying clinking behind him. I was playing Wooden Heart at the time. I wonder if he remembers?"

 Never in all the years I've been turning out this drivel has anything - not even the Oooh You Amaze Me T-shirts offer - provoked a post bag like the one concerning the Cumberland Pencil Museum in Keswick.

Thanks for all the letters and emails, especially to Lionel Burman, who writes at length from Merseyside warning parents to prepare for long visits because children love it so much. He also mentions the now sadly extinct Museum of Contraceptive Technique, while someone called WJSK emails to praise the French. "Not even Devon's best," he posits, "can compare with Agen's superb Prune Museum."

 Hype about a snap October election is baffling. Mr Tony Blair may not be the brightest, bless him, but is he likely to risk an election almost immediately after three weeks of the Olympics? Assuming our athletes perform as usual, the papers and phone-ins will be doing the requisite "What's wrong with Britain?" self-pitying whine. So I think you can rule out October. And remember, this is the column that brought you the "Gordon and Sarah ... it's over for ever" exclusive, so you can trust us.

 Is there no limit to the versatility of Valerie Leon? Already familiar to readers as a uniquely fearsome PR, not to mention the shop girl who erected Charles Hawtrey's tent in Carry On Camping, Valerie appears now to have appointed herself co-diarist. "Does this inspire you?" begins her latest fax. "Titillating Tania the Lotus Eater (alias Valerie Leon) was first seen wielding her whip by private arrangement with Cato in Return of the Pink Panther. They are to revive their dubious partnership for the Hungarian Cultural Centre, who are celebrating the extraordinary life of national poet Janos Pilinszky at the Hampstead Theatre on Sunday August 27. Valerie (add your usual Carry On Camping blurb) has promised me a private session with her whip if I mention the event." Excellent. Welcome aboard, Val.

 There is no news today of kidnap victim Gerald Kaufman. However, negotiations with splinter terrorist group the Real GAF (Judy Garland Appreciation Front) reopened late on Monday night, and we are quietly hoping for an announcement tomorrow.

fields.headline: Motorists face 25% rise in insurance
fields.standfirst: Report blames rise in injury claims and dearer car parts
fields.trailText: Car insurance premiums could rise by 25% this year, as companies contend with a sharp increase in personal injury claims and soaring costs for replacement car parts and garage call-outs, a report by the market analysts Mintel warns.
fields.body:
Car insurance premiums could rise by 25% this year, as companies contend with a sharp increase in personal injury claims and soaring costs for replacement car parts and garage call-outs, a report by the market analysts Mintel warns.

The rise follows last year's increase of 20% - and is set to continue, with the average cost of insuring a car rising from £226 in 1999 to £283 this year and £353 in 2001.

The report, which looks at all areas of motor insurance, makes sombre reading for a nation that is increasingly car-dependent. Nearly 30m private cars are expected on the roads by 2004, compared with some 25m in 2000, despite the government's attempts to make public transport more appealing, and an increase in petrol prices from 70p a litre to 85p in the past year - an 18% rise.

But Paul Davies, finance consultant at Mintel and the report's author, said the steep increase - which is expected to continue beyond next year - is partly the result of "artificially low" insurance premiums during the mid to late 90s caused by new companies such as Direct Line, Admiral and Churchill provoking fierce competition.

"The introduction of companies like Direct Line, which has far lower overheads, meant they could undercut traditional providers and they then dropped their rates as well," he said.

"That's meant the industry's been running at a loss - and it's been doing that since 1994, with an estimated £900m deficit last year.

"They're now trying to recoup that by trying to get premiums back to realistic levels. But it's very hard for consumers to see that."

The rise has also been due to the Ogden and Woolf changes - the law commission's recommendation, made last year, on personal and injury payouts which means victims of car crashes can now claim for future care costs and potential loss of earnings. The changes are estimated to have cost motor insurers an extra £450m last year.

The NHS can now charge insurance companies for the cost of treating victims of road accidents, causing claims to rise further. The average claim for a car covered by comprehensive insurance has soared by 53% in the past decade.

Despite the steep increase in costs to drivers, the report, Motor Insurance, predicts the UK motor insurance market is unlikely to record a profit until 2002 "at the earliest". That has bad ramifications for consumers: "We predict the increases will be sustained over the next few years," said Mr Davies, "because the market has to return to profitability."

But drivers could benefit once selling insurance on the internet - which now accounts for only 1% of all sales - picks up.

"Insurers are confident that the internet will have a key role to play in car insurance distribution in the future," said Mr Davies. "And with lower overheads, that could mean drivers get a better deal. Motor insurance is very cyclical, so in two or three years it could be more affordable."

The AA said dearer insurance added to the pressure on motorists on top of the increase in petrol prices. But a spokesman added: "You can guarantee there'll be another price war in a couple of years and then there'll be more value to be had."

webTitle: Three days and two nights had taken its toll. Then Jimi started to play

fields.headline: Three days and two nights had taken its toll. Then Jimi started to play
fields.standfirst: Thirty years ago this weekend the Isle of Wight hosted the ultimate British rock festival.  John Hudson  recalls sneaking in through a gap in the fence
fields.trailText: Thirty years ago this weekend the Isle of Wight hosted the ultimate British rock festival. John Hudson recalls sneaking in through a gap in the fence.
fields.body:
It was the greatest British superfest of all time. The biggest acts, the biggest crowd and the biggest debacle. I was 16, and with 600,000 other fans crossed to the Isle of Wight to be with Jimi Hendrix, the Doors, the Who, and a Who's Who of 1970s rock stars. Fans had been there all week and had set up a large area of troll shanties. Bare-chested Vikings with flares and harmonicas watched lethargically as thousands of newcomers passed through their settlement. Most were heading for the hill.

The organisers had thoughtfully constructed a secure arena that was overlooked by a hill that provided exceptional sound reception and an unparalleled view of the stage. They must have assumed that no one would want to spend three days on a slope as no attempt was made to prevent fans from taking up their free grandstand seats. Much of the hill was already occupied when we arrived. Only the steeper sections were vacant, but we found that by sitting in the scrubby bushes we could prevent ourselves from sliding down. As the summer light began to fade and the first acts started performing, the breeze rolled the clouds from 100,000 joints up the hillside.

Later that night, realising their error, the organisers made a three- pronged attack on the hill. First they tried turning the volume down. This provoked loud protests from everyone in the arena who was more than 50 yards from the stage. Second, a searchlight was turned on to discomfort those on the hill by not allowing them to sleep. This provided us with welcome light to peel oranges, open packets of biscuits and pee without saturating someone's sleeping bag. It also let latecomers know that they could still get a free seat in the gods, stage right. Finally, an agitated man came to the mike and begged us to decamp immediately or the festival would be cancelled. Heavy.

There was always a presumption that if enough people turned up, like Woodstock in the US the year before, it would become a free festival. We woke on Saturday to the sight of 20 or so Hell's Angels wielding spanners and long bar socket sets and heading purposefully in our direction. As we cowered in our bush they suddenly veered off towards the arena fence. Within a minute, operating quicker than Kwik Fit fitters, they had removed a 10-metre section of perimeter fencing. With whoops of triumph the hordes from the hill poured through the gap and spilled into the arena. The organisers' announcement - "We have decided to open the gates. This is now a free festival" - was met with roars of approval from everyone, apart from those who had paid for their tickets and were now being jostled for space by crowds of freeloaders.

It didn't take us long to realise that we had unwittingly swapped the royal box for Bedlam. Bodies lay everywhere on the urine-soaked ground of the arena. Bad-trippers flailed at the air and screeched at devils. Some rocked and hugged themselves, other wept with their eyes screwed tight against the frenzy. The volume of noise from the louder bands rushed through bodies like clumsy ultrasound. Joni Mitchell left the stage in tears and several acts disappointed hugely. We saw hippies come to blows. We left for the safety of our eyrie.

Appeals to raise money for drug busts were broadcast frantically amid longer and longer periods of silence from the stage. Rumours were rife that the organisers now could not afford the acts they had booked, and music was increasingly confined to records. Desperate times called for a desperate act. It still comes as a terrible shock to me to realise that I had travelled the length of the country to see, among others, Tiny Tim. It comes as an even bigger shock to remember that, with every other member of the crowd, we gave him an enormous welcome and demanded encores. He was not good - he was never good - but cometh the hour, came the falsetto.

Sunday morning brought more problems. The PA system spluttered and stuttered. Appeals for cash became increasingly hysterical. Announcements became more bizarre: "Could the person who left the hand-grenade in the shelter tent please come and collect it..." "Could somebody please claim the girl with tattooed tits in the first aid tent. She has forgotten who she is." More feedback squeals, whirrs, pops and silence. Early morning golfers were horrified to find tents pitched on the green at the back of the hill, but still putted out among the debris.

The crowd took to providing its own entertainment. I have an abiding image of a man playing pleasant acoustic guitar on a doorless toilet while the cubicle next to him burned furiously. The biggest cheer of the day came for a record, and we sang along ponderously: "Layzee Sunday Afternoonah..."

The pervading weltschmerz was further deepened by the growing rumours that Hendrix had cried off. Some had already started on the trek to the ferries. If you wanted proof that this was not the 60s, it was all around. The daring and freshness of Woodstock had here become humourless and tired. The chaos had started to matter. We were going through the motions. Lots of doubts, little direction, waiting and taking stock after an incandescent decade.

Three days and two nights had taken its toll on the crowd and many now slept. Unannounced, Hendrix started to play in the early hours of Monday morning. I slept through his opening number and then found myself sitting in the dark with half a million people, just listening. Strangely, you could sense the crowd's restraint. It was as if by shouting or applauding we would miss something or alter the focus. We looked down at the brightness of the stage and the first haunting bars of All Along the Watchtower spiralled back to us. Three weeks later Hendrix was dead and all we had were the LPs and the memories from the hill.

Someone mentioned the Isle of Wight festival at the pub the other night. No one had actually been, but they all spoke of it with affection and how it was the great musical event of all time. It is perhaps not peculiar that people who were not there know more about it than those who were. The longing may well outweigh the experience. In the minds of men and women, time has certainly done the Isle of Wight festival 1970 a favour. But I bet there are 600,000 of us who still wouldn't have changed it, or missed it for the world.

webTitle: Jonathan Freedland: Northern Ireland's Troubles internalised with loyalists killing loyalists.

fields.headline: Internalising the Troubles
fields.standfirst:
Belfast shootings: As factions get out their guns, the Tories are flirting with a rejection of the peace process
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Belfast shootings: As factions get out their guns, the Tories are flirting with a rejection of the peace process.
fields.body:
So to the land of the real north-south divide, where the border is real rather than metaphorical and what's at stake are not house prices but life and death. For in Ireland the killing has returned - though now it wears a different face. It is no longer a struggle between two sides fighting to erase or preserve that border between north and south. The new Troubles are troubles within - loyalists killing loyalists.

One gang attacked the other's parade on Saturday and the familiar revenge tragedy began in earnest: tit for tat, this life for that one, your eye for mine. The combatants are loyalist factions whose names form an alphabet soup of fratricidal rivalry: the UDA and UFF, backed by the UDP, on one side; and the UVF, backed by the PUP, on the other. It could be an Ulster production of Monty Python's Life of Brian - with the People's Front of Judea at daggers' drawn with the Judean People's Front. It could be, except two men were left dead on Monday, and four others have been killed in loyalist feuding these last few months - so no one is laughing.

What should those who wish only peace for Northern Ireland - and who had half thought we'd got there - think now? Is this a threat to the peace process or is it internal housekeeping, the equivalent of a mafia war where hoods rub out hoods but "civilians" are in no danger?

The quick and reassuring answer is that the latest round of violence is an internal matter. It represents a battle for supremacy in the Shankill estate, with the Ulster Freedom Fighters' Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair, only recently released from the Maze prison, bidding for turf and power: Mad Dog wants to be top dog. Those on the ground are in little doubt that he is fomenting the current trouble: he wants to be the lord of the Shankill.

There is something reassuring about this view. The men may be brutal, their terrain may be benighted, but it seems safely distant from the peace process. After all, and in true Monty Python style, no one can name a doctrinal difference that separates Adair's UFF from the Ulster Volunteer Force which it hates so bloodily. It is not as if they are fighting over the details of the Good Friday agreement. On the contrary, the political wings of both paramilitary organisations were committed to the agreement earlier and with more enthusiasm than David Trimble's officially more moderate Ulster Unionist party.

Still, though it may be comforting to see the current bloodletting as a Belfast episode of the Sopranos, it might also be a mistake. For there is danger here for Northern Ireland's fragile peace.

For one thing, even though Adair may look like a gangland thug he is not without politics. Under his watch, the UFF and its allies in the Ulster Defence Association have cosied up to the ultra-hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force. Unlike the other organisations, the LVF was never a serious partner in the peace process: it is a rejectionist outfit whose creed was horrific violence. If Adair is taking a movement that was once inside the peace tent and moving it outside, then that is a cause for real alarm.

The current violence could derail the peace process in a more direct way. "The traditional way these things end is by killing some taigs," says one watchful republican. He worries that loyalist internecine feuding rarely stays internecine for long: eventually they murder Catholics, if only to assert their status as the chief defenders of their community. Belfast's Catholics will be locking their doors more tightly tonight.

But there is a deeper challenge the men of loyalist violence pose to the accord. For what they have exposed are the places where the politicians failed.

Start with the opponents of Good Friday. What the last few days prove is that Unionism's hardliners, along with their allies on the British right, were looking in the wrong direction all along. Throughout the 1990s they were obsessed with the IRA; they rarely made a squeak about the armed men of loyalism.

They ignored the fact that the most vicious crimes of the Troubles were often committed by men pledging allegiance to the Union flag: witness the 1970s killing spree of the Shankill Butchers. British security sources privately admit that, while they faced in the IRA a disciplined organisation all but run like an army, they often confronted in loyalism men who seemed driven less by politics than psychopathy (or the racketeering pursuit of personal profit).

The rejectionists may also have been looking the wrong way when they chose their ground for opposition. The deal-breaker for them was always decommissioning - usually of republican weapons. John Hume kept on saying that disarmament was a red herring: you could give up guns on Monday only to buy new ones on Tuesday. Others quietly warned that the bitterest pill would be the release of prisoners - not just republican killers like those behind the 1984 Brighton bomb, but also the likes of Mad Dog Adair. Yet there was only room in the rejectionists' quiver for one arrow, and they aimed it at guns rather than at the men who might wield them.

But it is not just the naysayers who made mistakes. The British and Irish governments can also be faulted for failing to give sufficient support to the leaders who sought to turn the Shankill away from killing and toward politics. Men like the UDP's Gary McMichael and the ultra-impressive David Ervine of the PUP had their work cut out. At least Sinn Fein had a tradition of political republicanism to draw on; McMichael and Ervine were seeking to turn around movements whose entire existence had been dedicated to sectarian violence. The result is that McMichael is fast being eclipsed; he has too little muscle to wrestle the Mad Dog, let alone call him to heel.

The peacemakers of loyalism needed some help if they were to take on both their hardmen and their history. Theirs is a society where the language of gradualism and compromise has little appeal; their constituency is the loyalist male who feels left behind by the new economy of Northern Ireland and who misses the old tribal certainties.The politicians can only promise slow, hard answers, while Mad Dog and his gang offer something shorter and sharper.

What to do now? One quick remedy is to put Johnny Adair back where he belongs: behind bars. Like all the released prisoners, he was let out on condition. Now that he is failing to comply with the new dispensation, his licence should be withdrawn. He may have made some pro-peace noises when he was in jail but he did that because he wanted to get out: he talked the talk so he could walk the walk.

After that, the peacemakers need to help each other - today it's the beleaguered leaders of political loyalism, tomorrow it might be moderate republicans. They can start by boasting of their achievements. Just yesterday, while troops were back on the streets of Belfast, a trade mission arrived from Northern Ireland in Boston. It was led by the Ulster Unionist minister for trade and investment, Reg Empey, and included members of all the province's parties - including Sinn Fein's Pat Doherty, whose links to the IRA are close. Once such a shared mission would have been unimaginable; today it is becoming routine. While the thugs of the Shankill murder each other, the rest of Northern Ireland's people need to remember how far they have come - and to keep their eyes on the prize.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £10,000 Tokyo reward
fields.body:
£10,000 Tokyo reward

The family of Lucie Blackman, the former British Airways stewardess missing in Tokyo, offered a £10,000 reward yesterday for information about her whereabouts.

Detectives have been looking for the 21-year-old from Sevenoaks, Kent, since July 1.

Big Brother tensions mount

Contestants in Channel 4's Big Brother game show were stunned yesterday to find four of them nominated for eviction at the end of the week. Darren had three votes, with Anna, Thomas and Craig scoring two each.

Emergency exit in a good cause

Two fundraisers making their first parachute jump were ordered out of the aircraft early when the engine cut out. Sarah Jonsson, 28, and Emma White, 24, and their instructors took an emergency tumble over Somerset at 5,000ft.

Mountaineering record set

A British mountaineer is returning home today after knocking four years off the record for scaling the highest peaks in all 47 European countries. Rod Baber, 29, set out in 1998 and completed the feat by climbing Turkey's Mount Ararat.

Car dumping problem

Thousands of cars are being left by roadsides or in inner city areas, the RAC said yesterday. Its Chief executive, Edmund King, said: "Falling values for used cars and scrap metal means that many motorists don't dispose of their vehicles properly."

Here's one from a lot earlier

A trawler made a mammoth catch - bones from the prehistoric hairy elephant. Les Brand,skipper of the Apryl Louise, found the bones when he arrived back in Harwich.

Jerry Bowdrey, of the Natural History Museum in Colchester, said: "They are from the Pleistocene period of nearly 1m years ago."

webTitle: Pakistani army squeezes out political parties

fields.headline: Pakistani army squeezes out political parties
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's generals are about to rewrite the country's constitution, setting in stone their ambitious plans to hold local elections despite mounting opposition.
fields.body:
Pakistan's generals are about to rewrite the country's constitution, setting in stone their ambitious plans to hold local elections despite mounting opposition.

After years of army rule and a decade of democracy sullied by corruption, nepotism and greed, the military regime insists locally elected councils are the first step to solving Pakistan's crisis of governance.

Two constitutional amendments will formalise the new system and make it harder for future rulers to undo the reforms.

"We will take all possible measures to ensure that the local government system cannot be reversed by succeeding governments," said Tanvir Naqvi, a retired four-star general whose National Reconstruction Bureau drew up the reforms.

Voting will begin in December to elect the hundreds of 21-seat councils across the country, with women competing for six of the seats in each council.

The council leaders will in turn sit on larger district bodies and will have all-important control of police and local bureaucrats. The army will remain in control of the country.

The elections, which will run in phases until next August, will replace a 200-year-old system of appointed bureaucrats set up under British colonial rule.

However, the proposals have aroused the broadest criticism of General Pervez Musharraf's regime since the army took over in a coup last October. The wave of opposition, coupled with a deepening economic crisis, threatens to challenge the military's authority.

With the country's flagging economy adding to the new regime's woes, Gen Musharraf complained yesterday that Britain is not helping him trace at least 14 people who fled to the UK and are alleged to have plundered billions of pounds from Pakistan's coffers.

This followed a meeting on Monday with Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, during which Gen Musharraf tried to win financial help from Pakistan's biggest traditional lender. Hoping to revive Japanese lending, which was frozen after the 1998 nuclear tests, the general promised not to be the first to break his country's moratorium on testing.

"We were not the first to test, and will not be the first to resume testing," Gen Musharraf said. But he warned that Pakistan would respond if its arch-rival India tested again. He stopped short of meeting Mr Mori's demand that Islamabad sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. Mr Mori said sanctions could not be lifted unless both sides signed the treaty.

In Islamabad, many politicians and analysts have dismissed the general's local government reforms as unworkable and claim they are a thinly disguised attempt to undermine national political parties.

"This whole project towards bringing democracy may be a great failure if [the generals] don't realise that the political parties are a source of strength for a bright future for Pakistan," said Talat Masood, a retired Pakistani army general and newspaper columnist. "If [the parties] are weakened, then what is left for Pakistan?"

Gen Musharraf has promised to keep to a supreme court ruling which requires him to hold general elections by October 2002. But he has already tried to curb political opposition, suspending both houses of parliament and banning political rallies.

Candidates in December's local elections will be allowed to contest the seats only as independents, not on a party basis.

For some, Gen Musharraf's approach brings back memories of earlier military dictators such as Ayub Khan, in the 1960s, and Zia ul-Haq, two decades later. Both used local elections to stifle organised political opposition.

"In principle, I don't think anyone would argue that there should be a devolution of power in Pakistan," said Khalid Rahman, director of Islamabad's Institute of Policy Studies. "But this is really not very well prepared. The government is claiming this is the first step towards democracy but then they are saying elections will be on a non-party basis. That contradiction doesn't help us understand how a democracy will come from this."

At the same time, the general appears to be trying to ensure a permanent role for the army in future democratic governments.

Last week he cleaned out civilian advisers from his top policy-making body, the National Security Council, and promoted his four most important ministers to sit alongside the armed forces chiefs. Since the coup, the council has created policy, while the larger cabinet has taken a secondary role.

"It is an attempt to impose a permanent role for the military," said Rashed Rehman, a columnist at The News, an English-language daily. "They are looking for the perpetuation of a system in which the army calls the shots."

But Gen Musharraf insists Pakistan has no future if it returns power to the democratic leaders of the past decade.

"They have put Pakistan on the road to destruction," he said. "They are people who consider themselves gods and they want to impose their will on the people."

fields.headline: Revealed: Israel's nuclear site
fields.standfirst:
Photographs showing development of the secret reactor at Dimona give an insight into more than 30 years of weapons development

Special report: Israel and the Middle East

Net news

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: New photographs of the secret Israeli reactor at Dimona, published on the internet, confirm that Israel could have made 100-200 nuclear weapons, according to the Federation of American Scientists.
fields.body:
New photographs of the secret Israeli reactor at Dimona, published on the internet, confirm that Israel could have made 100-200 nuclear weapons, according to the Federation of American Scientists.

The high-resolution pictures, taken last month by Space Imaging Corporation's Ikonos satellite, are likely to settle arguments about how much plutonium the reactor can produce - from which the size of Israel's weapons stockpile can be calculated.

"Based on plausible upper and lower bounds of the operating practices at the reactor, Israel could have produced enough plutonium for at least 100 nuclear weapons, but probably not significantly more than 200 weapons," says the FAS.

It says the pictures support claims that Israel could be using highly enriched uranium to build nuclear weapons, or to increase the yield of plutonium weapons.

Buildings can be seen which may be associated with two techniques for uranium production: gas centrifuge and laser separation. But the size of the buildings suggests that uranium enrichment at Dimona is carried out on a relatively small scale.

The pictures show that dozens of small buildings have been added to the 14 square mile site in the Negev desert over the last 30 years. There are two extra medium-sized buildings measuring 26,500 and 30,100 sq ft, and a large building of 84,000 sq ft has been expanded to 103,700 sq ft (9,569 square metres).

The FAS, a Washington-based organisation which lobbies on scientific issues and includes 51 Nobel laureates among its sponsors, says there are several "interesting terrain features" at Dimona whose purpose has not been identified.

Pictures taken in the 1960s revealed a large excavation area, from which the Israelis removed an estimated 66,000 to 81,000 cubic yards of earth. The latest pictures show efforts to landscape the same area. The FAS suggests this may conceal a large underground reprocessing facility.

Just over half a mile from the main site, the pictures show what is believed to be a burial area for low-level radioactive waste.

Israel, the only nuclear power which does not admit to possessing nuclear weapons, has always refused to allow international inspection of the site.

In 1986, Mordechai Vanunu, who was a technician at Dimona, was abducted by Mossad agents in London and sentenced to 18 years in prison for providing information about Dimona, including pictures, to the Sunday Times.

The latest pictures have been shown on Israeli television and published in a newspaper, under a rule allowing material available on the internet to escape the military censor, as long as the source is mentioned.

Israel is one of a handful of countries which have refused to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Israel was singled out at the NPT review conference in New York in May for not placing its nuclear materials under "comprehensive" international safeguards.

Israel's nuclear weapons programme was debated for the first time in the Knesset, the country's parliament, in February this year.

Israel was said to have stockpiled up to 300 bombs, developed with the help of the South African apartheid regime, and it was planning to adapt submarines recently bought from Germany to carry nuclear missiles.

Though Shimon Peres, the father of the country's nuclear programme, has admitted that Dimona was built as a deterrent, Israel maintains an official policy of ambiguity, saying only that it will not be the first to "introduce" nuclear weapons in the Middle East.

webTitle: Gazing in awe at executive salaries, US-style

fields.headline: Gazing in awe at executive salaries, US-style
fields.trailText: While the salaries of British company directors seem stratospheric to the average worker, executives themselves look enviously at their US colleagues whose remuneration packages are in a different league.
fields.body:
While the salaries of British company directors seem stratospheric to the average worker, executives themselves look enviously at their US colleagues whose remuneration packages are in a different league.

The world's best paid director, according to Forbes magazine is Charles Wang, chief executive of Computer Associates, who was paid $650m (£437m) last year, mostly because of stock options. In the number two spot, Bobby Johnson from telecoms firm, Foundry Networks, pocketed $230m, again largely due to stock options.

As is the case in Britain, US corporate salaries are rising much faster than average earnings. Business Week's annual survey revealed that the average American chief executive made $12.4m last year, a 17% rise on 1998. This means that executive pay packets are a staggering 475 times larger than the pay of the average American manufacturing employee.

The pay gap between chief executives and workers is not as marked in Britain where bosses typically earn around 24 times the average manufacturing salary, according to remuneration experts Towers Perrin. The gap in Britain is the widest in Europe. In Germany, the average chief executive earns 15 times the average manufacturing workers' pay, while in egalitarian Sweden executive pay is 13 times greater.

The Guardian-Inbucon survey of boardroom rewards established that the most expensive board is Vodafone's where directors' salaries account for 27% of the cost, not as high as the 40% cost of the directors' of Energis in comparison with their workforce.

David Marsden, an industrial relations expert at the London School of Economics, says US-style pay packets are becoming more common on the continent, which will widen the gap between workers and their bosses.

The driving force is the move by European companies to tap the global equity markets for cash rather than relying on bank finance. This in turn is exposing them to shareholder pressures to perform.

The usual justification for the bonuses and stock options which boost US and British pay packets is that it keeps managers working in shareholders' interests by rewarding them when the share price improves. In fact, Mr Marsden says the performance hurdles chief executives must meet are often set so low that they collect even in bad years.

An alternative explanation sometimes advanced is that huge chief-executive pay packets exist simply to promote competition further down the corporate hierarchy. By striving to do well in order some day to become the boss, middle managers improve the performance of the whole company. Mr Marsden suggests that if this theory is correct it really does not matter what the chief executive does all day - he or she is just there to provide an illustration of the rewards of success.

But there are alternatives to this winner takes all approach. In Japan, chief-executive pay is deliberately linked to pay throughout the company because firms believe it encourages team work. Chief executives earn just 11 times the average worker's salary.

Mr Marsden suggests that for new economy firms where team work and shared knowledge are important a flatter pay structure may be more effective at drawing the best performance out of the entire workforce. The dot.com bubble appears to have burst but the employee share options schemes they favoured may still have a future.

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
As a result of the heat, I have been considering forming a comic book-style vigilante group called The Priority Seat "Men". This will consist of myself (in my current guise of pregnant woman with no ankles), an older person, someone on crutches and a person carrying infant triplets. Together we will ride rush hour tubes and stand near to so-called priority seats occupied by teenagers or able-bodied business folk.

You will say that this sounds like a sad case of tube rage. I say that at least tube rage is better (or less self-destructive) than office rage, which is what my case this week was all about. My client, Mr Angry, had been sacked after a pushing and shoving incident between him and a colleague, Mr Enraged, over whose turn it was to use a photocopier. The star piece of evidence on the employers' side, was a blurred photocopy which appeared to show Mr Angry holding Mr Enraged down by his ears.

On our side we seemed to have two main lines of attack:

1) A petition circulated by Mr Angry amongst his colleagues to demonstrate how out of character the incident was. There were 22 signatures. Great, except for two appended notes: "Except when provoked by circumstances not of his own making," and "Not so as to actually hurt anyone." Mr Angry took a little persuading that this document was not really going to assist him.

2) Mr Enraged was not sacked as a result of the incident. Mr Angry's view of this was that the difference in treatment amounted to race discrimination, because he was black and Mr Enraged was white. The employer said there was a difference in treatment because Mr Angry had a history of aggressive behaviour and Mr Enraged did not. At least I thought that was the issue. Until counsel for the employer asked to have a word before we went into the tribunal.

Counsel for the employer: "You do realise that your race discrimination case doesn't make any sense."

Me: "Why not?"

Him: "Because Mr Enraged is also black."

Me: "But Mr Angry says he's white."

After a directionless morning during which Mr Angry insisted that Mr Enraged was white and counsel for the employers insisted he was black, Mr Enraged turned up. One is a bit wary about jumping to conclusions, but he did look black. I turned to Mr A and whispered: "Do you really want me to put to this man that he is white?"

The steam seemed suddenly to seep out of Mr Angry: "I guess not." Maybe rage is just blinding. I myself did experience a fog of red before the eyes as I stood beside a geezer in a priority seat on my way back to chambers.

Before I realised he was asleep.

webTitle: Mandela urges Liberia to release C4 crew

fields.headline: Mandela urges Liberia to release C4 crew
fields.trailText: The former South African president Nelson Mandela yesterday telephoned the president of Liberia and urged him to release the Channel 4 television crew who are facing espionage charges.
fields.body:
The former South African president Nelson Mandela yesterday telephoned the president of Liberia and urged him to release the Channel 4 television crew who are facing espionage charges.

Mr Mandela told Charles Taylor that even if the Liberian authorities had a watertight case against the four men, "it would be a wonderful gesture if he could pardon or release the four journalists". Mr Taylor said he needed a day or two to consider the matter, according to Mr Mandela's spokeswoman, Zelda La Grange.

Meanwhile, Britain warned Liberia that detaining the two Britons, a Sierra Leonean and a South African, who were all working on a documentary for Channel 4, set the west African state on a collision course with the international community. "They are not spies, they are journalists, and this is an attack on international press freedom," the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain told BBC radio.

The four are David Barrie and Zimbabwean-born Timothy Lambon, both Britons, Gugulakhe Radebe, from South Africa, and Sorious Samura, a Sierra Leonean film maker. They work for a London based independent production firm, Insight News Television. All four appeared in court again yesterday at a bail hearing in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, but the judge refused bail, saying the suspected crime was too grave. The men went back to prison.

Representatives from Channel 4 said yesterday they were briefing a lawyer in London who would go to Monrovia later this week to support a locally retained solicitor. If convicted, the four men, who arrived in the country on August 1, could face up to 10 years in prison.

The Liberian president has called for a speedy trial open to the international media, but said it would be wrong for him to interfere in the judicial process. Referring to the film crew late on Monday, Mr Taylor said nothing would happen that would violate their rights under the laws of Liberia.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
There's a couple of old favourites making an appearance in the column this week. First off, professional widow, rock star and sometime actress Courtney Love is being sued by a film production company for breach of contract, fraud, defamation and infliction of emotional distress. Background Productions has filed suit against Love and the producers of Beat, which stars Kiefer Sutherland as heavily narcoticised author William Burroughs, and Love as his second wife Joan Vollmer, who he accidentally killed. Alexandra Cardenas, a Production Supervisor, alleges that Love called her a "puta" (a whore) in front of the whole cast and crew, and Antonio Zavalas, the CEO of Background, says that she called him and his employees "corrupt Mexicans"...

And, after a (very) short break from the law courts, Eminem 's back. This time though, he's bringing the case, as his on-again, off-again relationship with wife Kimberley comes to a pretty decisive off. Mr Marshall Mathers filed for divorce last week from the woman he's been with since high school - to call them sweethearts might be pushing it, as he's written several songs about murdering her and has Kim Rot In Pieces tattooed on his chest. Their turbulent relationship has included him pulling a gun on a man he thought she was involved with, and a suicide attempt...

More bad boy rappers - this time in the form of the Wu Tang Clan 's Ghostface Killah and U-God. Journalist Edward Cash Wallace has called in the police, claiming that he went backstage at a San Francisco concert under the impression that he was to conduct an interview, but instead was beaten by a Wu Tang bodyguard and then by the rappers themselves. Show promoter Boots Houghston admits that Wallace was punched by the bodyguard, but claims it was because no interview had been agreed and he was harassing the band. Rappers and journalists - not a good combination.

webTitle: Pig export ban can be eased, say EU vets

fields.headline: Pig export ban can be eased, say EU vets
fields.trailText: An EU ban on the export of live pigs and pig semen from England will be eased this week, days after it was imposed, providing a welcome boost for the hard-pressed pork and bacon industry.
fields.body:
An EU ban on the export of live pigs and pig semen from England will be eased this week, days after it was imposed, providing a welcome boost for the hard-pressed pork and bacon industry.

European vets yesterday unanimously agreed that the restrictions should only apply to animals from Norfolk, Suffolk and Essex, where 12,000 pigs on five farms have been slaughtered following an outbreak of classical swine fever.

The lifting of the ban on pigs from most of England must be agreed by commissioners on Friday but the government was relieved at the speed at with which the trade boycott, imposed on Monday last week, was being eased.

The decision by the vets amounted to a vote of confidence in measures to contain the disease, even though about 100 other farms are still under movement controls because of their proximity to the infected farms.

Seven other farms around the country have been cleared of swine fever although tests are still being completed on others that have reported sick pigs.

None of the pigs on these farms has yet been found to be suffering from the disease. The EU vets may consider easing the ban further early next month.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said the EU response was "proportionate to the current risks". It demonstrated that his department "was right to take the precautionary approach which was essential to stop the disease in its tracks and confirm the benefits of the contructive approach we have adopted towards our partners in the European Union."

Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary officer, said officials were trying to reduce the size of the surveillance zones.

"We have been tracing the movements of pigs, people and vehicles from the infected farms and we have been visit ing the destinations and looking at the pigs there and testing blood samples. We have got results coming in all the time and if they are all negative, then we will have contained it in East Anglia."

John Godfrey, chairman of the National Pig Association, was delighted by the decision and said that British vets had done a "tremendous job" in fighting the outbreak.

"But we have much work still to do to alleviate the pressures on those farms in the 10 km surveillance zones," he said.

Association leaders will meet Mr Brown today to discuss compensation and further help.

The Pig Veterinary Society said thousands of pigs on farms surrounding the infected ones should be slaughtered and compensation paid to their owners to stop massive overcrowding problems caused by the movement restrictions.

"The implication for the welfare of these animals is horrifying. The financial implications for these innocent farmers are equally distressing, particularly coming on the back of two years of huge financial loss. The potential is there for large areas of East Anglian farming to disappear."

Tim Yeo, the Conservative agriculture spokesman, and Colin Breed, for the Liberal Democrats, echoed the call for swift action to prevent the build-up of live pigs.

Live pig exports are thought to be worth around £30m a year, a relatively small proportion of the £126m a year export trade but there had been fears in some quarters that a wider ban on exporting pork and bacon might be considered.

webTitle: Mark Morris on OJ's film battle

fields.headline: The big fight
fields.standfirst: When OJ Simpson was acquitted of murder, it was the end of his war with the criminal justice system - and the start of his battle with the scriptwriters. Now he's trying to stop a biopic reaching our screens.  Mark Morris  reports
fields.trailText: When OJ Simpson was acquitted of murder, it was the end of his war with the criminal justice system - and the start of his battle with the scriptwriters. Now he's trying to stop a biopic reaching our screens.
fields.body:
It has been a long time since Orenthal James Simpson was a hero. Even before the infamous freeway chase and that trial, the memories of those glorious snaking runs for the Buffalo Bills were fading and being replaced by images of a mediocre film career. And while it is true that during the trial, a large proportion of black America rallied round, it wasn't because anyone really admired OJ. They were working on the understandable assumption that a black man arrested by the LAPD was likely to be innocent.

Now OJ is making a bid to be extremely popular with a select, but fast growing group. Specifically, people whose lives have been appropriated for TV or the movies, and are mad as hell about it. People such as Rubin Carter's lawyers, who felt that The Hurricane made them look lazy, ineffectual and incompetent. Or America's answer to the late Sir Robin Day, Mike Wallace, disgruntled because The Insider made him look like a man of less than unbending integrity.

Likewise, minor characters in Erin Brockovich and The Perfect Storm and pretty much every based-on-a-true-story TV movie you ever saw on Channel 5. All these people have made a fuss about the supposed distortion of their lives, but only after the product has reached the public. And by then, surely, it is too late. Occasionally, they can cause enough doubts to scupper an Oscar nomination, but that is just bitter compensation. OJ Simpson, though, is doing something altogether bolder: he's trying to snuff out a mini-series about his trial before it gets made.

It seems a strange time to be making a programme based on the Simpson farrago: it's yesterday's scandal but not quite history yet. Nor is the mini-series promising us the shocking truth about what really happened. But the portentously titled American Tragedy is a surprisingly heavyweight affair, with a script by Norman Mailer, and the Homicide/Oz pairing of Tom Fontana and Barry Levinson as executive-producers. Ving Rhames has been signed up to play showboating attorney Johnny Cochrane. All in all, it looks as upmarket as mainstream US TV gets.

But OJ doesn't want to be reminded of the trial. He seems to have been keeping a relatively low profile recently, since those misguided attempts to relaunch himself on the chat-show circuit. And his lawyers think that they have found a way to stop the mini-series reviving his trauma. They have filed a complaint with the Los Angeles Superior Court, claiming that the programme will be using privileged information provided by a member of the Simpson defence team, Robert Kardashian - a breach of confidentiality. There is, however, a big flaw with this. The mini-series is based on writer/director Lawrence Schiller's book American Tragedy: The Uncensored Story Of The Simpson Defence. And the book - which contains all the information supplied by Kardashian - was published in 1997. If Simpson was going to sue, he should have done it back then. He claims that he was too busy with the civil suit - which he lost - brought by the victims' families accusing him of being responsible for the deaths of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman.

But "too busy" isn't a generally accepted legal excuse. With Kardashian's leaks in the public domain for three years, it is unlikely that a court will do anything now. Not unless they buy into the subtext to the suit: that it is fine for information to appear in print because most people don't read, but put in a high-profile TV show and it can be really damaging.

So can you stop a TV or film company hijacking your life? In Europe, you might have a chance. In the US, probably not. In 1998 a California Supreme Court ruling (Polydoros v Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp) established that the right to privacy cannot be used by an individual to stop their name, history and personality from being used in a work of fiction. For the famous - like OJ - there is another law, the right of publicity, which might help.

It holds that you can't make money from a celebrity's image without their permission. But while its application for ads and T-shirts is clear, no one is quite sure if it covers TV or film. In general, programme and film-makers avoid trouble by either asking permission or cobbling together composite characters. But for some reason, nobody seemed that worried about offending Mr Simpson.

The same week that OJ was launching his case, another American male associated with a controversial death was having a little more luck with the TV networks. Aides for Senator Edward Kennedy gently suggested to the NBC network that running their Kennedy wives mini-series Jackie, Ethel, Joan: The Women Of Camelot two days before the November election, might be an interference with the democratic process. NBC considered the request, and decided that indeed it might be better not to remind Massachusetts voters about Chappaquiddick on the way to the polls. They have postponed the series to a less topical (and less troublesome) time in February. OJ, no doubt, will be reflecting on how, despite four decades of fruitful muckraking, nothing beats the Kennedy name.

But while its application for ads and T-shirts is clear, no one is quite sure if it covers TV or film. In general, programme and film-makers avoid trouble by either asking permission or cobbling together composite characters. But for some reason, nobody seemed that worried about offending Mr Simpson. The same week that OJ was launching his case, another American male associated with a controversial death was having a little more luck with the TV networks. Aides for Senator Edward Kennedy gently suggested to the NBC network that running their Kennedy wives mini-series Jackie, Ethel, Joan: The Women Of Camelot two days before the November election, might be an interference with the democratic process. NBC considered the request, and decided that indeed it might be better not to remind Massachusetts voters about Chappaquiddick on the way to the polls. They have postponed the series to a less topical (and less troublesome) time in February. OJ, no doubt, will be reflecting on how, despite four decades of fruitful muckraking, nothing beats the Kennedy name.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Twin Cities/The Ocean Planet
fields.body:
Jonathan Glancey's series on Twin Cities (11.0am, Radio 4) this week turns its attention to those old Lancashire rivals Manchester and Liverpool. In spite of the heady days in the 1960s, when it soared to international attention, Liverpool has never really got over the loss of its shipping business. Manchester, by contrast, seems to have gained its second wind. Its bid for the Olympics may have failed, but the very effort seems to have given its people a rush of adrenalin.

According to Professor Jacquie McGlade, there's an increasing scientific belief that life on earth emerged from smoking chimneys, which makes humans sound rather like first cousins to a kipper. However, what she is really talking about in her imposing new series on The Ocean Planet (9.0pm, Radio 4) are the mysterious geysers found six miles beneath the sea. They, rather than primordial slime, may have acted as the original source of terrestrial life.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Libya to pay $1m per hostage
fields.body:
Libya to pay $1m per hostage

Libya has agreed to pay $1m ransom for each of the 12 foreign hostages still held by Muslim rebels in the southern Philippines, sources said yesterday.

The hostages were to have been freed at the weekend but the fundamentalist Abu Sayyaf guerrillas stalled after Libya haggled to lower the ransom per captive, they said. Manila and governments of the foreign hostages have maintained they opposed paying ransom.

Reuters, Manila

Chechen rebel leader arrested

The Russian federal security service said yesterday it had arrested Lechi Islamov, the Chechen rebel who led the defence of Grozny until it was abandoned to Russian forces in February. He is accused of murder, kidnapping and extortion.

Russia says it is focusing on capturing leaders rather than skirmishing with rebel troops. But a Chechen official said yesterday that Russian troops were ambushed by rebels overnight, and there were casualties on both sides.

AP, Nazran

Spanish boy,14, forged money

A 14-year-old Spanish boy was released into his parents' custody yesterday after being charged with falsifying hundreds of thousands of banknotes, a police spokesman said

The boy was arrested after police found 475,000 pesetas (£1,731) in fake notes and counterfeiting equipment in his room at home near Barcelona.

AP, Barcelona

Sudan civilian targets bombed

A Sudanese army plane dropped 15 bombs near a relief agency compound and other civilian targets yesterday in the south-eastern town of Ikotos.

No casualties were reported in the attack on territory controlled by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. The Sudanese government has accused relief organisations of providing military assistance to the SPLA.

AP, Nairobi

Italians held over Pokemon

Italian police have seized 335,000 counterfeit Pokemon items, with a street value of about £2.7m. Twenty-four Italians were charged, most of them accused of falsification.

Reuters, Milan

fields.headline: Batting for our boys
fields.trailText: It's reassuring to know the outcome of the last Test match has become a grand debate on the state of the pitches (The danger of quick cricket, Sport, August 21).
fields.body:
It's reassuring to know the outcome of the last Test match has become a grand debate on the state of the pitches (The danger of quick cricket, Sport, August 21).

Perhaps if the West Indies had stormed to such a one-sided victory, we would all feel a little better and put it down to superior tactics and skill.
Paul Meredith
Hove, E Sussex

The most gratifying aspect of England's two-day win was that I was able to enjoy my friends' wedding in Wiltshire on Saturday, without having to worry about slipping off to check up on the score. A great win, a better wedding.
Kester Lovelace
Paris

How many other prime ministers and their families have to undergo the stupidity of media interest in their family holidays (Hapy families, August 21)? Is this intrusion endemic only to the British press and, if so, why?
Cllr Gwyneth Cooper
Chester

All seven people in your article (It's summer, but do top academics know how to relax? Education, August 22) are male. Gender bias or lack of female academics able to take a couple of weeks off?
Dr Jennifer Jenkins
King's College, London

Your article on Dr Seuss and Hollywood did not mention The 5,000 fingers of Dr T, the only film written by Ted Geisel (Doctor's Orders, G2 August 22). It is an odd and fascinating movie, if not entirely successful. It is also unmistakably Seuss-ian in its every frame. The film even received an Oscar nomination (though not for the screenplay).
Jay Russell
London

So Daniel Radcliffe is to be the big screen Harry Potter (Report, August 22). And there I was thinking Donald Dewar was the odds-on favourite.
Toby Wood
Peterborough

fields.headline: Jerusalem solution
fields.trailText: Some clever people like your Michael Adams (Visions of a new Jerusalem, August 22) and my brother Hugh saw the Jerusalem crisis coming and proposed the only possible remedy - a clearly ambitious international one.
fields.body:
Some clever people like your Michael Adams (Visions of a new Jerusalem, August 22) and my brother Hugh saw the Jerusalem crisis coming and proposed the only possible remedy - a clearly ambitious international one.

Maybe now, we need something even more ambitious. Why not transfer the whole UN organisation from jittery New York to the golden city - especially if, as seems possible, the next incumbent in Washington has difficulty in persuading his senators to provide the cash for the UN and wants to waste untold fortunes in the meantime on the Star Wars catastrophe.
Michael Foot
London

 Michael Adams is certainly correct in arguing that compromise is needed on the question of Jerusalem if real peace is to be achieved between Israel and the Palestinians. For such compromise to be achieved, there must be genuine understanding on both sides of the meaning of the city for the other.

Yet when commentators continue to dismiss the deeply held Israeli bond to the city as "no more than a slogan", we are left with barren debate. Neither is understanding facilitated by selective quotations from UN resolutions.

The legal status of the city has remained in dispute throughout the past century, while no country or people since Ottoman times has ever enjoyed internationally recognised sovereignty over its eastern side.

At Camp David, Israel made clear its willingness to address ideas designed to promote a compromise acceptable to both peoples and consistent with the interests of believers of all three monotheistic faiths. Unfortunately the Palestinian delegation refused steadfastly to discuss the issue at all. The willingness to seek workable solutions must be mutual if genuine peace is to be achieved.
DJ Schneeweiss
Israeli embassy

fields.headline: Lessons of girls' success
fields.trailText: Can Yvonne Roberts (Blaming the girls, August 22) explain how "emotional literacy" (the replacement buzz word for the insistence on male "vulnerability", perhaps?) going to raise levels of boys' educational achievement?
fields.body:
Can Yvonne Roberts (Blaming the girls, August 22) explain how "emotional literacy" (the replacement buzz word for the insistence on male "vulnerability", perhaps?) going to raise levels of boys' educational achievement?

We've had over a decade of trying to "redefine masculinity so that it means more than the wage a man earns and a stoic refusal to show emotion", but no one has a clue what that redefinition might entail, or where the possible examples might be found - and the boy still needs the qualifications in order to earn "a man's wage". We know what we don't want from boys - violence, predatory sexuality, reading "lad mags" - but not what we do, especially as any "failures" can't be dumped in factories or the armed forces any longer.
D Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent

Why the fuss about girls doing better in exams? They are ahead of boys in growth and development from the age of two. The boys who do well are like child prodigies. The reason girls apparently had less good results in the past was because many were not encouraged by their families to continue their studies past school leaving age. Perhaps the answer is to have a more flexible approach to the ages for starting and finishing formal education.
Ann Kirpalani
Luton, Beds

Of course the problem of underachievement amongst boys has to be addressed, but not in ways which will lead once more to discrimination against girls (Single sex lesson plan, August 21).

Resources will always be limited and if boys and girls are taught in separate classes we can all guess which of the classes will get the qualified physics, maths, biology or English teacher. The causes of under-achievement in boys are likely to be found in early family life and early years in school. Messing about with single sex education in later years is tackling the symptoms and not the causes. Pre-school education is vital. We now have to attract the most able men into the teaching of young children, to provide appropriate role models.
Ann and Neil Holmes
Bromsgrove, Worcs
mnholmes@newscientist.net

Gender is not the most important factor affecting school performance. In fact, it probably isn't even in the top five. The differences between girls and boys are small compared to the differences between localities, types of school and social classes. A boy at a leafy private school is still likely to do far better than a girl at an inner-city comprehensive. But this doesn't fit the media obsession with gender politics.
Pete Maldeshap
Wolverhampton

The gender gap at 0.6% is so close it is just not relevant. Look at why boys do better than girls in later life, nothing sexist in this, just plain truth. The gap is caused by boys playing football, golf, cricket, rugby, going to the pub and not spending all their lives in study. They emerge into life as team players - competitive, aggressive leaders - and very broad in their interests. Much business is done in the hospitality boxes at Lords or Highbury or over dinner and a bottle of wine or on the golf course. It is far better for boys to have this supplement to their education than trying to get all grade A A-levels, far better for his long-term future that a lad leaves school with moderate A levels, and a single figure golf handicap.

Forty thousand boys took maths, compared with 20,000 girls, you won't get far in business life if you can not read a balance sheet.
CN Rackley
Burgess Hill, Sussex

Doesn't section 28 prevent single-sex lessons?
Andy Lisle
Bidford on Avon, Warks

webTitle: Letters: Soccer transfers: a debate of two halves

fields.headline: Soccer transfers: a debate of two halves
fields.trailText: It's ironic that football bosses are moaning about the possible abolition of the transfer system (Race to head off transfer doomsday, Sport, August 22). They enthusiastically embraced the corporate ethos and turned a sport into an industry. Now they contemplate one of the consequences. Others will follow.
fields.body:
It's ironic that football bosses are moaning about the possible abolition of the transfer system (Race to head off transfer doomsday, Sport, August 22). They enthusiastically embraced the corporate ethos and turned a sport into an industry. Now they contemplate one of the consequences. Others will follow.

The transfer fee is an anachronism that does not exist in any other Europe-wide business. Workers, many of whom are also highly paid specialists, sign a fixed-term contract, which they and their employer fulfil. Legal remedy for breach of contract is open to either party. When the contract is completed the employer can replace the employee who is allowed to move on freely.

No EU industry makes its own rules. The right to make huge profits is balanced with the responsibility to adhere to legally enforceable guidelines. Why should football be different?
Tim Webb
London

The stance of the European Union in meddling in foot ball will, if implemented, destroy the game - though it seems that in the view of the EU and its supporters, the ruining of livelihoods, industries and enterprise is a price worth paying to reach the goal of a socialist European state. The EU simply does not have a right to meddle in this. If the greatest barrier to the free movement of workers in the EU is language, why is the EU not encouraging a single common language, English?
Dr David Viner
Stibbard, Norfolk
d.viner@uea.ac.uk

webTitle: Letters: Russia can't look west for a scapegoat

fields.headline: Russia can't look west for a scapegoat
fields.trailText: I can't imagine why John Gray (Russia's fall, August 22) thinks the west should shoulder the blame for the state of Russia. Western advisers may have recommended privatisation and freeing up prices.
fields.body:
I can't imagine why John Gray (Russia's fall, August 22) thinks the west should shoulder the blame for the state of Russia. Western advisers may have recommended privatisation and freeing up prices.

They also suggested eliminating corruption and the introduction of property rights and tax laws. Russia chose the parts that would create the oligarchs and impoverish the majority, while ignoring what might help the development of a market economy and a democratic society.

I spent several years trying to help Russian managers run their businesses. Pointing out their problems - inefficiently producing low-quality goods that no one wants - got a few polite nods, followed by a list of reasons why the suggested changes wouldn't work for them. From the company to the macro level, the Russian response has been the same. Gray's comments about policies "utterly unsuited to history and circumstance" just echoes the Russian authorities' own excuses. Russia will change when those in power drop their bone-headed obstinacy and accept the responsibility for the terrible state of the country.
Glenn Richer
Cambridge

In their eagerness to ascribe the indifference of the new leadership to Soviet legacies, the Soviet press forgot to mention a significant difference. There was no heroic response to the Kursk disaster of the calibre of the Soviet helicopter pilots who in 1986 flew repeated missions over the stricken Chernobyl reactor to shroud it in concrete, sacrificing their health - and in many cases their lives -to minimise the fallout. We will now no doubt see the advent of western-style buck-passing, in which no responsibility is taken by those in real command.
Terry Monaghan
London

As the tragedy has unfolded, has anyone heard the distant thumping of script proposals landing on Hollywood desks? They'll change the ending, naturally.
Eira Reed
Shalford, Essex

I have watched with great sadness the battle to save the men on board the Kursk. Is there any fund to help the families of the sailors?
Roseanne Kelly
Horsham, West Sussex

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A maths error reproduced by us when writing about the results of a medical survey (yesterday, page 8) had the Guardian saying that missed appointments by patients at GP surgeries were costing the NHS £18m a year. The right figure is £187m.
fields.body:
A maths error reproduced by us when writing about the results of a medical survey (yesterday, page 8) had the Guardian saying that missed appointments by patients at GP surgeries were costing the NHS £18m a year. The right figure is £187m.

The Roman emperor Claudius could not have patronised the Colosseum (Passnotes yesterday, G2, page 3), as he died in 54AD, roughly two decades before it was built under the emperor Titus Flavius Vespasianus, rendered Vespasian in English.

The Byron quotation given ("When falls the Coliseum, Rome shall fall; And when Rome falls - the world") should have been assigned to Childe Harold's Pilgrimage.

Contrary to a panel listing "cyberpirates", page 3, August 21, the US hacker Kevin Mitnick has never been on the FBI's most wanted list or on a most wanted poster. Neither was his 1999 fraud sentence five years. It was 46 months.

A column yesterday, page 15, renamed the former Conservative defence and foreign secretary Malcolm Rifkind as Michael.

Analysis, page 19, August 21, looked at non-mainstream candidates in US presidential elections. A chart named the leading independent hopeful in 1980 as John Andrews. He was John Anderson.

The name of a psychology lecturer at Cranfield School of Management was misspelled, page 26, Jobs and Money, August 19. He is Richard Kwiatkowski.

The actress Maureen O'Hara turned 80 on August 17. Our Birthdays list that day, page 22, put it at 79.

Portsmouth College should have been in 34th place in the Guardian survey of col lege A-level results, page 6, August 18. It had an average points score of 17.21.

The rankings were in proper order in a table of Rugby Union Zurich Premiership teams (Sport, page 11, August 21), but many of the points were wrong, for which apologies.

A heading on the cover and text on page 7 of Office hours, August 21, referred to Chelsea's famed "registry office". It is a register office.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. The Roman emperor Claudius could not have patronised the Colosseum (Passnotes yesterday, G2, page 3), as he died in 54AD, roughly two decades before it was built under the emperor Titus Flavius Vespasianus, rendered Vespasian in English. The Byron quotation given ("When falls the Coliseum, Rome shall fall; And when Rome falls - the world") should have been assigned to Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. Contrary to a panel listing "cyberpirates", page 3, August 21, the US hacker Kevin Mitnick has never been on the FBI's most wanted list or on a most wanted poster. Neither was his 1999 fraud sentence five years. It was 46 months. A column yesterday, page 15, renamed the former Conservative defence and foreign secretary Malcolm Rifkind as Michael. Analysis, page 19, August 21, looked at non-mainstream candidates in US presidential elections. A chart named the leading independent hopeful in 1980 as John Andrews. He was John Anderson. The name of a psychology lecturer at Cranfield School of Management was misspelled, page 26, Jobs and Money, August 19. He is Richard Kwiatkowski. The actress Maureen O'Hara turned 80 on August 17. Our Birthdays list that day, page 22, put it at 79. Portsmouth College should have been in 34th place in the Guardian survey of col lege A-level results, page 6, August 18. It had an average points score of 17.21. The rankings were in proper order in a table of Rugby Union Zurich Premiership teams (Sport, page 11, August 21), but many of the points were wrong, for which apologies. A heading on the cover and text on page 7 of Office hours, August 21, referred to Chelsea's famed "registry office". It is a register office. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.
