fields.headline: Lewis Waddilove
fields.standfirst: Social policy pioneer whose energy and vision fuelled the growth of housing associations
fields.trailText: Lewis Waddilove, who has died aged 85, was a Quaker committed to social change, whose work was at the heart of postwar social housing policies. His integrity and sincerity gave him the authority to confront politicians of all parties, often with unpopular proposals. His campaigning was based on absolute honesty and meticulous attention to detail.
fields.body:
Lewis Waddilove, who has died aged 85, was a Quaker committed to social change, whose work was at the heart of postwar social housing policies. His integrity and sincerity gave him the authority to confront politicians of all parties, often with unpopular proposals. His campaigning was based on absolute honesty and meticulous attention to detail.

Waddilove was the first director, from 1961-79, of what is now the Joseph Rowntree Foundation (previously the Joseph Rowntree Memorial Trust), and managed its affairs from 1946-79. He had been born into a strong Quaker tradition, was educated at Westcliff high school, Southend, and, although he received a number of honorary degrees, he never took one himself. During the war, he served with the Friends Ambulance Service in the Middle East.

When Waddilove first arrived in York, the Rowntree organisation was the Village Trust, concentrating on the model garden village of New Earswick, York, begun by Joseph Rowntree at the turn of the 20th century. Waddilove steered the trust into wider realms, with a private act of parliament that created the Joseph Rowntree Memorial Trust, covering all aspects of social research and experiment.

Today, the Joseph Rowntree Foundation is the largest independent supporter and initiator of social research, spending more than £9m a year, and its housing trust provides 2,000 homes and a range of specialist accommodation, residential and nursing care, and community activities and facilities, in and around York.

Just one part of Waddilove's role in expanding the value and influence of the foundation was in establishing the family fund in 1973, at the request of Sir Keith Joseph, then secretary of state for health and social services, to distribute grants to families with severely disabled children. Today, the Family Fund Trust pays out nearly £25m a year. The housing origins of the trust led Waddilove to become a founder trustee of both the British Churches Housing Trust (promoting church-based housing associations) in 1964, and then of Shelter in 1966, where he was later to take the chair.

I got to know Lewis Waddilove when I started work at the British Churches Housing Trust in 1968, and it was he who appointed me in 1973 to be director of the National Federation of Housing Associations (today, the National Housing Federation), which he chaired for most of the period 1965-79. At the same time, he served on the board of the Housing Corporation, during the influential years before and after the Housing Act 1974; he was deputy chairman of the corporation from 1978 to 1983.

To those of us involved with Shelter, and the newly-formed housing associations of the late 1960s and 1970s, Lewis was more than an elder statesman. He was a mentor and a model. Not for him the placard-waving and the protest marches; he favoured the assembling of evidence, the marshalling of rational argument, the combination of courtesy and persistence in handling the politicians of the day.

The fact that housing associations have come to dominate the social housing scene owes an enormous amount to the guiding hand of Lewis Waddilove. His approach was always subtly different from the mainstream. Steeped in the tradition of Joseph Rowntree, he never looked at issues from the top down. Despite his intellectual prowess and establishment appearance - he was always immaculately turned out - he had no sense of superiority; he was determined that the places built by the Joseph Rowntree Housing Trust should not bear the stamp of charity, rather being, as Rowntree said, "self governing communities".

Waddilove championed the idea of housing co-operatives and was critical of local authority housing, where he felt tenants were powerless. To the end, he remained a tenant himself in one of the housing trust's properties in New Earswick.

He was also involved in a range of other social policy issues, including commonwealth immigration, reform of the social services, legal aid, rent rebates and allowances, the future of the voluntary sector and much more. He chaired the personal social services council, the BBC/IBA central appeals advisory committee, and the coal-mining subsidence compensation review committee.

Incredibly, he also had time for civic duties in York, as a JP, a deeply respected chairman of the York University council, chairman of the Quaker schools (Bootham and The Mount) and as chairman of the York city charities. Always his quiet, sincere style supported the clarity of vision and wise analysis he brought to each subject.

The standards Lewis set remain a template: sustain your underlying vision of social change, while handling with precision the everyday tasks of administration; be persistent but always courteous; maintain total integrity, however sophisticated the negotiations; listen carefully and see all sides to the argument before drawing conclusions; deal with people of all kinds with an equal degree of respect. Following even partially in his footsteps is no easy task.

He is survived by his second wife, Maureen Piper, and by the son and daughter of his first marriage, to Louise Power, who died in 1967.

 Lewis Edgar Waddilove, social policy campaigner, born September 5 1914; died August 21 2000

fields.headline: Sir Campbell Adamson
fields.standfirst: Liberal capitalist who raised the profile of the CBI and pioneered a banking revolution at the Abbey National
fields.trailText: There have been very few leaders of British industry who could claim, with some irony, that they both pioneered a revolution in the banking system and helped to bring down a Conservative government. But that was the remarkable achievement of Sir Campbell Adamson, who has died aged 78.
fields.body:
There have been very few leaders of British industry who could claim, with some irony, that they both pioneered a revolution in the banking system and helped to bring down a Conservative government. But that was the remarkable achievement of Sir Campbell Adamson, who has died aged 78.

As director-general of the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), he was accused of helping to undermine the Heath government during the general election of February 1974. While he rejected the charge out of hand, the story remains full of fascination.

Adamson was appointed to his high-profile job in 1969, at a peak of industrial tension between government, employers and trade unions; a year later, Edward Heath's Conservative party swept to power on a platform of reform. The Industrial Relations Act was introduced at the end of 1970 and, at once, ran into huge problems, from which the government was forced to retreat in the face of trade union power. By mid-1972, compromise was in the air, and, throughout 1973, Heath, the CBI and the TUC sought to establish a working relationship.

The breakdown of this attempt - caused by the Middle East crisis, oil prices quadrupling overnight and a miners' strike - precipitated the February 1974 election.

Two days before polling day, Adamson, in a private speech to the Industrial Society, criticised the rigidity of the government's industrial relations policy. The press had not been invited, but somehow his words slipped out. They caused a political sensation and, after Heath lost the election, he blamed Adamson for contributing to the government's narrow defeat.

It was an absurd exaggeration because Adamson had said nothing that was not common knowledge through- out industry - nor, for that matter, inside the Heath government. Even so, Adamson felt duty bound to fall on his sword; he twice tendered his resignation, which was twice rejected. He then took all the flak with great stoicism, nor was there any trace of whinge. Yet the shadow of that occasion always remained at the back of his mind.

His other prime slot in history must be his remarkable achievement in pioneering the change in status of the Abbey National Building Society from a mutual to a public company - the first major building society to move in that direction. It was the opening shot in a revolution that transformed Britain's financial services and, to achieve it, Adamson had to overcome tradition, prejudice and fierce opposition from Abbey members. In the end, however, his scheme triumphed by a vote of 9 to 1.

Adamson was born in Perth, the only son of a distinguished Scottish accountant, who disliked even the idea of living south of the border - "true Scots", as Adamson would describe his family culture, with a touch of characteristic humour. Nonetheless, an attractive job offer persuaded the father to move to England, and send his son to Rugby. Young Adamson went on to Corpus Christi, Cambridge, where he read economics under John Maynard Keynes - an influence which never left him.

A hereditary night-blindness kept Adamson out of the war, although he tried everything to get into the armed services. After a brief war-time stint with the Royal Institute of International Affairs, he went into the steel industry. He started in 1945 as a management trainee with Baldwins, in south Wales, and went on to work with the merged Richard Thomas & Baldwin plants, ending up - at the age of 36 - in charge of the construction and operations division of RTB's huge Spencer works at Llanwern.

All of that was re-shaped into the Steel Company of Wales (Scow) prior to nationalisation in 1947, at which point Adamson took charge of labour relations. It was his achievements in steel - in particular, the humanity of his management - that drew him to the attention of Harold Wilson's second Labour government, and, in 1967, he was invited to join the still-developing Department of Economic Affairs (DEA), George Brown's ill-fated invention designed to challenge Treasury economic dominance of Whitehall.

Adamson was appointed as a senior industrial adviser, in charge of co-ordinating all the other industrial advisers. He was given the temporary status of a deputy under- secretary of state, although, by the time he arrived at the DEA, Brown had moved on and Michael Stewart was in charge of a department that was plainly heading nowhere in particular.

After two years, Adamson was glad to leave. Technically, he was still attached to Scow, but, by then, the steel industry had been re-nationalised, and the first chairman of British Steel, Lord Melchett, wanted to appoint him to a senior managerial post.

That is when fate and chance intervened. Adamson wanted a holiday between leaving Whitehall and taking up a new job. With his first wife, Gilvray, whom he met at Cambridge and married in 1945, he planned a safari drive across the Sahara - a long cherished ambition. As they were about to depart, John Davies, then director-general of the CBI, rang to suggest that Adamson might be interested in the CBI job, which he was leaving. The Adamsons left for their holiday, leaving post restante addresses in Algiers and Cairo - which is how he first learned he had been appointed director- general of the CBI.

A damson's seven years with the organisation were among the most turbulent years for British industry, and the economy, since the war. He always claimed that his biggest achievement was persuading the CBI, in 1971 to 1972, to hold back price rises, without which Heath's pay and prices policy would never have taken off. He was certainly the main architect of that policy, and it helped to halve the inflation rate.

Yet, in retrospect, Adamson's most significant legacy was in carrying the CBI in support of Heath's pro-European policies. He was one of the first British industrialists to be convinced of the need to link with Europe, and his leadership was crucial in influencing Britain's largest companies. Interviewed shortly after his departure in 1976, he said he would like to be remembered as "somebody who helped to put the CBI firmly on the map". Few could now argue against the view that he achieved precisely that.

He also saw nothing to scorn in bringing all sides together to help resolve major social and economic problems. "A civilised society must have co-operation between government and both sides of industry," he argued.

A string of appointments in industry, banking and financial institutions followed his departure from the CBI. Then, in 1978, he surprised everyone by taking up the chairmanship of Abbey National - at the age of 56. These years were among the most rewarding of his career, and he played a major role in transforming Britain's financial services and the culture of building societies.

Adamson's personal life also went through a period of dramatic change. He separated from Gilvray, a sociologist and social worker, and, in 1984, married a gregarious American, Mimi Lloyd-Chancellor. They were to spend many happy years sharing a remodelled terraced house in Battersea and a country home in Oxfordshire.

Adamson was a liberal capitalist with a profound social awareness. He might easily have become a socialist at Cambridge, but rejected what was then politically fashionable. Years later, he claimed - only half jokingly - that it was hearing Herbert Morrison speak about the virtues of the Labour party that put him off. Yet it did not deter him from pursuing a wide range of social activities; one of his most notable contributions was to found, and chair, the Family Policy Studies Centre in 1984, where he appointed Malcolm Wicks, now a Labour MP, as its first director.

So many of Adamson's qualities can be gleaned from his Who's Who listing; brass rubbing, music, walking, arguing (in later years, he omitted brass rubbing). No one who walked with him was ever in any doubt about his unusual mix of qualities - immense sensitivity, a strong, ethically-based vision, and mischievous humour coupled with self-deprecation.

He is survived by Mimi, and two sons and two daughter from his first marriage.

 William Owen Campbell Adamson, industrialist, born June 26 1922; died August 21 2000

webTitle: German prosecutor steps up war on racist crimes

fields.headline: German prosecutor steps up war on racist crimes
fields.trailText: German authorities yesterday sent out a powerful signal of their determination to crack down on the far right when it emerged that the federal chief prosecutor had taken personal charge of the latest trial for race murder.
fields.body:
German authorities yesterday sent out a powerful signal of their determination to crack down on the far right when it emerged that the federal chief prosecutor had taken personal charge of the latest trial for race murder.

Kay Nehm, whose intervention is usually reserved for cases of suspected terrorism, had earlier said neo-Nazi violence posed a threat to security because of the climate of fear and intimidation it created.

Three young men from Dessau in eastern Germany went on trial in the city of Halle yesterday, accused of a killing that has provided an impetus for mounting concern over the far right. Mozambique-born Alberto Adriano died on June 14 after being kicked and beaten as he made his way home in the early hours.

His German widow, Angelika, faced the three skinheads yesterday as a prosecutor from Mr Nehm's department opened the case for the state. The victim was the father of three children, aged eight, three, and six months.

"The defendants assumed that Adriano could die as a result of their attack", Joachim Lampe told the court. "But their hatred of foreigners made them indifferent to this".

The chief prosecutor's decision was the latest initiative aimed at curbing neo-Nazism, which is rife in the east. It was announced as the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, began a tour to gain insight into the area's problems.

Speaking in Bad Elster on Monday, Mr Schröder called on people to stand up to the neo-Nazis to prevent them undoing east Germany's achievements since reunification.

In recent weeks, the government has pressed for a ban on the most extreme of the legal right-wing parties, pledged more than £20 million to an anti-racist drive in schools and announced an advertising campaign to encourage tolerance.

Manfred Pöchel, the interior minister of the regional government in Saxony-Anhalt, where Mr Adriano was murdered, called for the toughest possible sentence if the defendants were found guilty.

Mr Adriano's death was important in galvanising the authorities into action. According to the indictment, his attackers beat then kicked him with their military-style boots for five minutes. They continued kicking him and shouting "Get out of our country, you Negro pig", even after Mr Adriano had stopped moving.

Enrico Hilprecht, aged 24, sat impassively as the court was told how he had kicked Adriano 10 times in the head. He faces up to 15 years in prison for the killing.

He and his co-defendants, Frank Miethbauer and Christian Richter, both 16, were said to have chanced on Mr Adriano as they stormed through Dessau shouting "Blacks out". The younger men are liable to receive a shorter sentence of up to 10 years.

After the indictment was read, the judge ordered proceedings to continue behind closed doors because of the law regarding juveniles. A lawyer for the victim's family said all three defendants had admitted in closed evidence that they had taken part in the attack.

The defence is expected to argue that they were too drunk at the time to be fully responsible. An expert witness is to be called to testify on their condition after they were arrested at the scene of the attack after residents called the police.

The link between far-right violence and state security was made earlier this year in a report from the security service that played a role in stirring anxiety. The BVD, Germany's equivalent of MI5, said it had detected terrorist-style organisation among neo-Nazis.

Underlying the authorities' disquiet, there are other factors - notably a concern that racism in the east could hinder Germany's integration into a globalised economy. Germany currently accepts some 200,000 newcomers each year.

Already this year, the government has offered 20,000 temporary work permits to computer specialists, many of whom it expects to come from the Indian sub-continent.

Chronology of violence

1990

A 28-year-old Angolan is murdered in the eastern town of Eberswalde, Brandenburg, in what is regarded as Germany's first post-unification race murder. The early 90s are marked by a string of attacks on hostels for immigrants and asylum-seekers.

1992

Race riots in Rostock. A hostel for Vietnamese is besieged for five days.

1993

Skinheads beat up a black member of the US luge team in the resort of Oberhof in the former East Germany.

1996

Two neo-Nazis jailed by a Potsdam court for a racist attack on three black Britons. Noel Martin of Birmingham is left paralysed from the neck down. Ten immigrants and asylum-seekers die in an inferno at their homes in the northern port of Lübeck in the worst racist attack in Germany since the war.

2000

April
Five skinhead youths given sentences of between four and six years in Stralsrund for jumping on the heads of two Vietnamese men in an attack which put one victim into a coma for 10 days. The sentences are greeted as a change in attitude towards racist violence.

June
Alberto Adriano from Mozambique murdered in Dessau.

July
Chancellor Gerhard Schröder announces that a crackdown on the far right is a priority of the second half of his government's term. Two days later, a bomb explodes outside a Düsseldorf railway station injuring 10 immigrants. One, a pregnant woman, loses her unborn baby in the attack.

August
Official committee set up to consider ban on the National Democratic party of Germany (NPD), which has a prominent skinhead element.

Mozambique-born Alberto Adriano died on June 14 after being kicked and beaten as he made his way home in the early hours. His German widow, Angelika, faced the three skinheads yesterday as a prosecutor from Mr Nehm's department opened the case for the state. The victim was the father of three children, aged eight, three, and six months. "The defendants assumed that Adriano could die as a result of their attack", Joachim Lampe told the court. "But their hatred of foreigners made them indifferent to this". The chief prosecutor's decision was the latest initiative aimed at curbing neo-Nazism, which is rife in the east. It was announced as the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, began a tour to gain insight into the area's problems. Speaking in Bad Elster on Monday, Mr Schröder called on people to stand up to the neo-Nazis to prevent them undoing east Germany's achievements since reunification. In recent weeks, the government has pressed for a ban on the most extreme of the legal right-wing parties, pledged more than £20 million to an anti-racist drive in schools and announced an advertising campaign to encourage tolerance. Manfred Pöchel, the interior minister of the regional government in Saxony-Anhalt, where Mr Adriano was murdered, called for the toughest possible sentence if the defendants were found guilty. Mr Adriano's death was important in galvanising the authorities into action. According to the indictment, his attackers beat then kicked him with their military-style boots for five minutes. They continued kicking him and shouting "Get out of our country, you Negro pig", even after Mr Adriano had stopped moving. Enrico Hilprecht, aged 24, sat impassively as the court was told how he had kicked Adriano 10 times in the head. He faces up to 15 years in prison for the killing. He and his co-defendants, Frank Miethbauer and Christian Richter, both 16, were said to have chanced on Mr Adriano as they stormed through Dessau shouting "Blacks out". The younger men are liable to receive a shorter sentence of up to 10 years. After the indictment was read, the judge ordered proceedings to continue behind closed doors because of the law regarding juveniles. A lawyer for the victim's family said all three defendants had admitted in closed evidence that they had taken part in the attack. The defence is expected to argue that they were too drunk at the time to be fully responsible. An expert witness is to be called to testify on their condition after they were arrested at the scene of the attack after residents called the police. The link between far-right violence and state security was made earlier this year in a report from the security service that played a role in stirring anxiety. The BVD, Germany's equivalent of MI5, said it had detected terrorist-style organisation among neo-Nazis. Underlying the authorities' disquiet, there are other factors - notably a concern that racism in the east could hinder Germany's integration into a globalised economy. Germany currently accepts some 200,000 newcomers each year. Already this year, the government has offered 20,000 temporary work permits to computer specialists, many of whom it expects to come from the Indian sub-continent. Chronology of violence 1990 A 28-year-old Angolan is murdered in the eastern town of Eberswalde, Brandenburg, in what is regarded as Germany's first post-unification race murder. The early 90s are marked by a string of attacks on hostels for immigrants and asylum-seekers. 1992 Race riots in Rostock. A hostel for Vietnamese is besieged for five days. 1993 Skinheads beat up a black member of the US luge team in the resort of Oberhof in the former East Germany. 1996 Two neo-Nazis jailed by a Potsdam court for a racist attack on three black Britons. Noel Martin of Birmingham is left paralysed from the neck down. Ten immigrants and asylum-seekers die in an inferno at their homes in the northern port of Lübeck in the worst racist attack in Germany since the war. 2000 April Five skinhead youths given sentences of between four and six years in Stralsrund for jumping on the heads of two Vietnamese men in an attack which put one victim into a coma for 10 days. The sentences are greeted as a change in attitude towards racist violence. June Alberto Adriano from Mozambique murdered in Dessau. July Chancellor Gerhard Schröder announces that a crackdown on the far right is a priority of the second half of his government's term. Two days later, a bomb explodes outside a Düsseldorf railway station injuring 10 immigrants. One, a pregnant woman, loses her unborn baby in the attack. August Official committee set up to consider ban on the National Democratic party of Germany (NPD), which has a prominent skinhead element.

fields.headline: Nazia Hassan
fields.trailText: Nazia Hassan, who has died of lung cancer at the age of 35, revolutionised Asian pop music. A singer of rare expressiveness, she pioneered the disco revolution in Indian film music in the 1980s.
fields.body:
Nazia Hassan, who has died of lung cancer at the age of 35, revolutionised Asian pop music. A singer of rare expressiveness, she pioneered the disco revolution in Indian film music in the 1980s.

If Someone Like You Comes Into My Life, the song she sang - as a 15-year-old schoolgirl - in Qurbani (Sacrifice, 1980), was one of the biggest hits in Bollywood film music. Young Asians in the sub-continent and Britain took to the dance floors to its tune.

Born into a well-to-do Karachi family, Nazia came as a teenager to London, where the song was recorded after she had met Bollywood filmmaker Feroz Khan at a party. She was not a trained singer, but Feroz, and the London-based composer Biddu, liked the nasal quality of her voice.

Nazia's association with Biddu brought her into the limelight on the British Asian pop scene. Together, they brought out the immensely successful album, Disco Deewane (1981), which, with its racy songs and harmonious blend of eastern rhythms and western beats, was number one for more than a year. Overnight, Nazia became the queen of Asian pop.

Later, she and her brother, Zohaib Hassan, sang in another Bollywood film, Star. They returned to Pakistan in the early 1980s and released their first album, Young Tarang. Another album, Hotline, followed in 1987. Nazia's last solo album, Camera Camera, came out in London in 1992. Though some of these later albums lacked Nazia's early expressiveness, they still revealed her joie de vivre.

Nazia, who had a London University law degree, lived most of her life in Britain, but always returned to her roots in Pakistan. She was independent, and was never afraid to speak her mind. A lot of her money was given to charity; she also set up an organisation to help the poor, and - even at the peak of her popularity - made special appearances on television shows for children. She spent a lot of time with young people, educating them about the dangers of drugs.

She is survived by her husband and son.

 Nazia Hassan, singer, born April 3 1965; died August 13 2000

fields.headline: TWA air explosion 'not sabotage'
fields.trailText: US safety investigators yesterday ruled out a criminal act as the cause of the explosion that destroyed TWA Flight 800 and killed all 230 people aboard four years ago, and said the most likely cause was an electrical fault.
fields.body:
US safety investigators yesterday ruled out a criminal act as the cause of the explosion that destroyed TWA Flight 800 and killed all 230 people aboard four years ago, and said the most likely cause was an electrical fault.

The national transportation safety board (NTSB) dismissed various conspiracy theories as it began a final review of a report into the crash at a two-day public meeting.

The NTSB chairman, Jim Hall, ruled out sabotage. "Had we found such evidence, we would have immediately referred the matter back to the appropriate law enforcement authorities for their action," he said. "Let me state unequivocally, the safety board found no such evidence."

Flight 800, a Paris-bound Boeing 747-100, crashed into the Atlantic off Long Island 14 minutes after takeoff from New York's Kennedy International Airport on July 17, 1996.

Bernard Loeb, director of the NTSB's office of aviation safety, said the most likely cause of the crash was a short circuit involving electrical wiring leading to the centre-wing fuel tank. Theories ranged from a wiring fault to bombs or a heat-seeking "Stinger" missile. The missile theory circulated after witnesses reported seeing lights streaking upwards at the time of the crash.
Reuters

webTitle: Cambridge graduate trampled by elephant during Africa trip

fields.headline: Cambridge graduate trampled by elephant during Africa trip
fields.trailText: An adventure-seeking Cambridge University graduate on a driving expedition across Africa has been trampled to death by an elephant he was trying to photograph in Kenya.
fields.body:
An adventure-seeking Cambridge University graduate on a driving expedition across Africa has been trampled to death by an elephant he was trying to photograph in Kenya.

Edward Harrison, 28, from Rugby, Warwickshire, is believed to have woken at sunrise and wandered off on his own to photograph wild animals at dawn in the Masai Mara game reserve.

His companions later found his body outside the secure compound of the Sopa safari lodge on Sunday.

He was among a group of 32 driving in Land Rovers on the first leg of an expedition from Cambridge to Cape Town organised by the university's officer training corps. The expedition left on July 10 and arrived in Kenya on the 28th day.

The accident happened when the group, made up largely of students and Territorial Army officers, took a break to go on an organised three day safari before flying home.

Mr Harrison, who graduated in 1995 with an engineering degree, was due to start an MBA in Paris on Friday.

A postmortem examination was expected yesterday. His body will then be flown back to Britain.

Another group is flying out this week to start the second leg, from Kenya to Cape Town.

The trip commemorates the anniversary of battle honours won by the Cambridge University Rifle Volunteers who served with the 1st Battalion of the Suffolk Regiment in the Boer war in 1901.

webTitle: Coalfield town switches to green fuel

fields.headline: Coalfield town switches to green fuel
fields.standfirst: Town where enterprise was underwritten by black gold
fields.trailText: One of the strongest old fortresses of King Coal decided yesterday to cut a symbolic link with mining by voting decisively to heat and light all its council buildings with "green" electricity.
fields.body:
One of the strongest old fortresses of King Coal decided yesterday to cut a symbolic link with mining by voting decisively to heat and light all its council buildings with "green" electricity.

Rotherham council in South Yorkshire will be supplied in future by power from wind turbines and renewable natural sources, including coppiced willow and agricultural waste, in spite of a last ditch rebellion by coalfield campaigners.

A meeting of all the Labour-dominated authority's councillors yesterday backed an earlier decision by the executive "cabinet" to go green on best value grounds. The move will end contracts for energy from a mixture of coal, gas and nuclear power stations, as well as for 3,000 tonnes of coal used each year in council boilers.

"We need to get the best value and to take into account coming environmental measures like the climate control levy," said Mark Edgell, Rotherham council's leader. "But we are emphatically not turning our back on the mining community to which this area owes so much. We are in the forefront of coalfield regeneration and winning huge investment to create a new future for this part of South Yorkshire."

The new power source will save Rotherham an estimated £67,000 initially, balancing the £137,000 it will cost to introduce the change against £204,000 liable for payment under the climate levy. Yesterday's meeting also heard submissions from Yorkshire Electricity and power experts suggesting that green power would be cheaper in the long term.

"There is no longer a direct link between our power demands and Yorkshire coal anyway," said Mr Edgell. "Existing power comes from a mixture of suppliers, and the coal part of it is likely to include imports from overseas. It is much more important for us to concentrate on bids for funding like the £80m South Yorkshire has won in the latest round of the single regeneration budget, or the enormous investment of £780m which the county is getting from Europe."

The decision is likely to win reluctant acceptance from the Coalfields Communities Campaign, a consortium of local councils, including Rotherham, which lobbies regardless of political control. The group's Yorkshire branch has campaigned strongly against the energy switch, but is reluctant to criticise a partner council which has had a high profile in winning regeneration funds.

Coal mining unions, however, remain adamantly opposed to the move, amid fears that Rotherham's last remaining colliery, the RJB pit at Maltby, may lose a proposed £30m coal fired power station. Pat Carragher, general secretary of the British Association of Colliery Managers, joined the pit deputies' union, Nacods, in calling for the council to "continue to fight for the long term future of UK coal" by changing its mind.

Rotherham is the first English council to sign a 100% deal for green electricity, following limited agreements of up to 60% by other authorities. Ken Wyatt, a member of the ruling Labour group, said: "I'm pleased and proud that we are taking the lead for future generations. The council has a responsibility to set an example."

Yorkshire Electricity welcomed the move as a boost to its own increased use of renewable resources such as coppiced willow. The firm assured yesterday's meeting that it would not make extra profits from green power, a premium on which currently pays for the development of renewable fuel generators which should get cheaper as use spreads.

fields.headline: Suitable sitooterie
fields.standfirst: Scots garden follies revisited
fields.trailText: Lord Foster's Docklands bridge may wobble but his sitooterie certainly does not, in spite of the best efforts of Northumberland's breezes and subversive bystanders.
fields.body:
Lord Foster's Docklands bridge may wobble but his sitooterie certainly does not, in spite of the best efforts of Northumberland's breezes and subversive bystanders.

The architect's version of a Scottish summer house (sitooterie means because you "sit oot" in it) was unveiled yesterday in the romantic grounds of Belsay House, near Newcastle upon Tyne, one among 11 commissioned by English Heritage for an exhibition of 21st century versions of these garden follies.

"The aliens have landed," murmured one of the mansion's guides as the wraps were whisked off Foster's silver, inflated (but stable) canopy with its delicate legs. Suitably eerie chords emanated from beneath its roof, as a string quartet emphasised that sitooteries were a place to enjoy music as well as take tea.

The Foster structure, which resisted determined "wobble" pressure, stood alongside the works by Tania Kovats, Julian Opie, Claudio Silverstrin and other designers that have drawn thousands of extra visitors to the mansion.

"The sitooteries are proving that the juxtaposition of contemporary, visually powerful structures with an historic setting is enormously popular," said Peter Bromley, English Heritage's regional director.

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, said the massed follies could only delight and provoke, and guessed that sitooteries might be the next garden centre craze.

Useful link:

Foster and Partners

fields.headline: Town where enterprise was underwritten by black gold
fields.standfirst: Coalfield town switches to green fuel
fields.trailText: Rotherham invented the screw tap and the portable Bailey bridge, but coal was the first and greatest reason for the town's success.
fields.body:
Rotherham invented the screw tap and the portable Bailey bridge, but coal was the first and greatest reason for the town's success.

The sunken dips of medieval bellpits still surround the town and mark where rich seams came helpfully closer to the surface than in neighbouring areas, where it took deep-mining to give the industry domination of the local economy.

By that mid-19th century time Rotherham had used its black gold, and the transport links of the Great North Road and South Yorkshire's waterways, to stimulate other heavy industries. The town became if anything more famous for steel production, inventive engineering, and pottery which produced the vast Rhinoceros Vase, still admired and deplored at the local Clifton House museum.

Rotherham's most productive mining period was as late as the early 1980s, just before the national pit strike, when 11 pits employed some 10,500 men.

Thousands more worked in coal-dependent industries, including the engineering successors of Edward Chrimes, who pioneered the screw tap at his brass foundry in the 1820s.

The only surviving pit, Maltby, now employs 600 men.

webTitle: The girl who loved Bond's creator

fields.headline: The girl who loved Bond's creator
fields.trailText: The story of famous misogynist Ian Fleming's affair with an English rose has resurfaced with the sale of a handful of sepia photographs
fields.body:
She was the Girl Who Loved Him, a highly connected English rose who remained true to Ian Fleming, the creator of James Bond, despite his repeated, 007-like, womanising exploits.

For nine years, from the day she met him aged 21 until her death in 1944, Muriel Wright had a passionate affair with the rakish author who declared women to be "like dogs". He finally tired of her, but when she was killed in an air raid in Belgravia the notorious arch-misogynist was distraught and racked with guilt.

The story of Fleming and his lost love has resurfaced with the forthcoming sale of a handful of sepia photographs unearthed in an Oxford antiques shop.

The pictures - in three dust-covered family albums - would have held little interest for many, but the collector who bought them was sufficiently intrigued to identify the pre-war figures captured in fading black and white.

With only a faded signature to help him, the buyer - remaining anonymous for the time being - discovered the albums' first owner was Violet Wright, Muriel's sister, and that the photographs included several of Fleming's one time lover, from childhood to her 21st birthday just weeks before they met. The albums cover 1915 to 1935.

Yesterday, the collector, who comes from Essex, said: "I came across them by accident when I was browsing in an antiques shop in Oxford and they were in a couple of books I bought.

"The name Wright meant absolutely nothing to me, but the photos were obviously of a well connected family and I recognised "Elwes", another name in the album, which was connected to Lord Lucan, so I was intrigued."

His search took him to Yeldersley Hall, the Wright family home in Derbyshire, where he learned of Muriel, the accomplished daughter of an MP who had the looks of a model and was noted as a polo player. Muriel, who was called "Mu" by Fleming, is referred to as "Mu Mu" or "Moo Moo" in the photographs, fell in love with the author shortly after they met during the summer of 1935 in the fashionable ski resort of Kitzbüuhel in the Austrian Tyrol.

Fleming was entranced, but as the relationship progressed later treated he began to treat her badly, pursuing affairs with three or four other girlfriends including his future wife, then Lady Ann O'Neill. Muriel's family were so incensed, her brother Fitzherbert, who had been at Eton with the Bond creator, threatened to horse-whip him. Fleming apparently fled to Brighton.

The albums, which hold pictures of her and Fitzherbert, will be auctioned in London next month.

Rupert Powell, a director of Bloomsbury Book Auctions, which is conducting the sale on September 7, said the estimated price was £200 but the vogue for Ian Fleming meant this could easily be exceeded.

fields.headline: Worthington Cup round-up
fields.trailText: Fulham suffered their first hiccup of the season last night, Marco Gabbiadini's 24th-minute goal securing a surprise 1-0 home victory for Northampton on the opening night of Worthington Cup warfare.
fields.body:
Fulham suffered their first hiccup of the season last night, Marco Gabbiadini's 24th-minute goal securing a surprise 1-0 home victory for Northampton on the opening night of Worthington Cup warfare.

But the Londoners were not the only Premiership promotion hopefuls to stumble. Watford face a testing return leg at Whaddon Road after being held to a goalless draw by Cheltenham , Bolton had to call on an 84th-minute strike by Dean Holdsworth to beat Macclesfield 1-0, and Carlo Corazzin was on target as Oldham upset Huddersfield 1-0.

Late goals from Steve Foster and Mark Rivers rescued Crewe from embarrassment at home after they trailed Bury 2-0 with six minutes to go. But Wolves lost, Matt Murphy's goal for Oxford United at Molineux going unanswered, and Blackpool beat Stockport 1-0.

There was good news for Grimsby fans, the assistant manager John Cockerill - in charge after Alan Buckley's sacking yesterday - celebrating with a 2-0 win over Carlisle , Stacy Coldicott and Bradley Allen the scorers.

webTitle: United fall down on the Town

fields.headline: United fall down on the Town
fields.trailText: Ipswich matched and at times surpassed Manchester United last night as they earned a draw against the champions at Portman Road.
fields.body:
Ipswich not only managed to eyeball Manchester United here last night but at times threatened to stare the champions down. Certainly George Burley's newly promoted side had the better of a fast and entertaining draw which offered early evidence of the Suffolk team's ability to survive back in the Premiership.

The problems the Ipswich attack caused Sir Alex Ferguson's defenders were less of a surprise than the stubborn efficiency with which their defence limited United to a sprinkling of scoring opportunities. To be sure Richard Wright's goalkeeping helped but then Fabien Barthez was hardly idle at the other end.

United were never allowed to settle into the confident stride that had enabled them to stroll past Newcastle two days earlier. The speed and tenacity with which Ipswich tracked down opponents, denying them time and space on the ball, had much to do with that.

An exceptionally fit team, Ipswich needed all their stamina to maintain the ferocious pace they had set themselves. In midfield Jim Magilton, Matt Holland and Jermaine Wright performed crucial roles in preventing Roy Keane and Paul Scholes linking up with United's strikers, and though Ryan Giggs occasionally got behind the Ipswich defence neither he nor David Beckham, booked late in the match for ironically applauding the referee, posed a consistent threat.

Jeff Winter booked four United players, three of them for dissent, which led Ferguson to voice his own counterview. "Some of these referees nowadays are absolute prima donnas," he said. "They make problems for themselves."

This result will have banished some of the doubts raised about the ability of the Ipswich defence to live comfortably in the Premiership. Last night Hermann Hreidarsson, Burley's £4m signing from Wimbledon, was a dominant figure in a back three which refused to be panicked by the fame of the opposition.

In fact Jaap Stam and Ronnie Wallwork, who had replaced the injured Ronny Johnsen, looked more nervous when taken on for pace and wit by David Johnson and Marcus Stewart, whose speed on the counterattack never allowed the United defenders to settle.

In budgeting for the 40 or so points they will need to survive this season Ipswich were never going to bank on getting much from their encounters with United, so last night's point was something of a bonus. It also laid the ghost of the 9-0 drubbing inflicted on them by United in their last league meeting five years ago.

Ipswich, naturally buoyant after winning promotion, took the game to their opponents. That much was expected. What was not expected, however, was the speed and the ease with which they took the lead in the sixth minute.

Nothing if not an intelligent team with good passing habits, Ipswich cleverly used Johnson to draw defenders out of position, Phil Neville among them. As Neville abandoned his station at left-back Johnson laid the ball out to the advancing Fabian Wilnis, who moved in unchallenged to drive the ball low past Barthez.

United drew level when Wallwork dummied over an inswinging free-kick from Beckham, completely fooling Wright. Yet they still could not raise their game sufficiently to win it and had Barthez not leapt to his left to keep out a header from Jamie Clapham 20 minutes from the end they might well have lost.

fields.headline: Cup final punch 'captured on TV'
fields.trailText: A Tottenham Hotspur football fan was captured on closed circuit television attacking a rival fan during last year's Worthington Cup final, Harrow crown court, in north London, heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Tottenham Hotspur football fan was captured on closed circuit television attacking a rival fan during last year's Worthington Cup final, Harrow crown court, in north London, heard yesterday.

Ruth Lelacheur, 30, suffered bruising to the back of her ear and a damaged tooth as a result of the alleged attack by Jonathan Edmonds at Wembley stadium in March last year.

Edmonds, 31, of Slough, Berkshire, denied charges of affray and actual bodily harm.

Michael Latham, prosecuting, said Miss Lelacheur, a Leicester City fan, was in a family enclosure with her partner and her daughter, Megan, three, when a dispute arose about the presence of Spurs fans.

He said Megan fell and Miss Lelacheur felt blows to the ear and to her jaw.

After the pictures were shown on Crimewatch, Mr Edmonds went to a police station and denied assault.

Mr Latham said Mr Edmonds claimed he was pushed over and hit out in self defence. "He is saying the blows were not directed at Miss Lelacheur."

Miss Lelacheur told the court there had been a carnival atmosphere in the ground just before the incident.

"But then not long after kick-off we heard a group of about five to seven Tottenham fans sitting just behind us shouting: 'We are Tottenham, We are Tottenham.'

"A lot of Leicester fans then started shouting that the Spurs fans should not have been in that part of the ground.

"My partner, Jim, called over a supervisor and told him that people were not happy with the situation as things could turn nasty and there were a lot of children around.

"The Spurs fans had stopped shouting at this time and the supervisor told my partner to sit down and shut up and that the fans were not doing anything."

Shortly afterwards, she was pushed into a gangway and her daughter fell to the floor.

"I then felt several punches. All I was thinking about was Megan. I felt two blows, one to my left jaw and one to the right side behind my ear."

She suffered severe bruising behind her right ear and pain in her jaw. One of her teeth had crumbled.

Cross-examining, Gavin Meerylees said he did not dispute that Miss Lelacheur had been hit by his client.

He said: "The trouble started, did it not, when people realised Tottenham fans were in that area and Leicester fans objected to that?

"One reason those fans got into that part of the ground was that tickets had been sold by some of the Leicester players and had been bought by some of the Spurs fans."

The trial continues today.

webTitle: Chelsea suffer northern exposure as Windass and Carbone blow away Blues

fields.headline: Chelsea suffer northern exposure as Windass and Carbone blow away Blues
fields.trailText: Not for the first time in recent seasons Chelsea travelled away from the capital only to find themselves undone by a team of relatively meagre resources, and a certain Benito Carbone.
fields.body:
On those countless occasions when Chelsea slip to ignominious defeat against unfancied opposition a long way from home, there is invariably a moral to the story.

It usually revolves around the old argument that, even if a team can be crammed with gifted footballers, the whole costly exercise will prove to be pointless if they are incapable of summoning up sufficient pride and self-respect to scrap like wounded prizefighters when the going gets tough.

For Chelsea the going always seems to get tough when they are asked to head north and stand toe to toe with a team of relatively meagre resources and limited ambition.

At the final whistle last night an exaltant Valley Parade rose to acclaim the laying in place of the first brick in a wall which Bradford City believe will, come season's end, have preserved their Premiership status.

Legions of chest-thumping Yorkshiremen were also laughing at the King's Road Millionaires who departed for the dressing room with their heads bowed, their reputation soiled and their claim of technical superiority shredded.

Just when it appeared that Chelsea had reluctantly agreed that good teams deliver irrespective of their surroundings, this wretched performance dispelled the notion.

They had their chances but in truth their football was so pedestrian, so bland, so lacking in pace that they deserved nothing but the derision of their supporters and the condemnation of their manager Gianluca Vialli.

"Our performance was just not good enough," he said. "It hurts me much more to lose at places like this than to lose against the likes of Leeds United and Manchester United.

"If we are ever to win the Premiership we have to start winning these kinds of games.

"Tonight we played in a hurry; we played as individuals, not as a team."

Bradford may well be a team awash with battle-hardened veterans who are, perhaps, enjoying one last cameo appearance on the big stage, but they were marvellous in their industry.

On Saturday at Anfield their manager Chris Hutchings could find no place for Benito Carbone. But after that defeat by Liverpool the expensive and moody Italian was drafted in to add a dash of flair to a side who, on occasions last season, almost seemed to revel in their anonymity.

Predictably Carbone ran the show from the first minute to the 75th, the moment when he steered in from distance to embarrass the Chelsea goalkeeper Ed de Goey and confirm Bradford's victory.

Bradford gift more space and time to their opponents than most and from the start it seemed probable that Chelsea would gorge themselves on possession.

To a certain extent they did but too often their best work was undertaken in central midfield. Bradford were always diligent but created very little.

Even so, midway through a tepid opening half they scored almost as if to remind Chelsea that complacency is always the enemy within.

From a Chelsea perspective it was a truly awful goal, for having permitted Lee Sharpe to cross from the left flank they stood and watched as Dean Windass steered a fine header just inside the far post.

"If am proud of them, I really am," said Hutchings.

He had every right to be.
